story:
About "Desire & the Sea"

Edgar Oliver is a legendary actor, playwright and poet who has been active in New York's downtown theatre community since the 1980's.  Over the past thirty years, he has produced a body of work that the New Yorker's  Hilton Als calls "emotionally grand." 

As a playwright and stage actor, he has written and performed in plays that were regularly staged at La MaMa and other downtown venues.  He has also been a sought-after actor in a myriad of other plays, most notably with the Axis Theatre Company under the direction of Randy Sharp.  

Among his most important achievements are three acclaimed one-man shows: East 10th Street: Self Portrait with Empty House (directed by Randy Sharp); Helen & Edgar  (directed by Catherine Burns); and most recently, In the  Park (also directed by Randy Sharp).   The In his review of East 10th Street, the New York Times' Ben Brantley called Edgar "a living work of theatre all by himself."   He later described Helen & Edgar  as "utterly absorbing,"   And Hilton Als called In the Park "...enthralling...a love story about moments and sensations."  

Edgar is also one of the most beloved storytellers at The Moth.   

In 2011, Edgar began a performance collaboration with The Octave Doktors.  On April 28, 2014, Edgar and the Doktors performed a concert of poems and readings at Sideshows by the Seashore on Coney Island.  It was the latest in a long line of collaborations between Edgar and the Doktors.  The evening's program brought together the music of the Doktors with a selection of Edgar's poems and monologues from plays spanning the past twenty-five years, including Summer   and Motel Blue 19, all focused on the themes of longing and the sea.   

It was an exceptional evening of poetry and prose featuring haunted swimming pools, a talking undertow, a ship of words,  a macabre road trip, and moments of urgent longing.  The evening's program represented a high point in the artistic collaboration between Edgar and the Doktors.

The Doktors have successfully recorded and produced two albums of their music, and have recorded and uploaded many of the pieces they've created with Edgar.  They are now preparing an album of the spoken word and musical content from Desire & the Sea, along with a number of other collaborative pieces.     

Edgar and the Doktors need to raise $1,300.00 for the costs related to creating the album. 

— Recording
— Mixing
— Production of CDs
— Paying musicians and performers

They are offering a range of great perks for those who are able to contribute to the project:

— Digital downloads and physical copies of the album
— Handmade books and other handmade artifacts from Oilcan Press, signed by Edgar
— DVDs of The Hermit and Other Poems featuring Edgar reading from this work in the house on East 10th Street
— CDs of other music by the Octave Doktors

___________________________________________________________________

For more information about Edgar's career and work, please visit: 
http://edgaroliver.wordpress.com/about/.

Edgar's books of poetry are published by Oilcan Press:  https://www.etsy.com/shop/oilcanpress
___________________________________________________________________

The bandmates of the Octave Doktors are: 

Sami Buccella — bass, keys, percussion
Jeff Burns — banjo, bass, clarinet, vox
Aaron Howard — jew's harp, strings, tibetan signing bowls, typewriter, words 
Andy Lachance — guitar and organ
Ghost Pat — guitar
Sarah Moskowitz — bass, drums, keys, typewriter, ukulele
Angela Rogers — vox

The Octave Doktors have written and recorded dozens of unique songs and spoken word pieces.  You can listen to some of them here: 
https://soundcloud.com/octave-doktors
http://octavedoktors.bandcamp.com/

story:
Hey There!

Hi! We're Allison Walter and Kristin Shoffner and we just started our own production company. We just graduated with BFA degrees from UCF and are trying to get started.

Check out our website to get the whole picture: 

Http://fwpproductionco.wix.com/home

Our Deal

We were selected to be a part of Orlando's 2013 Fringe Festival but need a little help getting there. We're producing Lesyle Headland's wickedly hilarious play Bachelorette. Our dreams are big, but our wallets are not. And it costs money to put on a good show. Thats why we need your help!

What we're asking

We're asking for $1200. Over the course of 4 months - That's only $10 a day! 

The money will be going toward production costs such as:

  • Renting rehearsal space
  • Festival Application Fees
  • Props 
  • Costumes
  • Lighting and Sound
  • Rights to do the production

Why you should totally donate

If we reach our goal we get to keep all our money and Indiegogo only gets 4% comission. If we don't reach our goal they get to keep 9% of the funds. Plus with your help we will be able to create a fully produced production. Not only will the show be great but you'll be supporting young artists and our dreams! 

If you're broke (like us)

Times are hard. If you don't have any spare change to throw our way, come see our show anyway! Check out the Fringe website and get your tickets now!

  • www.orlandofringe.org

Thank you!        We love you!        Every dollar helps!

story:
Hi my name is Eden, & I'm a dancer. To be specific, I dance ballet.

I live in Minneapolis, Minnesota. It's a great city with a lot of support for the arts. Great music, great theatre, great museums & galleries. But what Minneapolis doesn't have is a reputable ballet company with a summer intensive training program for young dancers like me. That’s why my acceptance to the Boston Ballet School's Summer Intensive program is a great opportunity to get advanced training from professional dancers, choreographers, and connect with other young dancers like me.

My expectations weren’t set on being accepted when I auditioned because there are lots of great dancers trying to get spots in summer intensives. It’s tough to get accepted and invited to attend. It surprised me when The Boston Ballet School emailed me to invite me to their summer intensive program, and I was being moved into a higher age bracket alongside accomplished dancers.

What I Need - And What You Can Expect

Opportunities don’t come without a cost. The summer intensive program is 5 weeks in Boston this summer, and it’s not cheap. I'm here on IndieGogo to raise $6500 for tuition, lodging, and airfare. I won't be able to attend this intensive program without your help.

If you're interested in getting involved with my effort to attend the 2015 Boston Summer Intensive, I want to thank you in advance. If you back my campaign you'll receive emailed updates every week. Depending on which perk you select you'll have access to video, images, and even prints from ballet-themed concept art I'm developing with Miles Heille; my brother and professional lens-wielder.

Make A Difference

Ballet summer intensives are an essential part of a dancer’s development. The opportunity to work with world renowned choreographers, trainers, and other dancers with similar passion and focus will prepare me for a professional career in ballet. 

Your support makes you an awesome human who values the artistic and physical  discipline of ballet, and a supporter of the arts in general!

Your help extends beyond this campaign. If this is successful I want to share my experience with other dancers to help them take advantage of their opportunities that may be out of financial reach. My story, which hopefully is the story of a network of friends like you working together to get this done, can encourage others and demonstrate a practical method to accomplish the goal.

What Can Go Wrong & How To Manage It

Opportunities are wonderful, but they always have an element of risk. I face a risk in falling short of meeting my goal. I have family members with successful crowdfunding experience who are helping me put together and monitor my campaign. They've offered to jump in and offer more exposure and ideas if needed. I've selected flexible funding here on Indiegogo that allows me to put pledges toward my goal whether or not the full target is reached.

Ballet is an athletic activity, and can expose dancers to injury. In November and December of last year I worked very hard to recover from nerve damage in my shoulder, just in time to dance the lead in The Nutcracker. If you've experienced physical therapy you know there's no guarantee to the process, but you won't improve if you don't give it your best effort. Thankfully I've had a full recovery. Injury is always a risk, but my instructors and I work hard to keep me conditioned and in proper technique to prevent injury from happening again.

Other Ways You Can Help

My grandma always says "many hands make light work." Awareness is an important element to finding any solution. 

• Your best support might be sharing a link to my campaign with everyone you know. 

• Indiegogo makes it simple - use the link to share on Facebook, Twitter, Pinterest, Instagram, or whatever new social media network pops up in the next forty days.

• Support summer enrichment programs for kids in your community, whatever the discipline may be. 

Thank You For Considering My Campaign

If you're still looking at this, thanks for taking the time to read all of the way through. I had some help from some talented friends to put this together. My brother, Miles Heille, is pretty good behind a lens. My dad, Chris Heille, encouraged me and helped me put this campaign page together. Special thanks to my studio's director, Ashley Burkland, for her guidance and training for the last few years. Ashley Ballet Arts Academy and has been a great environment for young dancers has an awesome roster of instructors! And thank you again for considering my campaign. Boston, here I come!

story:
Why shouldn’t puppets sign?

ALL-IN PRODUCTIONS sets down its roots in the east to create new theatre made differently.

We are going to produce for the stage Phil Johnson’s locally set story ‘The Little Blue Boat and the Secret of the Broads!’ in May 2015 for a small scale regional tour. This tales sees Able Sea Bear charter his way through the Norfolk Broads making friends and having an adventure on the way. These performances will be accompanied with free drama workshops for children from all back grounds to engage in and learn more about acting, signing, describing and working with disabilities. A teacher of the deaf ‘this is great, Oliver [a Deaf child] is really excelling; everyone is speaking his language for the first time ever’.

This is the second project from All-In Productions; the first a research and development of this story was made possible by a grant from Norfolk County Council and was supported using public funding by the National Lottery through Arts Council England. The first project explored the techniques needed to attempt to stage a performance for audiences who are Deaf, visually or hearing impaired, this culminated in a successful scratch production which we are now mounting into a fully realised stage performance.

What We Need 

We need your support to fund for a communication support worker in the rehearsal room to work with the actors on a sign integrated performance. This £1750 will cover these costs and enable the company to improve the level of accessibility of the performance which is set to perform around the East. 

The Impact

We want to build on the work conducted during the research and development project in October 2014, with the Artistic Director conducting pre-production R&D, exploring the barriers that audience members with a Learning Disability or Autism face when attending the theatre and how these can be removed or made easy for the individual to participate in theatre more easily as an audience member.  This will be achieved by working with a number of partnering organisations and facilitating interactive workshops where this topic will be addressed.

At present, most long-running shows schedule one relaxed performance a year for audience members with Autism or Learning Disabilities. However, 2 million people whose lives are affected by autism, either by having the condition themselves or as a family member of someone with Autism: one performance of a show where audience members can be themselves and respond to the art in whatever way they choose hardly seems a high enough frequency of performances. In addition, Autism or Learning disabilities are often coupled with a physical disability that requires a person to use a wheelchair permanently: consider how few wheelchair spaces theatres have on offer at each performance and suddenly what is offered becomes a lot less, with appropriate tickets for these seats become like gold dust. We think this is unacceptable and want to change it.

 This is all about the collaborative process of developing the work with the audience that it is destined for and therefore feeds heavily from the workshop. Only 15 % of the Deaf, hearing or visually impaired children that we have worked with have attended the theatre. In fact the deaf children who hadn’t been to the theatre didn’t know the sign for the theatre or indeed couldn’t understand what it was, therefore unlikely to engage for themselves. This is why we have elected to engage with the communities and organisations that are likely to bring children in groups to the productions.

Risks & Challenges

This production is obviously costing more than £1750, the rest of the money is coming from a variety of sources, we are waiting the outcome of Arts Council England funding, to which we are quietly confident as we have previously been funded by them for the Research and Development for this production. We also have received some financial support from trusts and foundations and other money pledged to the cause.

If you have any questions you can contact us through our website and we can answer any queries you may have: www.All-InProductions.co.uk

Other Ways You Can Help

Follow us on Facebook and twitter and share this campaign with your friends and help us open up the world of theatre to new audience who haven't had a chance to experience it like this.

story:
UPDATE:

Why are we selling the tickets through an INDIEGOGO page?

We considered using a separate website for you to purchase tickets for PLUNGE, but but between the extra fees and complications--it just wasn't worth it for you or us. 

PRE-SALE tickets are ONLY being sold on this INDIEGOGO page. Donate $7.00 and your name will be placed on the list. (You can also buy a ticket through one of the team members in person with cash, to make things really easy.)

Make sure to indicate which date (30 or 31) you are planning to attend! :) 

Tickets will be $10.00 at the door. So get yours now and save a few bucks!

______________________________________

What is PLUNGE?

A one-woman show. A swim lesson. An exploration of childhood, fear, and balance. A young girl asking difficult questions about the way our world works (and doesn't). 

Born out of a fascination with water, PLUNGE pushes the limits of solo performance and blends traditional theatre with inspiration from circus arts and a friendly dollop of audience participation. 

GET YR TICKETS NOW (by donating here!)

$7.00 each
August 30th, 31st at 8pm
The Sherry Theatre
North Hollywood, Los Angeles

Why a West Coast Premiere?

We've been adapting, expanding, and fine-tuning PLUNGE to better tell this story since it was born back in January 2015. PLUNGE has recently evolved and found its footing through two workshop performances in May and June in Orange County. We are so excited to have the opportunity to perform at The Sherry Theatre in Los Angeles on August 30 and 31! The Sherry Theatre is an intimate North Hollywood space built on nurturing new theatre and emerging artists (read: us)! The West Coast premiere brings you PLUNGE as a newly complete production, AND introduces the thrill of aerial silks to the performance! 

And even this isn't even our final form: by performing in August in an established theatre for an amazing audience, we'll be prepared to launch PLUNGE into the circuit of solo performance, fringe, and arts festivals around the country. We're looking to bring PLUNGE to many new locations, to share the story and grow our artistic family. (So if you don't live in Los Angeles, donating can help bring the show to you, too!) This premiere will give us footage, credits, and connections to make our plans for 2016, 2017, and onwards happen. We've got big dreams and an even bigger work ethic. 

We would be honored to have you join us in taking the first step on an exciting journey!


We Need Your Help!

We have almost all of the elements of this production purchased (costumes, set, lights, camera, sound, marketing), but we need help with a few of the bigger costs. Your donation would go towards the following:

1. Rental of The Sherry Theatre's space (2 nights): $335
2. Royal blue Aerial Silk and Hookup Equipment and Professional Rigging: $240

= $575 Goal!


Want to see the show? The EASIEST way to get your TICKET to PLUNGE is by donating to the campaign! 

Just $7.00 gets you a ticket, a Thank You card in the mail, and a shout-out on our Facebook page. So much love!

(Check out our PERKS to see how easy it really is.)


About Us:

GENEVIEVE SIMON (Writer, Performer) is an actor focused on devised, solo, and physical theatre. She has trained with Tim Robbins' The Actor's Gang in Los Angeles, Upright Citizen's Brigade, and The Royal Shakespeare Company (in collaboration with Ohio State University). She has worked with Robert Post Comedy Theatre, and her previous solo show, "MAPS: Where Do We Go From Here?", was performed in Columbus, Ohio at Kafe Kerouac, Ohio State University, and various found spaces. She is currently training in aerial silks and lyra at Firestorm Freerunning and Acrobatics in Santa Ana, CA. Genevieve looks to make theatre a place to learn, listen, and demand social justice.
(Genevieve has also been teaching swim lessons to all ages for the past 8 years, and is certified by the American Red Cross in CPR/First Aid and as a Water Safety Instructor.)
www.genevieve-simon.com

JEREMY CHARLES HOHN (Director) is a performer and artist living in Orange County, California. His passions lie in physical theatre and collaborative arts with a particular interest in puppetry and mask work. When Genevieve asked him to help shape her vision for PLUNGE he was both challenged and excited. Excited, to be working with such a daring and colorful talent, and challenged, because his recent work is often without text. He thinks this one-person show is charming in its presentation and play; PLUNGE stands (or rather swims) atop a strong and relatable foundation reminding that fear can overwhelm and cripple us at any age, but our lives are determined by the strokes and actions we make to improve and rise above them.

DALIA ANDERTON is an actress and graphic designer who made the beautiful logo for our show! Find her on Facebook and tell her she's awesome.

MEGAN LEANNE GAINEY (Producer) is so proud and excited to have the opportunity to be a part of this production. While most of her theatrical work pertains to acting, Megan is incredibly passionate about working with the development of new plays. With a passion for social justice, she focuses a lot of her attention on work that allows those with a story to tell find their voice to tell it. She was a part of the creative team of [Our Life]: The Black Youth Stories Project at UC Irvine and will be working with Theatreworks in Colorado Springs this summer as Sybil in Private Lives. Other credits include the world premiere of The Last Lifeboat*(Florence) The Two Gentlemen of Verona (Julia) and an all-female version of Hamlet.  meganlgainey.weebly.com

ROSS JACKSON (Producer) is very proud to be a part of this production. He has produced projects in Southern California and Little Rock, AR including [Our Life]: The Black Youth Stories Project (UC, Irvine), The Dwarf (Counter-Balance Theater), Coup de Comedy Festival (Improv Revolution), and AiR Summer Dance Concerts 2011 & 2012 (Artists in Resonance) and is currently helping to develop two new, unnamed social justice projects. Ross believes in the power of sharing stories and feels a true responsibility to be sure that every voice has a chance to be heard, particularly those of the marginalized and underrepresented. M.F.A. in Drama from University of California, Irvine.



Want to PLUNGE even further? 

Check out our Facebook page, website, and Pinterest page below!

Pinterest page: https://www.pinterest.com/genesimon/plunge/
story_txt:
UPDATE:Why are we selling the tickets through an INDIEGOGO page?We considered using a separate website for you to purchase tickets for PLUNGE, but but between the extra fees and complications--it just wasn't worth it for you or us. 
PRE-SALE tickets are ONLY being sold on this INDIEGOGO page. Donate $7.00 and your name will be placed on the list. (You can also buy a ticket through one of the team members in person with cash, to make things really easy.)

Make sure to indicate which date (30 or 31) you are planning to attend! :) 
Tickets will be $10.00 at the door. So get yours now and save a few bucks!
______________________________________What is PLUNGE? A one-woman show. A swim lesson. An exploration of childhood, fear, and balance. A young girl asking difficult questions about the way our world works (and doesn't). Born out of a fascination with water, PLUNGE pushes the limits of solo performance and blends traditional theatre with inspiration from circus arts and a friendly dollop of audience participation. GET YR TICKETS NOW (by donating here!)$7.00 eachAugust 30th, 31st at 8pmThe Sherry TheatreNorth Hollywood, Los AngelesWhy a West Coast Premiere?We've been adapting, expanding, and fine-tuning PLUNGE to better tell this story since it was born back in January 2015. PLUNGE has recently evolved and found its footing through two workshop performances in May and June in Orange County. We are so excited to have the opportunity to perform at The Sherry Theatre in Los Angeles on August 30 and 31! The Sherry Theatre is an intimate North Hollywood space built on nurturing new theatre and emerging artists (read: us)! The West Coast premiere brings you PLUNGE as a newly complete production, AND introduces the thrill of aerial silks to the performance! And even this isn't even our final form: by performing in August in an established theatre for an amazing audience, we'll be prepared to launch PLUNGE into the circuit of solo performance, fringe, and arts festivals around the country. We're looking to bring PLUNGE to many new locations, to share the story and grow our artistic family. (So if you don't live in Los Angeles, donating can help bring the show to you, too!) This premiere will give us footage, credits, and connections to make our plans for 2016, 2017, and onwards happen. We've got big dreams and an even bigger work ethic. We would be honored to have you join us in taking the first step on an exciting journey!We Need Your Help!We have almost all of the elements of this production purchased (costumes, set, lights, camera, sound, marketing), but we need help with a few of the bigger costs. Your donation would go towards the following:1. Rental of The Sherry Theatre's space (2 nights): $3352. Royal blue Aerial Silk and Hookup Equipment and Professional Rigging: $240= $575 Goal!
Want to see the show? The EASIEST way to get your TICKET to PLUNGE is by donating to the campaign! Just $7.00 gets you a ticket, a Thank You card in the mail, and a shout-out on our Facebook page. So much love!(Check out our PERKS to see how easy it really is.)About Us:GENEVIEVE SIMON (Writer, Performer) is an actor focused on devised, solo, and physical theatre. She has trained with Tim Robbins' The Actor's Gang in Los Angeles, Upright Citizen's Brigade, and The Royal Shakespeare Company (in collaboration with Ohio State University). She has worked with Robert Post Comedy Theatre, and her previous solo show, "MAPS: Where Do We Go From Here?", was performed in Columbus, Ohio at Kafe Kerouac, Ohio State University, and various found spaces. She is currently training in aerial silks and lyra at Firestorm Freerunning and Acrobatics in Santa Ana, CA. Genevieve looks to make theatre a place to learn, listen, and demand social justice.(Genevieve has also been teaching swim lessons to all ages for the past 8 years, and is certified by the American Red Cross in CPR/First Aid and as a Water Safety Instructor.)www.genevieve-simon.comJEREMY CHARLES HOHN (Director) is a performer and artist living in Orange County, California. His passions lie in physical theatre and collaborative arts with a particular interest in puppetry and mask work. When Genevieve asked him to help shape her vision for PLUNGE he was both challenged and excited. Excited, to be working with such a daring and colorful talent, and challenged, because his recent work is often without text. He thinks this one-person show is charming in its presentation and play; PLUNGE stands (or rather swims) atop a strong and relatable foundation reminding that fear can overwhelm and cripple us at any age, but our lives are determined by the strokes and actions we make to improve and rise above them.DALIA ANDERTON is an actress and graphic designer who made the beautiful logo for our show! Find her on Facebook and tell her she's awesome.MEGAN LEANNE GAINEY (Producer) is so proud and excited to have the opportunity to be a part of this production. While most of her theatrical work pertains to acting, Megan is incredibly passionate about working with the development of new plays. With a passion for social justice, she focuses a lot of her attention on work that allows those with a story to tell find their voice to tell it. She was a part of the creative team of [Our Life]: The Black Youth Stories Project at UC Irvine and will be working with Theatreworks in Colorado Springs this summer as Sybil in Private Lives. Other credits include the world premiere of The Last Lifeboat*(Florence) The Two Gentlemen of Verona (Julia) and an all-female version of Hamlet.  meganlgainey.weebly.comROSS JACKSON (Producer) is very proud to be a part of this production. He has produced projects in Southern California and Little Rock, AR including [Our Life]: The Black Youth Stories Project (UC, Irvine), The Dwarf (Counter-Balance Theater), Coup de Comedy Festival (Improv Revolution), and AiR Summer Dance Concerts 2011 & 2012 (Artists in Resonance) and is currently helping to develop two new, unnamed social justice projects. Ross believes in the power of sharing stories and feels a true responsibility to be sure that every voice has a chance to be heard, particularly those of the marginalized and underrepresented. M.F.A. in Drama from University of California, Irvine.

Want to PLUNGE even further? Check out our Facebook page, website, and Pinterest page below!Pinterest page: https://www.pinterest.com/genesimon/plunge/

story:
Who are you again?

We are Vanessa Labrie and Kathleen Glynn, co-founders of Trip & Guts Theatre, the first and only theatre company in the United Kingdom to showcase Québec new writing.

We've cofounded the company as a way to give a voice to Québec culture in the United Kingdom and build bridges between both cultures.

Our first production, Cut Throat (Tranche-Cul) by Jean-Philippe Baril Guérard, was a huge success at the Camden Fringe, last year, receiving multiple four star reviews and generating profit as well.

We're thrilled to be back with our second production, Clean Slate,  directed by Deborah Kearne, and starring Asha Cluer, Lauren Douglin, Clara Emanuel, Kathleen Glynn, Vanessa Labrie, and Hannah Wilder.

Table Rase (French title) was originally written by Catherine Chabot in Montreal, with the collaboration of Brigitte Poupart, Vicky Bertrand, Marie-Anick Blais, Rose-Anne Déry, Sarah Laurendeau, and Marie-Noëlle Voisin.

Right. And what is it you're up to now?

We are performing Clean Slate 20-21-22-23-24 and 28-29 June + 9, 12-13 July 2017 at The Courtyard Theatre. You can book HERE.

Okay, and why should I help out this year?

Clean Slate gives an important voice to women who are usually confined to archetypes: the wife, the mistress, the teacher, the list goes on. As a matter of fact, the largest ever analysis of film dialogue was recently published and the most abysmal statistic was found to be "when women occupy at least 2 of the top 3 roles in a film, which occurs in 18% of our films. That same scenario for men occurs in about 82% of films."

The play is the result of the collaborative effort of seven Québécois women who had a strong urge to show women the way they are, in all their complexity, as human beings. It's safe to say they've succeeded, as the play won Best New Writing at the Prix de la Critique Awards in Québec. The story is gut-wrenching, hilarious and moving, leaving the audience to feel like they're not supposed to be there. 

On top of that, we have a fantastic and diverse cast of women coming from all parts of the world and our director and mentor, Deborah Kearne has led this ship brilliantly.

We are so honoured to be able to continue to make you laugh, think, and dream again this year, and we are excited for the discussions this play is going to stir up.

Gotcha. *Pulls out wallet* How much do you need?

We're looking to raise about £2000. We know. It's A LOT. But get this: it won't even cover our total production costs.  However, last year's campaign was such a success, we're confident that we can rally people once more this year. With your help, we'll be able to cover most of the costs for the venue, the marketing material, rehearsal spaces, and props. And a lot of the unplanned and unforeseen stuff.

Making theatre is very costly and involves many sleepless nights. We want for you to know the costs that go into producing a show and for you to feel like you've made a difference in our production, which is why we've designed our perks in such a straight-forward way.

And is there any other way I can support you ladies?

There are plenty of extra ways to show us your love. Here are a few...

  •  If you haven't already, follow us on Twitter @tripandguts , re-tweet us and share the good news!
  • Invite your friends/family/local butcher/florist/etc. to the show.
  • Book your tickets online now HERE.
  • Take a look at our website.

Et un petit mot en français...

story:
DAS Spring Theatre Festival

We're the Dead Arts Society (DAS), a UC Davis student organization focusing on producing original works of student written theatre. At the moment, we're working to fund our Spring Quarter Theatre Festival consisting of two original full-length plays and two one-act plays, one of which is a musical! With about thirty performers and countless other students involved as writers, directors, and stage managers, we're hoping that YOU can help bring these original student-written pieces to life!

We Need Your Help!

In the past, we've performed our shows in a relatively small theatre that seats approximately 60 people. If the audience fills up (which it often does), though, we're forced to turn people away. This quarter, however, we didn't want to deny anyone the opportunity to see these four incredible shows, so we decided to rent a larger theater! Larger spaces, however, are more expensive and since we never charge for tickets, we need your charitable donations to make these plays a reality! Any contribution (seriously -- even $1) helps us get one step closer to making these plays accessible to everyone as well as encouraging the incredible creativity and artistic talent of all UCD students!

More About The Plays...

Dinner, written by John Malin, is a farcical comedy about a nice family dinner that goes horribly wrong. Harold has invited his whole family to a nice restaurant for dinner, at the end of which he plans on (finally) proposing to his girlfriend, Penelope. However, as Harold's family arrives, things start become complicated very fast. Soon it seems clear that no one is quite who they say they are and everyone has something to hide. Dinner features lies, secrets, infidelity, twelve ridiculous characters, and a whole lot of cutlery.

Natalie (Micaela Cirimeli)

The Blood Law, written by Rachel Pevsner, is a one-act play about three young adults who set out to change the world—and the trouble they run into during their attempt.  Humorously told with the assistance of "radio" and "television" announcers, The Blood Law creates a world of the near future where free speech is at a minimum and anything can happen to those who speak out.

All Dried Up! (Jenny Adler)

PERFORMANCES

May 31, June 1, 2, 6, 7, and 8 at 8PM in Wyatt Theatre on the UC Davis campus.

More About DAS

The Dead Arts Society has been a UC Davis undergraduate student organization for more over two years. We've put on quarterly showcases and full-length productions since Winter Quarter 2010. We're a club for actors, dancers, singers, directors, choreographers, playwrights and anybody else who has a passion for any of the performing arts. Everyone from all levels of experience and majors are welcome! If you have any interest in DAS, visit our Facebook page (https://www.facebook.com/pages/Dead-Arts-Society/152483591494259) or send us an email at deadartssociety@gmail.com.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't make a donation, we completely understand. But you can always spread the word to friends, family, or random strangers! And regardless of any monetary contribution, you're more than welcome to attend the performances! We perform for you and a full house is the the most valuable gift we could ask for. Plus, how could you not want to see these four amazing shows?!

story:
U.I.N! (Unicorns In Need)

Nonsuch Theatre are a Nottingham based, international physical theatre company and over the last year we've been working hard to create our first major work Acqua Alta - a contemporary reimagining of Noah's Ark. After 10 months of planning and development we're now at the stage in the show's journey where we are about to enter our final rehearsal phase ahead of publicly launching the work in May - but we need your help to make this a reality!  

Acqua Alta is a rhythmic and mythical story that follows the lives of five unfortunate Unicorns who suddenly find themselves in a strange and uncomfortable chamber; the ceiling is dripping, the floor is wet and they're left facing an unimaginable question: What do you do when Noah leaves you to drown?

With your support we will be able to answer this question, finish the development of the show and create a performance of the highest possible quality. We'll also be able to maximise the opportunity provided by partnering with Create Theatre Mansfield to use our first performances as a launchpad for our artistic development by letting as many people as possible know about our work and create some Nonsuch buzz!


What We Need & What You Get

To date we've funded the show's development through our own funds and in-kind support however we now need a financial injection in order to stage and market the finished production. Costumes, make-up, scenery and props will undoubtably take our work to the next level but they all cost money and so we've created this CrowdFunding project!

Our £1200 will split down as follows:

  • £250 - Costume Budget
  • £500 - Set and Prop Budget
  • £100 - Prosthetic make-up (Our unicorns have sawn off their horns - they're in a mess!)
  • £250 - Marketing Budget
  • £100 - Production Pack Creation - so we can promote our work to other venues and extend the life of this project.

Should we reach our target, this £1200 will be put to use alongside the £5420 of in-kind support we have already raised through a number of partnerships with institutions such as Theatre Delicatessen and Create Theatre that will give us rehearsal space, performance space and technical equipment at no cost to us.

In exchange for your generosity we'd love to be able to get you an order of the realm (which you would clearly deserve) but unfortunately that's not quite possible, so we've put together four levels of fabulously Freerange perks to satisfy your needs whatever your budget! Check them out, select your favourite and top up our totaliser! Will you be a Pony, Stallion, Centaur or Unicorn? 

The Impact of Your Generosity

This production is our first, full-length performance project and is therefore critical to our development as young and emerging theatre makers. Being a relatively small company the impact the success of this crowdfunding will have on our practice will undoubtably be far reaching. Not only will we be able to physically realise the design elements of the performance to create a captivating visual aesthetic but we will also be able to connect with a larger and more diverse audience base as a result of an increased marketing budget - we're exceedingly passionate that non-theatre goers and theatre goers alike have an equal opportunity to experience our work.

We are equally very aware of the long-term impact the success of this project will have as producing a high quality performance, organising a successful launch and engaging with other venues through a production pack will hopefully lay the foundations for our future artistic development and careers.

Whilst we may be young, we feel we have achieved a great deal in our 10 month life span, we're very proud of what we've done so far and can't wait to see what the future holds! 

Since we formed in April 2013 we have produced two work in progress showings: Acqua Alta (Rose Bruford College) and Observations of a Stick Stirrer (Battersea Arts Centre); launched a very successful Workshops for Schools and Colleges Programme; ran a number of residency opportunities at institutions such as Nottingham's New Art Exchange and Bristol's Tobacco Factory Theatre; and started working in association with Theatre Delicatessen and Nottingham's Creative Quarter Company to acquire and establish a performance development hub for emerging artists like us in Nottingham City Centre. 

About The Show

Noah, the richest and most prosperous of the religious billionaires has landed on his feet - he’s just completed building the world’s largest luxury cruise ship: The Marshmallow, complete with the world’s first floating menagerie. Due to increased sea levels as a result of global warming he’s allowing two of every species passage as part of his floating zoo allowing his guests to relax, unwind and enjoy the delights of the world’s most exotic animals, every single animal in fact… well, apart from Unicorns, Noah can’t stand Unicorns.

Thor, Perseus, Lamia, Arachne and Pandora (five unicorns with an insatiable desire to share the stories of their past) suddenly find themselves in a strange and uncomfortable chamber. The ceiling is dripping, the floor is wet and it seems like the place is about to flood. Rejected after an attempted boarding of The Marshmallow the five beautiful creatures wonder if their placement in this chamber is a result of Noah’s disdain for them. 

Combining extreme physicality, song and dance, “Acqua-Alta” transports the audience to a world where mythology and music combine and where historic tales from years past merge with the foreboding reality of five of the most beautiful creatures ever created. 

Join Our Freerange Family

Whilst we know not everyone is in a situation where they can contribute to our project we'd still love you to be involved and there are few simple ways that you can easily support our work without spending a penny!

  • Join us on social media by following us on Twitter, liking us on Facebook and subscribing to us on YouTube.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word of our campaign!
  • Subscribe to our 'Freerange News' email newsletter.
  • Tell everyone you know about our launch performance at Create Theatre on May 10th 2014.

Thank you for your support and stay Freerange!

Love

Nonsuch Theatre

story:
Ignite Theatre Company; Inspiring thought, memories and compassion.

Here at Ignite Theatre Company we believe that memories are key. We aim to create innovative and exciting community drama which provokes an appreciation and acceptance of individuals memories.

Ignite Theatre Company is based in the South Wales area, we are three BA (Hons) Applied Drama students in our final year at the University of South Wales who joined together through our passion for creating theatre with a purpose. Our drama in the community company is unique in how we specifically produce theatre which aids the re-emurgence of memories.

We are made up of;

- Mark Lloyd; Researcher, performer and scripter.

- Aleighcia Scott; Researcher and facilitator.

- Eve Turner; Researcher and facilitator.

Entitled Memory House, our first project aims to evoke memories of different eras throughout time for people with early stages of dementia /the elderly. By creating a safe environment for these people we are able to aid their memory with compassion.
By turning an empty space into a room representative of a home from a specific era. We will use sounds, smells and select items that are identifiable from that time frame and show footage from interviews with members of the public recalling their memories of that period. There will also be an ‘Everyman’ type character who will act as a link to each decade.  After the performance, the audience members will be invited to spend some time looking at the set and it’s contents before filming a video diary of the memories that have been provoked from the performance and set.

Our target for our project is £500, why you may ask?

- Our piece is heavily reliant on props from our 4 chosen decades. To be able to authentically recreate these decades we will source original memoribilia.

- The transport for our audience. As you know our chosen audience are either people with dementia or the elderly in genral. Therefore we have to take into consideration that many may be coming from residential homes.

- Hire of set from a local scenery company.

As a non-profit organisation any extra donations will be donated to Age Cymru.
story_txt: Ignite Theatre Company; Inspiring thought, memories and compassion. Here at Ignite Theatre Company we believe that memories are key. We aim to create innovative and exciting community drama which provokes an appreciation and acceptance of individuals memories. Ignite Theatre Company is based in the South Wales area, we are three BA (Hons) Applied Drama students in our final year at the University of South Wales who joined together through our passion for creating theatre with a purpose. Our drama in the community company is unique in how we specifically produce theatre which aids the re-emurgence of memories. We are made up of;- Mark Lloyd; Researcher, performer and scripter.- Aleighcia Scott; Researcher and facilitator.- Eve Turner; Researcher and facilitator. Entitled Memory House, our first project aims to evoke memories of different eras throughout time for people with early stages of dementia /the elderly. By creating a safe environment for these people we are able to aid their memory with compassion. By turning an empty space into a room representative of a home from a specific era. We will use sounds, smells and select items that are identifiable from that time frame and show footage from interviews with members of the public recalling their memories of that period. There will also be an ‘Everyman’ type character who will act as a link to each decade.  After the performance, the audience members will be invited to spend some time looking at the set and it’s contents before filming a video diary of the memories that have been provoked from the performance and set. Our target for our project is £500, why you may ask?- Our piece is heavily reliant on props from our 4 chosen decades. To be able to authentically recreate these decades we will source original memoribilia.- The transport for our audience. As you know our chosen audience are either people with dementia or the elderly in genral. Therefore we have to take into consideration that many may be coming from residential homes. - Hire of set from a local scenery company. As a non-profit organisation any extra donations will be donated to Age Cymru.

story:
Who we are

Rooster Theatre Company was formed in Kingston Upon Thames in 2013, by a group of Drama graduates and we have a common belief, that our productions should be more than 90 minutes of entertainment, but this ethos has proved shockingly ineffective at turning us into millionaires.

What we have done

Since our conception in 2013, we are working towards building a reputation for performances which take risks and challenge our audiences. We always try to be socially conscious without being preachy – reveling in the darker side of human nature.  Previous productions include performing in Kingston’s International Youth Arts Festival for three consecutive years, with Martin McDonaugh’s ‘The Lieutenant of Inishmore’, a collection of monologues entitled ‘DIY’ and most recently with a pointedly grotesque reworking of Brecht’s ‘The Exception and the Rule’. From plots and themes involving terrorism and class-struggle, our work gives us the title of a political theatre company.

Most recently, we produced an unorthodox adaptation of the writings of Harold Pinter, See No Evil, Hear No Evil, Speak No Evil. This piece took three of Pinter’s short plays, ‘Landscape’, ‘One For the Road’ and ‘Silence’, ostensibly unrelated and written years apart over Pinter’s long career in theatre, and thrust them together to form a narrative of powerful images and themes. First performed at Brighton Fringe in May 2014, the performance was lauded for its “slick nature” and “delightful intelligence” of the direction and how the cast “rose incredibly to the task of bringing these complex short plays to life”. Chiefly, though, the piece was commended for “the initial question they ask themselves and in turn their audience” and its understanding that “Risk is the nature of theatre” (New Current). The piece was also performed at Edinburgh Fringe in August 2014 and Thessaloniki, Greece the following November. Performed in one of the leading theatres of North Greece, this bold adaptation of Pinter was one of the first English language theatre pieces to be staged in Thessaloniki. Once again we received possitive reactions, with particular praise given to our efforts to “challenge their audience’s brains” and for offering “something different to Greek theatre as a whole” (ParalaxiMag).

What we are working on now

Our current piece, The Daily Tribunal, is a devised piece which seeks to bring to life the otherworldly beast that is the morning newspaper. Directed by Sofia Nakou and Laura Duffy, it follows the journey of two homeless men (actors Sam Nunes de Souza and Alex John) who find themselves faced with the unlikely task of writing a daily article for their local newspaper. The piece mixes a single narrative with stylised representations of news stories in an attempt to dissect the dual elements of virtue and vice which flow both into, and out of, the stories we digest every day. How does good intent give into corruption? Can journalistic integrity stand tall in a culture of flashy tabloid gossip? And, most importantly, do we as a society really demand anything better? These are some of the questions this piece tackles with a dark humour and an unflinching embrace of human nature.

And why we need you!

Our performances to this point have been well-received and we have lots of projects planned for the next few months, taking us from London to Edinburgh and Greece, but right now is that special time when we’ll get by with a little help from our friends (and sorry, but that’s you). Just a small (or huge) donation will help fund our travel and accommodation, when we perform outside of our humble village of London. Vital expenses such as marketing, renting venues and keeping ourselves sheltered and fed in foreign lands have built to a point that social awareness and glowing reviews can’t quite cover. In short, we need a bit of money. Like all emerging theatre companies we need support, and likely owing to recent cuts to the arts, we’ve decided to turn to you!

story:
The Project.

Hello. We are Zach Donovan, Felicia Lobo, Lauren Harris, and Joe Gery. We all went to NYU together and now we are creating our own work in New York City. We are producing a brand new play by Zach Donovan called Birthday Play. The play is about a guy who hates his birthday. Today, he is 22 years old. He desperately wants to grow up but is terrified of growing old. As he runs his errands in a dream-like metropolis plagued with untimely rain showers, he finds himself continuously confronted by his birthday. The play is slated for production in NYC this coming June. Take a look at the team!

BIRTHDAY PLAY by Zach Donovan

Directed by Felicia Lobo

Produced by Joe Gery

Associate Produced by Lauren Harris

Set Design by Jenna Antoniades

CAST 

Abby Awe, Madeline Barr, Zoe Curzi, Zach Donovan, Kelley Dugan, Sam Gonzalez, Dante Jeanfelix, Katie Looney, Jenna Rush, Sky Smith, and Mina Walker

What We Need.

In order to create, foster, and sustain the world of this play, our team needs to raise at least $3,500.

You would be amazed (maybe) at how much it costs to rent a performance space in New York City. In fact, about 75% of our budget has been allocated to cover that one expense. The rest of the budget will go toward expenses like set, rehearsal space, lighting, costumes, and props.

Challenges. 

We are actively creating our own work. We are not waiting for someone to give us a play to work on. Zach had an idea and we said YES! We are employing the help of a number of artists whom we respect and admire. We have a big cast - 11 people!  - and a big creative team - an additional 11 people! We want to provide the opportunity for these artists to do their best work in a brand new play.

Other Ways You Can Help!

If you are not in a place to help us out financially, don't sweat it - we totally get it! What you can do is tell everyone you have ever met about this play and share this campaign!! We want as many people to be involved in it in as many ways as possible. If you can be in the audience, we need that. If you are an amazing advocate of the arts, we need advocates. If you have other hidden talents, let me know about those so we can get you involved. Anything and everything helps.

story:
Short Summary

Hello! My name is Elizabeth Wessa and I am producing and directing my first show in NYC! My husband and I are both actors and after a casting drought for him, he decided to write a short play called "An Actor's Life for Me", about the pit falls and unique perks of being an actor, and submit it for a one act play festival. The play was accepted! So, along with our friend and co-writer, we're endeavoring to make this one act play into a professional caliber piece. It's an opportunity for three struggling New York artists to be a part of a show of which they are proud, and to get back in the NYC theatre scene.

What We Need & What You Get

For a successful production we need $500:

  • $150 for the submission to the festival
  • Approximately $100 for flyers and advertising (the festival requires 350 flyers for their use & we'd like some extras for our personal distribution)
  • $80 for props and costumes
  • $100 for rehearsal space
  • $50 for the actors--yep, we want to pay our actors. It might only be a travel stipend, but hey, it's better than nothing!
  • $20 for sundries! In case something runs over budget, or we've forgotten about something we need (water for the actors for example)

Don't worry, we haven't forgotten you. When you donate to our show you get stuff!

  • A donation of any amount gets a personalized thank you from the cast and crew of "An Actor's Life for Me"
  • Donate $30 & get a digital copy of the performance
  • Donate $500 & get a producer's credit & all previous rewards!
Where does the money go if we don't reach our goal? We'll use all the funds we receive towards defraying the cost of the production. The show must go on!

The Impact

Your contribution to our campaign is so important! Without your help we just won't be able to create the professional quality piece we know we can make. The arts are a severely underfunded area in our country, which is such a shame because it is the artists' world that is the world worth living in. Where would we be without the creativity and dreams that stem from artists' imaginations. Helping three artists bring a dream to life isn't the worst way to spend a few dollars. 

If the show does well at the festival, we're hoping to perform it again and even seek publication. This festival is a starting point for a show we think has a lot of potential and possibly can be expanded into a longer length piece. It can't be done without your help!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot make a monetary donation today, please at least share our campaign. Support the arts! Spread the word! Thank you again for all of your help.

story:
Youth Theater in the Bronx!

When I saw Open Hydrant Theater Company's youth program perform a hilarious and spot-on adaptation of A Midsummer Night's Dream in the style of Doo Wop, I was SOLD!

I decided right then and there that this was the company I wanted to see perform the two short plays I had written for the FringeJR festival. I mean, what is better than seeing an excellent and outstanding youth company perform for other kids? 

Theater for kids performed by kids! YES!

This campaign is important to me because, if I can raise the money I need to cover the cost of production, then 100% of whatever we make in the Box Office will be awarded to this special youth company. That makes me feel GREAT!

Not only will you be contributing to this great opportunity for a youth company from the Bronx to have their excellent work showcased at a highly visible festival in Manhattan, but you will be contributing to FUTURE projects that this youth company will undertake. Yeah! Give yourself a round of applause!

What We Need & What You Get

I've kept things pretty simple on purpose. That said, when you add up all the little details like insurance, programs, postcards, festival entry fees, equity stage manager, designers, etc., well, you get the idea. It's going to cost about five grand. 

So what do you get? YOU get to feel awesome for supporting my PLAYWRIGHTING DEBUT! What? Wow! 

You also get to support an incredible youth theater company in the BRONX! Woo!

So, What's This Play About, Anyway? 

Helen Ivy Bunter is a world renowned ghost hunter when she’s not busy being eight years old. With her pillowcase full of various ghoul-hunting tools she goes to the Haunted Holliot Hildorf Hotel to help the proprietor, Alastair MacAlister, convince Viktor the Mourner to stop frightening the guests. Helen gets unexpected help from a young ghost named, Pierre, while narrowly escaping a herd of pajama clad zombies and a temperamental boiler.

AND

Shadow is just your average tween ghoul until one magical moonlit night she is compelled to ride a unicycle that her mysterious aunts left for her. She experiences a full range of emotions on an unsteady adventure where she learns about some of the responsibilities that come with growing up.

TWO ADVENTURES with young female protagonists! Oh, yeah!!!

When and Where?

We're playing the FringeNYC festival in August of this year! If you live in New York, you can see us on 8/15 at Noon, 8/21 at 7:00, 8/27 at 2:00, 8/29 at 6:00, and 8/30 at Noon. All of our shows take place at the Theater at the 14th Street Y on 344 E 14th Street at 1st Ave. 

The Impact

Do you believe that children's theater can make a difference? 

I do.

 I also think this theater for kids performed by kids might be a really great idea. 

Shall we find out together?

story:
My name is Malcolm Harris, I am 18 years old and am a recent graduate of Lewis Cass Technical High School in Detroit, MI. I am the sole-creator, co-writer, co-director,  and actor in my original production of “Junior”. Coming out of high school I was presented with two choices. One follow the crowd and go to college, or two, go out into the world and follow my dreams.  I picked the less popular one.  With the support of friends and family my dreams of having my first production is coming to existence.  “Junior” is a play that uses the combination of original monologues and scenes to portray the relationship or lack thereof between sons and their fathers. 

$50,000 seems like it’s a lot of money, well because it is. In order to put on this production we are presented with a prodigious quantity of problems. One is finding a space that we can perform in on a regular basis. Either the theatre cost too much for us or they don't have enough dates that we need to put on our run. We usually have been running on a shoe string budget but we have been prevailing. All of our costumes we bring from home, a lot of times borrowing clothes from other cast mates. We have a minimal set because we don't have the funds or the means to make our own. If we can reach our goal of $50,000, we will be able to put on a two month run of our show. From there we can take it on the road so more people can be touched by this powerful message, and see the importance of the "father-son relationship". After that possibilities are endless. We intend to take this show to New York but one step at a time.

The reason I believe that this show is unlike any other and can have such a huge impact on our society is because it is and it has already (on a much smaller scale). My writing partner and I took it upon ourselves to do our best to break boundaries and make this show different than anything that we know of. Every time we put on this production we have make it more extravagant and art orientated. We are trying to bring all forms of art into this show so it will become an experience that our audience will leave filling full. These stories are all true stories or based off true stories. I wanted to write and finish this project because I feel that as young black men we don’t speak up for ourselves, we tend to bottle emotions inside (because “real” men don’t cry). I want to give these young men a voice, and erase or justify all stereotypes that us as young black men have stamped on our foreheads. The cast itself is filled with all young black men ranging from 16-25 years of age. All these stories in one way or another can relate to someone else in their lives.

We are not just asking for money, we are asking for support and fans. We need people that will spread the word and ensure that this show will grow and prosper. No dollar amount is too small, no amount of support is too little. We as a cast would like to thank you in advance for even considering to help us.

Donnevan Tolbert(19), Malcolm Harris (18), Antonio Jeffries (16), Devin Laster (25), Brandon Haugabook (18), Brandon Foxworth (17)

story:
Short Summary

The Pub Corner Poets are a collaborative company grounded in creating  original work and giving new artists a chance to be heard. During our last visit to the Fringe, we were nominated for Total Theatre's Emerging Company Award for our run of Angry.

Our next project Sad Little Man, is a stand-up tragedy set performed by the mind of a young man in shock. Described as “a stunning, bittersweet story” and “theatrically beautiful” by Noises Off Magazine, and “Hypnotic", "beautifully executed", "perfectly captured" and "visceral" by The Sunday Times, a combination of performance poetry, physical theatre, pounding music and projection tell the story of the many lives of Lee and someone he loves.

Our dates for this run are the 21st to the 28th of August at the Paradise Green Annex

What We Need & What You Get

We are trying to raise £800, this will help us cover the costs of travel and marketing.
£500  will go towards the cost of hiring a van (including van man) to lug a bathtub, giant bath curtain, several mics and a big wooden frame to Scotland and back.
£100 will get our two lovely performers to the Fringe (would be a pretty boring show without them) and then back home again.

£200 will allow us to print some sexy posters, and buy a load of spray-on glue to stick them to every available surface Scotland has to offer, as well as printing flyers and helping us to promote our show online

Send us...

£5- And we'll give you a shout out on our social media (twitter, facebook- the works)
£10-  The above plus your name with thanks on our poster, which we will send to you as a PDF. 
£20-  The above plus a poster delivered to your door. (Or the door of wherever you would like it sent)
£30- All of the above plus your poster will be signed by the cast and playwright.  You will also receive a complimentary ticket to either our Edinburgh, London or Hull runs. We'll email you the dates to select from.
£50- All of that stuff plus we will commission our team of only mostly alcoholic poets  to write, perform and film a poem on a topic of your choice which will be hosted on our website, www.pubcornerpoets.co.uk and social media.

To claim any of the above perks please make sure you leave your email address when you make your donation.

The Impact

Our last visit to Edinburgh resulted in a sold out run of our debut show Angry (a show which netted its writer Josh Overton  the Sunday Times Playwriting award) earned us a nomination for Total Theatre's  Emerging Company Award. 

P.C.P. is run by a dedicated team of people who all have to do normal human jobs on the side to keep themselves alive, throwing their spare time into making our projects happen. A shot at bringing Sad Little Man  to the fringe this year offers us a chance to make a big step forward towards creating theatre full time and opens up doors for us to expand into cities across the country bringing our theatre, our poetry and our educational programme to a whole new group of people.

Risks & Challenges

We fully appreciate that we may not hit our target for this campaign but any funds we do secure we intend to put towards making this show happen even if it has to be on a shoestring budget. Any donations made will be gratefully received and will not go to waste.

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that just like us you work jobs too and that may mean that you're not able to donate towards Sad Little Man. You can still help us by spreading the word about the show and our campaign on social media or following us on the social media platforms listed below.

Facebook.
www.facebook.com/pubcornerpoets

Twitter.
@pubcornerpoets

Instagram. 
@pubcornerpoets


(Also Indiegogo suggested we remind you to use the "Indiegogo share features", but we have no idea what those are.)

story:
UN GRAND PROJET 
Pour aujourd'hui et pour l'avenir 

Les 6, 7 et 8 novembre prochains, un nouvel événement  fera vibrer tout le campus: des spectacles professionnels et étudiants, contes, conférences d’artistes, ateliers, tables rondes et soirées festives,  animés par la toute première édition du Festival du théâtre de l’Université Laval.  Avec des invités tels que Robert Lepage, Larry Tremblay, Maxime Robin, Frédéric Dubois et, comme porte-parole, Jean-Nicolas Marquis, c'est une parfaite occasion de mêler l’art d’aujourd’hui et la relève de demain. L'objectif est de créer une plate-forme de partage et ainsi offrir au grand public une expérience unique et stimulante. De plus, tous les spectacles, conférences et tables rondes sont offerts gratuitement. Notre programmation complète saura plaire autant aux amateurs de théâtre qu’à ceux qui désirent s’initier à l’art actuel de la scène.

L'idée est également de faire vivre notre projet aujourd'hui, mais de le rendre disponible aux générations futures d'étudiants qui souhaiteront, eux aussi, faire connaître leur passion pour le théâtre et les arts de la scène. 

Une initiative étudiante

Cette initiative, entièrement étudiante, est le souffle collectif d’un programme universitaire. Près de trente élèves travaillent avec dévouement, depuis près de six mois, à la construction de ce festival dans le but de faire découvrir leur passion quotidienne aux autres universitaires, mais aussi au grand public. C’est avec beaucoup de réjouissance que les étudiants vous ouvrent les portes de leur univers. Aidez-nous à financer notre festival et faites vous aussi partie d'un grand projet d'avenir.

story:
Night Lights Theater Group  presents...


Say You Love Satan

by Roberto Aguirre-Sacasa 

A diabolical comedy that pairs the timeless struggle of good vs. evil with the perils of modern dating. When Andrew meets Jack, it seems like a match made in Heaven. That is until Andrew discovers that Jack is... the Son of Satan. (Yes, the Satan.) Despite their differences, they try to make it work. But what is the price of having Beelzebub for a boyfriend? How long will their happiness last before things go completely to - well, you know. 

Starring Omar Cruz | Brock Yuric | Carmen Lobue | Frank Vushaj | Blake Merriman 

Special Performances by NYC chanteuse Minnie Dee as Goodness Incarnate

For this production, Night Lights Theater Group has joined forces with Queerocracy, an activist organization cultivating the leadership of queer folks, and people living with HIV/ AIDS in NYC. Together we are working to end the AIDS crisis, stigma and discrimination within the gay community by intersecting Activism and Art. In this case, Theater. 

Where Is The Money Going? 

Your generous donations will enable us to bring this play to life!! This money will cover everything from theater rental, rehearsal spaces, set/ graphic design to the programs we print for opening night. 

20% of all ticket sales will be donated to Queerocracy. 

Help Spread the Love! 

Every little bit helps! ... Even if it's not money!

Please help us spread the word about our Campaign through Facebook, Emails, Twitter, Word of Mouth... 

THANK YOU!!!

The Duplex Cabaret Theater, NYC 

Sat/ Sun, Nov 2nd-3rd & 9th-10th 

@ 6:30pm & (two-drink minimum)

story:
WHO:

This production of Peter Schaffer's classic drama is a passion project for director Julia Joyce-Barry. A second year Acting MFA candidate, Julia has long awaited the time when she might have the resources and support to direct her favorite play with a mix of Columbia University classmates and outside collaborators.

Equus will feature performances by Eliza Green-Smith, Kenard Jackson,Timur Kocak*, Jake Lasser, Alexandra Pucci, Nick Shea, Phumzile Nelisiwe Sitole, and  Angela Sperazza*. With lighting design by Michael Mcgee and Dramaturgy by Jolene Noelle.

*denotes member of Actor's Equity Association


WHAT:

While on a drive with a friend in the English countryside, playwright Peter Schaffer was told a story about a 17 year old boy who had blinded 6 horses in a barn outside Suffolk.  At once fascinated and disturbed by the story, Schaffer set out to write what is now his revered drama Equus.

Known for its brilliant mix of clenched British realism and lurid fantastical elements, Equus has attracted audiences since 1973 where it performed for 2 years in London. It later moved to Broadway and featured  renowned actors Anthony Hopkins, Richard Burton, and Anthony Perkins as the child psychologist, Martin Dysart. In the most recent Broadway run Dysart was played by the late Richard Griffiths, with Daniel Radcliffe as Alan, the boy in question.


WHEN/WHERE:

Equus will perform in Columbia Unviersity's Schapiro Studio Theater.

605 West 115th St. Between Broadway and Riverside

Jan 15th (invited dress) 8pm. Jan 16th and 17th 8pm and Jan 18th 2pm and 8pm.

Directions: Take the 1 train to 116th st. Walk to 115th st and turn right. 605 is just past the UPS store. Once inside go down the stairs to the basement level.


HOW: 

Admission is free and you can reserve your tickets at equusJan2014@gmail.com

Make a donation on this site, and help Julia and her team of dedicated actors and designers make Equus come to fruition!


WHY:

 Although Columbia University is housing the project, the production team does not receive any financial support for the production of Equus. Although the production team is using very few outside resources, there are a few expenses which cannot be avoided. To give you an idea of where your money is going, here is an example of our budget. 

Performance Rights: $300

Equity Actor Compensation: $ 240

Stage Manager Stipend: $150

Props/Costumes: $100

Miscellaneous/unforeseen expenses: $100

Indie-Go-Go platform fee: 3%

Indie Go-Go Payment processing fee: 4%

ALSO! 'Tis the season for generosity and giving!

story:
Short Summary

YEAR of the HIPPO began one year ago with development throughout the summer and fall of 2012. It is a play about our generation’s version of the American Dream and takes place in the year following college graduation in a world clouded with daunting doubt—and college debt. We are the most talked about generation in the media today and this play comes from those experiencing these issues first hand. Something must change with the educational system or our generation will be defined by money and luck. MultiPurposeRoom was awarded a four-month residency with the Field and through this residency we have developed and shaped YEAR of the HIPPO.

What We Need & What You Get

So, here’s the challenge:

It’s 2013, right?

We have 13 people in our company.

If each of us finds 13 people to give $13, we will reach our goal!

 

And just to make things even more exciting, our goal date is February 13th, which is Will Detlefsen’s 23rd birthday.

 

MPR’s 2013 GOAL: $2,197.13

 

We cannot do it without you.

The Impact

MultiPurposeRoom has a workshop presentation set for the end of January of 2013.

We will perform an excerpt of the show at Dixon Place on February 4th.

Your contributions will go directly towards taking YEAR of the HIPPO to a theatre in the summer of 2013. We are ready to bring in the designers and give this play the proper set, lights, media, sound, and costumes it deserves. We hope you will help us make this possible!

story:
• Short summary
    • Hello! My name is Dane Leasure, producing artistic director for the Rubber City Shakespeare Company. We are an upstart Shakespeare Company based in the Akron area of Northeast Ohio. Between me and my staff we have been involved in theatre and fully invested in the performing arts for many years. We are excited to bring Shakespeare to the Akron area.
    • This campaign is very important to us. We will be using money donated as startup funds to produce artistic shows through the year. We will be offering free programing as well so that everyone can enjoy and find love for Shakespeare and his plays. Your contributions will help breathe life into our company and we will be forever indebted to you.
  • What we need and what you get
    • What we need is clear. We need money. We are looking to raise $2500 to pay for a multitude of items required and necessary to run a successful theatre company. Your donations will go to pay for rehearsal space, performance space, costumes, props, lighting, marketing items such as posters and programs. If we meet our goal of $2500 we also will be able to pay our cast and administrators a small token of our appreciation for what they do!
    • Now comes the fun part. What you get for donated to our efforts and passions. For $10 (Mechanicals) you will be mentioned on our website and our production program. For $25 (Athenians) you will receive a personal thank you from the Producing Artistic Director. For $50 (Fairies) you will receive 2 reserved seats for our first production of A Midsummers Night Dream. For $100 (Lovers) you will receive a signed poster from the cast of our first production A Midsummers Night Dream. For those who are able to donate $250 (Royalty) you will be mentioned in our pre-show speech for ALL the shows performed in our inaugural  artistic year. And final but most certainly not least, those who are able to donate $500 (Robin Goodfellow) the Rubber City Shakespeare Company will give you all of the above plus two tickets for all of our productions in the 2013 artistic year and a special notation in all future programs as a “Principal Sharer” in our company.
    • Whatever we raise, no matter if we meet our goal or not, will go towards one of the three productions we plan on performing in the 2013 artistic year and our free programming. Every penny will go to something important.
  • The impact
    • The Rubber City Shakespeare Company can have a great impact on the city of Akron, OH. We will be bringing the arts to the public. We will be introducing Shakespeare to a public that might have had very little time if any at all, with him. And we are making Shakespeare accessible to a modern audience.
    • As a new company our combined experience as a staff has shown that people enjoy the artistic quality of Shakespeare.
  • Other Ways You can help
    • We understand that many people out there just can’t contribute money. And that is OKAY!!! We still love you. All you have to do is share our campaign link with all your friends. Put it on Facebook and twitter.  Also feel free to share our website, www.rubbercityshakes.weebly.com and our Facebook page, facebook.com/rubbercityshakes. The more people who know about us the better! Word of mouth is a very powerful thing and we embrace it! Also don’t forget to use the Indiegogo share tools on the page below. They have been created for your convenience.

Short summary

Hello! My name is Dane Leasure, producing artistic director for the Rubber City Shakespeare Company. We are an upstart Shakespeare Company based in the Akron area of Northeast Ohio. Between me and my staff we have been involved in theatre and fully invested in the performing arts for many years. We are excited to bring Shakespeare to the Akron area.
This campaign is very important to us. We will be using money donated as startup funds to produce artistic shows through the year. We will be offering free programing as well so that everyone can enjoy and find love for Shakespeare and his plays. Your contributions will help breathe life into our company and we will be forever indebted to you.



What we need and what you get

What we need is clear. We need money. We are looking to raise $2500 to pay for a multitude of items required and necessary to run a successful theatre company. Your donations will go to pay for rehearsal space, performance space, costumes, props, lighting, marketing items such as posters and programs. If we meet our goal of $2500 we also will be able to pay our cast and administrators a small token of our appreciation for what they do!
Now comes the fun part. What you get for donated to our efforts and passions. For $10 (Mechanicals) you will be mentioned on our website and our production program. For $25 (Athenians) you will receive a personal thank you from the Producing Artistic Director. For $50 (Fairies) you will receive 2 reserved seats for our first production of A Midsummers Night Dream. For $100 (Lovers) you will receive a signed poster from the cast of our first production A Midsummers Night Dream. For those who are able to donate $250 (Royalty) you will be mentioned in our pre-show speech for ALL the shows performed in our inaugural  artistic year. And final but most certainly not least, those who are able to donate $500 (Robin Goodfellow) the Rubber City Shakespeare Company will give you all of the above plus two tickets for all of our productions in the 2013 artistic year and a special notation in all future programs as a “Principal Sharer” in our company.
Whatever we raise, no matter if we meet our goal or not, will go towards one of the three productions we plan on performing in the 2013 artistic year and our free programming. Every penny will go to something important.



The impact

The Rubber City Shakespeare Company can have a great impact on the city of Akron, OH. We will be bringing the arts to the public. We will be introducing Shakespeare to a public that might have had very little time if any at all, with him. And we are making Shakespeare accessible to a modern audience.
As a new company our combined experience as a staff has shown that people enjoy the artistic quality of Shakespeare.



Other Ways You can help

We understand that many people out there just can’t contribute money. And that is OKAY!!! We still love you. All you have to do is share our campaign link with all your friends. Put it on Facebook and twitter.  Also feel free to share our website, www.rubbercityshakes.weebly.com and our Facebook page, facebook.com/rubbercityshakes. The more people who know about us the better! Word of mouth is a very powerful thing and we embrace it! Also don’t forget to use the Indiegogo share tools on the page below. They have been created for your convenience.

story:
Who We Are 

  • Located in Jacksonville, Florida, Jacksonville Dance Theatre (JDT) is a contemporary dance and performance company dedicated to creating and promoting excellence in the field of professional dance on local, national and international stages. JDT is committed to creative innovation and exchange through dance making, performance and education. A 501(c)(3) non-profit organization, JDT’s local performances and outreach impact Jacksonville directly, while our national and international performances raise Jacksonville’s arts visibility and status overall.

  • This importance of this campaign cannot be understated. As a small, emerging arts organization, public contributions make up a large portion of our project budgets. For our fourth annual concert we are performing at the historic Florida Theatre in Jacksonville, and we need your help to fund it! 

  • Contributors to this campaign will help JDT achieve a major goal: performing on the Florida Theatre stage in Downtown Jacksonville. This has been a dream of ours since our inception. Learn more about the Florida Theatre here http://floridatheatre.com/

What We Need & What You Get

  • The cost of producing a dance concert at the Florida Theatre will run us about $10,000. These costs include: the venue itself, the lighting designer, stage crew, and production staff; paying dancers for rehearsals and the performance, and costuming the show; hiring a videographer and photographer; paid media and advertising, printed collateral and marketing...oh, and list goes on and on... but those are the heavy hitters. 
  • Some of our exciting perks are free tickets to the concert, a 2016 photographic calendar, JDT t-shirts and other merchandise, honorable mention on the JDT website, and special invitations to behind the scenes rehearsals. 
  • If the goal is not met, all contributions will go specifically to paying the dancers and artists directly involved in the concert itself.
