This has been a dream of ours since our inception. Learn more about the Florida Theatre here http://floridatheatre.com/

   What We Need & What You Get  The cost of producing a dance concert at the Florida Theatre will run us about $10,000. These costs include: the venue itself, the lighting designer, stage crew, and production staff; paying dancers for rehearsals and the performance, and costuming the show; hiring a videographer and photographer; paid media and advertising, printed collateral and marketing...oh, and list goes on and on... but those are the heavy hitters.  Some of our exciting perks are free tickets to the concert, a 2016 photographic calendar, JDT t-shirts and other merchandise, honorable mention on the JDT website, and special invitations to behind the scenes rehearsals.  If the goal is not met, all contributions will go specifically to paying the dancers and artists directly involved in the concert itself.

story:
Short Summary

Every story matters. In an age where anything we dislike or challenges our worldview is deemed “fake” it is more important than ever to tell stories that accurately reflect personal experience. Every race, gender, religion, country, family, and occupation tells the story of those living in it. This is my story.

I have been writing and performing Musical Theater for the majority of my life. I worked in retail for a decade. During my tenure I experienced humanity in ways I never imagined. This campaign, to fund The Retail Song Cycle’s first reading is the culmination of that effort and experience. The piece is a story about human decency, consumerism, work ethic, societal norms, and how we treat each other. If you have every sold to or bought anything from a person, this is your story too. And if you have ever whistled a song Hamilton or hummed “Feed The Birds,” you’ll know why I’m telling it in song.

The campaign I am starting here is to help tell this story. Theater of any level, and especially musical theater, is only born from the efforts of a team working together to tell these stories. The skill, time, space, and equipment necessary for even the humblest of productions, the staged reading, is a massive undertaking. Hundreds of hours of rehearsal, technical work, and organization will go into even a single performance. Which is why I am turning to all of you to help bring this modern american worker's tale to life for the very first time.

 

What We Need & What You Get

The Retail Song Cycle will require $2800 to become a reality. Professional musicians, performers, a stage manager, and front of house staff all need to be paid for their skills and time. Most of the performers I will be working with have decades of experience, and as you will hear and see in this piece, I believe people should be paid for their skill and time.

The space, equipment, maintenance, and advertising will also cost a sum. New York, is still one of the most expensive cities in the world and the beautiful Midtown venue we are planning to use is affordable by those standards, but still expensive by most others.

As a backer of this project, you will be helping dozens of artist in this expensive metropolis perform a piece their care about without the fear of it’s effect on their bank account. After all, the idea of the starving artist was first championed by Lord Byron, and you can guess by his title that it was more of an intellectual desire than the realities of his situation.

As a backer you will receive:

All Contributions include a Social Media Shout Out and Credit in the Limited Edition Playbill

$10 - A Ticket

$20 - A Limited Edition Autographed Postcard, a Ticket

$50 - A Limited Edition Autographed Poster, and Pair of Tickets

$100 - A Limited Edition Autographed Playbill and Pair of Tickets

$250 - An Autographed Copy of the sheet music of the song of your choice from the show, and a Pair of Tickets

$500 - All Autographed Merchandise and a Pair of Tickets

$1000 - A Brand New, Customized, Original Song by the Composer/Lyricist of our Show.

The Impact

My time in retail taught me a lot. Enough to fill a musical, actually; and as I worked, I wrote. On breaks, on my phone after a customer walked away, in the aftermath of Black Friday: I made a record that I knew I would someday share. This show is based on actual events, every line a customer utters in this play, was uttered in real life, and I believe with all my heart, this story needs to be told. 

With this project I will be launching a bold effort in my career in the Musical Theater world. I'm creating a new work and it requires passionate people like you, to bring it to life.  This reading will be the first step for this show and from 38th St in Midtown Manhattan, where we will be putting up this show with your support, we are only a 5 minute walk to 42nd and Broadway.

Risks & Challenges

The biggest challenge with a new show this size, is time. We need to rehearse for many hours to represent the material, but with the talented people I have assembled to bring this show to life, I know we will be able to create a new and thrilling theater experience for you our supporters, and the Theater.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t support us financially at this time, believe me when I say “we get it.” As actors, singers, musicians, composers, writers, and artists, we struggle every day to keep going in a world that isn’t always kind to our work. Don’t feel bad if you can’t give right now.

If you are on social media, please share this page with your friends and like/follow our pages. If you have friends or family in the Tri-State Area, send them our way! If you can only show support with your words, we not only say thank you but we take strength from you support.  I wrote this piece for the people of the world who are underpaid and overlooked, and if you feel that way, please pass this campaign along so we can tell not just my story, but yours.

story:
Scripts: Ireland's Playwriting Festival

                   

 What is it?

    For 7 days in September the picturesque heritage town of Birr, Co. Offaly, a haven of Georgian elegance, will play host to an ensemble of playwrights, producers, actors and directors, all working towards one goal....To produce 7 outstanding new Irish plays in 7 fun-filled days!


Scripts takes place from the 8th-14th September
Co-Produced by Birr Theatre and Arts Center and Jasango Theatre

    Scripts is a festival dedicated to new Irish plays—the writing of them, the development and nurturing of them. Playwright's have submitted original 15 Minute plays on the theme "Home".  Those selected will benefit from a professional development process where they will be mentored by professional playwright Eugene O' Brien in an exciting workshopping process. Also included in the festival is a fully produced radio play, pop up plays around the town of Birr, writing workshops for adults and teens, and a final performance of the chosen plays. (Winning playwright announced following performances!) Check out www.scriptsireland.com for more details!

Writing Workshops will be led by Christian O'Reilly and Phillip McMahon, extremely successful and talented professional playwrights in Ireland who we are thrilled to have working with us!




How can you help?

    Your support means so much to us. Giving writers a chance to explore their talents, create beautiful work, and learn from talented experts in their field is something we believe in, and are passionate about. Nurturing these works and promoting Irish writers is such a worthy cause! Your support will help this festival reach its potential and have wide reaching results.


Eugene O'Brien


Angela Ryan


What will your support provide?

Marketing materials to get the word out there.The more people that hear about Scripts the more successful it will be!

A chance for playwrights to work with Eugene O'Brien for a week in Birr. Through a workshop experience during the week of September 8th, the chosen playwrights will present to you exceptionally crafted scripts and performances.

Resources for bringing over 35 artists together for collaboration.  Writers, actors, directors, producers, and lovers of the arts will be coming together to create this amazing festival. The organization of this massive group takes time, commitment, and money to make it all happen. Your contribution will help us bring our passion for new theatre works to Birr and the rest of Ireland!

Be a part of the process!  Your contribution and support will make you connected and a part of this new writing festival! Your help will continue to sustain it so that Scripts will be become an annual festival. Come join us in the amazing energy that we bring in collaborating with passionate Irish artists!


Emma Nee Haslam, Seamus Feerick, Oisin Foley, John Maguire

Angela Ryan, Siobhan Donnelan, Martina Reilly, Eugene O'Brien, Darren Donohue

Oisin Foley, Angela Ryan, Lisa Daly, John Maguire, Seamus Feerick


Thank you in advance for taking the time to read about Scripts! We hope you join us and become a part of this inspiring Festival!

story:
Help 30 promising, young artists from Cambodia’s rural villages to perform rare classical, folk & sacred Khmer dance on their debut international tour in the US.

We need your valued support to raise $20,000 in the next 60 days, towards sponsoring the travel and subsistence costs of the tour.

It was 2007 when I was first introduced to these amazing children, when they were starting out as students at a new performing arts school, in the countryside within the Angkor Wat World Heritage park. 

I marveled at their elegance, poise and control even then.

But after 6 years of rigorous training under the guidance of the Conservatoire’s Royal patron and their dedicated teachers, these extraordinary young dancers and musicians have been transformed into swans.

On 2 accounts, I am so proud!! As a Cambodian adopted in the UK and a Trustee of Nginn Karet Foundation for Cambodia (NKFC) - the nonprofit responsible for the Conservatoire.

What an incredible transformation into the Sacred Dancers of Angkor dance and music troupe, after so much hard work!

The Sacred Dancers of Angkor Tour (http://www.nkfc.org/ustour) is important to me for so many reasons. Here are three:

1. Their mission is highly spiritual: to connect Cambodian-Americans to the Motherland during the Buddhist Holy Month of Remembrance and to dance, as is the ancient tradition by sacred dancers, for peace and harmonious world.

The children will be staying with the same local Cambodian communities that have invited them to perform in the Buddhist Pagodas.

2. It will raise awareness of Cambodia’s distinctive centuries-old cultural heritage, which was almost wiped out by the Khmer Rouge.

3. It is a unique opportunity for the students to learn from the cultural exchange workshops organised with prestigious Ballet institutions, as well as with established Khmer dance troupes to bond and share their common experiences and dreams.


Rayvnn Karet-Coxen, chair of NKFC, said, “like the divine Apsara women seen carved in stone on the Angkorian temples, these extraordinary young artists are dancing for peace and to honour their American hosts.”

Princess Buppha Devi, the Cambodian Royal Ballet’s former prima ballerina and patron of NKFC also said, “These children are inspired by the truth of who they are: children of Angkor. They were born to walk in the footsteps of our greatest ancestors.”

PLANNED SCHEDULE (for more details, please visit http://nkfc.org/ustour)

September 16 – 23 in Lowell-Boston

September 24 – 3 in New York

October 1 – 10 in Washington 

October 10 – 23 in Long Beach-LA

The Sacred Dancers of Angkor troupe will also perform at theatrical performances (see below). All proceeds will go to support the dance school, which is part of the charity NKFC's sustainable development program and caters exclusively for children from the rural communities within the World Heritage site of Angkor.

For Details of how to book tickets and further information please contact nkfc@nkfc.org

September 22  Fundraiser at Lowell High School - 50 Father Morissette Blvd, Lowell, MA 01852

September 29  Fundraiser at Asia Society - Lila Acheson Wallace Auditorium, 725 Park Avenue, New York,NY 10021

October 4  Fundraiser at New Fortune Restaurant - 16515 S. Frederick Ave, Gaithersburg, MD 20877

October 19  Fundraiser at Martha B Knoebel Dance Theater - California State University, 6200 Atherton Street, Long Beach, CA  9081

October 21  Fundraiser at Colburn School Zipper Hall - 200 S Grand Ave, Los Angeles, CA 90012

RISKS AND CHALLENGES

The $20,000 goal is only a portion of the estimated cost of $3,500 per person for the 6-week trip, including visas, insurance, food and travel.

We are employing multiple methods for fundraising, including traditional corporate sponsorship, the NKFC website (http://www.nkfc.org/ustour), social networking and other crowd funding websites. All funds raised will go straight towards the above mentioned costs of the tour.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

If you are unable to give a money donation, you can still help us out by spreading the word about the Sacred Dancers of Angkor Tour, by emailing to family, colleagues, and friends any of the following links: 

·  Sacred Dancers Tour page on our NKFC website http://www.nkfc.org/ustour

·  Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/pages/Sacred-Dancers-of-Angkor-US-Tour-2013/614629601902351

·  First Givingif you are in the US: http://www.firstgiving.com/fundraiser/NKFC/us

·  Just Giving if you have UK contacts: http://www.justgiving.com/NKFC-Appeal

Also, please contact us at nkfc@nkfc.org and we'll give you brochures and posters to distribute in your area.

The more you spread the word about the Sacred Dancers of Angkor, the more chances the children have of a sustainable future and safeguarding the cultural legacy of traditional Khmer dance.

story:
Summary

What Makes Us Feel Good begins with a cow attempting to put the audience at ease. In reality, however, this is an actor looking for self validation. We cannot be certain how the audiences at The Tank will respond, but Johnny the Cow will most certainly ignore them. Especially once he has asked them a question. You see, he wants to get to the good stuff. A trauma involving his mother. A lifetime of self doubt. Forgiveness. Anyway, there’s another actor on stage now. They are preparing to present an educational children’s theatre show based on the life of murderer William Bradford Bishop. They are certain that it will be both marketing and compelling. The resulting performance is an amalgam of children’s broadcast programming, live educational theatre, and William Bradford Bishop’s violent acts in Bethesda, Maryland in 1976.

In What Makes Us Feel Good, we meet William Bradford Bishop as he is burning the corpses of his victims and teaching us to spell “grave”.  Along with his loyal pals, Mrs. Teapot and Johnny the Cow, William Bradford Bishop flees from the authorities and searches for meaning in existence. Through it all, William is plagued by flashbacks of his marriage, self loathing thoughts, and visits from a poetic and profound life sized squirrel.

This play is our longest standing collaboration and much of that is owed to the content which it presents. It’s a young play about young people oppressed by their own self hatred and intelligence (or potential lack thereof). In a way, these themes are a microcosm of our growth as artists. Conceived in our earliest and most vulnerable college haze, we’ve worked on it while juggling internships, assistantships, and other personal projects. For better or for worse, and much like some of the characters in this play, we’ve learned to embrace this self doubt and use it as a tool to create the kind of live performance we wish we could see more of.

See more photos from the workshop here!

Check out some video clips of the show here and here. 

 

TEAM

The Equity approved Showcase will be performed by Marielle Young*, David Brummer, Alison Schilling, Gina Doherty, and Kelsey Lurie.

Costumes by Iliana Paris.

Lighting Design by Christina Tang. 

*Appearing courtesy of Actors’ Equity Association. 

Special Events (company) is a collaborative co-op that looks to constantly reconfigure its own definition of collaboration. Though the lead artist may change, we are all able to take joint ownership over the work that we present. We are interested in pushing experimentation in the form to greater lengths, which often manifests itself as big shifts in aesthetic or tone between pieces. A major driving force is the impossible quest to find authenticity in theater. Using self prescribed tools like cliche, genre, sound, pop culture, and dance to disrupt a play’s complacency to narrative and form is our way of making theater that is as complex, weird, and self referential as everyday reality.

 

Brett Evan Solomon (playwright) is a writer and performer based out of New York City. His work as a playwright has been produced or developed through Nylon Fusion Theater Company, The Southampton International Theater Workshop, The Secret Theatre, Dixon Place, Muchmore's, Play Date at Pete's, The Tank, The Brick, Interrobang New Works Festival, Piggies Amusement Complex, The Exponential Festival, and The Drama League. He has held assistant positions with Young Jean Lee, Rachel Dickstein/Ripe Time, Target Margin Theater, New York City Players, A Collection of Shiny Objects, and Genee Coreno. B.A, Double Major in Theater and Performance/Playwriting and Screenwriting, Conservatory of Theatre Arts at SUNY Purchase College.

 

Gabriel Vasquez (director) is a director, performer, and native New Yorker. He has presented work at Muchmore’s, Dixon Place, The Tank, Vital Joint, and The Brick among others. He was a 2017 resident artist at the Drama League with Brett Evan Solomon's queer reveng tale Such a Tragedy. He began serious work on a new piece titled Minor Kerouac as part of Barton Booth’s Make Room residency on Governors Island this summer. He was last seen performing in SOMEONEPLEASELISTENANDUNDERSTAND (they’re wiretapping our brains) as part of the Exponential Festival. As an assistant director or intern, he has worked with Rachel Dickstein/Ripe Time, The TEAM, The Wooster Group, Sanaz Ghajar, and Sponsored By Nobody. BA, Theater and Performance, SUNY Purchase College. cargocollective.com/gabrielvasquez.

 

What We Need & What You Get

The majority of the funds we are hoping to raise will be going towards actor/designer stipends and rehearsal space. The entire team has been on board since our first small reading at Dixon Place and we want to make sure we can compensate them. The rest will be spent on costume/prop construction, a singular set piece, volunteer accident insurance, and contingency. Any additional funds we may raise will go to additional marketing material. 

We are so excited to share these perks with you, which include spelling lessons with William, a digital tea date with Mrs. Teapot, and our deepest gratitude. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone is in a position to donate, but that doesn't mean we can't use your help! You can:

-Share this fundraiser with your friends, family, and colleagues

-Buy a ticket to the show

-Bring a friend to the show

-Like Special Events' Facebook page

They are preparing to present an educational children’s theatre show based on the life of murderer William Bradford Bishop. They are certain that it will be both marketing and compelling. The resulting performance is an amalgam of children’s broadcast programming, live educational theatre, and William Bradford Bishop’s violent acts in Bethesda, Maryland in 1976.
In What Makes Us Feel Good, we meet William Bradford Bishop as he is burning the corpses of his victims and teaching us to spell “grave”.  Along with his loyal pals, Mrs. Teapot and Johnny the Cow, William Bradford Bishop flees from the authorities and searches for meaning in existence. Through it all, William is plagued by flashbacks of his marriage, self loathing thoughts, and visits from a poetic and profound life sized squirrel.
This play is our longest standing collaboration and much of that is owed to the content which it presents. It’s a young play about young people oppressed by their own self hatred and intelligence (or potential lack thereof). In a way, these themes are a microcosm of our growth as artists. Conceived in our earliest and most vulnerable college haze, we’ve worked on it while juggling internships, assistantships, and other personal projects. For better or for worse, and much like some of the characters in this play, we’ve learned to embrace this self doubt and use it as a tool to create the kind of live performance we wish we could see more of.
See more photos from the workshop here!
Check out some video clips of the show here and here. 
 
TEAM
The Equity approved Showcase will be performed by Marielle Young*, David Brummer, Alison Schilling, Gina Doherty, and Kelsey Lurie.
Costumes by Iliana Paris.
Lighting Design by Christina Tang. 
*Appearing courtesy of Actors’ Equity Association. 
Special Events (company) is a collaborative co-op that looks to constantly reconfigure its own definition of collaboration. Though the lead artist may change, we are all able to take joint ownership over the work that we present. We are interested in pushing experimentation in the form to greater lengths, which often manifests itself as big shifts in aesthetic or tone between pieces. A major driving force is the impossible quest to find authenticity in theater. Using self prescribed tools like cliche, genre, sound, pop culture, and dance to disrupt a play’s complacency to narrative and form is our way of making theater that is as complex, weird, and self referential as everyday reality.
 
Brett Evan Solomon (playwright) is a writer and performer based out of New York City. His work as a playwright has been produced or developed through Nylon Fusion Theater Company, The Southampton International Theater Workshop, The Secret Theatre, Dixon Place, Muchmore's, Play Date at Pete's, The Tank, The Brick, Interrobang New Works Festival, Piggies Amusement Complex, The Exponential Festival, and The Drama League. He has held assistant positions with Young Jean Lee, Rachel Dickstein/Ripe Time, Target Margin Theater, New York City Players, A Collection of Shiny Objects, and Genee Coreno. B.A, Double Major in Theater and Performance/Playwriting and Screenwriting, Conservatory of Theatre Arts at SUNY Purchase College.
 
Gabriel Vasquez (director) is a director, performer, and native New Yorker. He has presented work at Muchmore’s, Dixon Place, The Tank, Vital Joint, and The Brick among others. He was a 2017 resident artist at the Drama League with Brett Evan Solomon's queer reveng tale Such a Tragedy. He began serious work on a new piece titled Minor Kerouac as part of Barton Booth’s Make Room residency on Governors Island this summer. He was last seen performing in SOMEONEPLEASELISTENANDUNDERSTAND (they’re wiretapping our brains) as part of the Exponential Festival. As an assistant director or intern, he has worked with Rachel Dickstein/Ripe Time, The TEAM, The Wooster Group, Sanaz Ghajar, and Sponsored By Nobody. BA, Theater and Performance, SUNY Purchase College. cargocollective.com/gabrielvasquez.
 

What We Need & What You Get
The majority of the funds we are hoping to raise will be going towards actor/designer stipends and rehearsal space. The entire team has been on board since our first small reading at Dixon Place and we want to make sure we can compensate them. The rest will be spent on costume/prop construction, a singular set piece, volunteer accident insurance, and contingency. Any additional funds we may raise will go to additional marketing material. 
We are so excited to share these perks with you, which include spelling lessons with William, a digital tea date with Mrs. Teapot, and our deepest gratitude. 

Other Ways You Can Help
We understand that not everyone is in a position to donate, but that doesn't mean we can't use your help! You can:
-Share this fundraiser with your friends, family, and colleagues
-Buy a ticket to the show
-Bring a friend to the show
-Like Special Events' Facebook page

story:
A sample taste, about us: 
 

  • Our names are  Ifigenia Karamitrou and Korina Gougouli. We are two recent graduates from the National Theater of Greece who are in the process of putting up an art installation inspired by Sarah Ruhl's 'Melancholy Play'.

    Our ideal wish is to introduce this work to a Greek audience given that it deals with all kinds of issues that are currently at the forefront of this time period. Moreover, the play treats issues of melancholy, depression and sadness in a very fragile and sensitive manner without being dogmatic. So far, we have been successful in completing an adaptation of Ms. Ruhls’ play based on the plays main character 'Tilly'. We've been successful in getting in touch with Sarah Ruhl as well as booking a performance space that has granted us a three month performance time period. Our only set back, as you may have already guessed, is a budget issue. Given that we are two freshly graduated actresses from the National Theater, who decided, (instead of going off to auditions), to have our first step into the theater field be something we wish to create on our own. That said, we are tight on money and are in need of your support. With all the nerve, we decided to get this campaign together to ask for some help. We would be grateful for any money that could be donated. (Cents are welcome as well).

 

What We Need
 

  • We've been lucky enough to have been offered space in BIOS a rather well-known bar located in the center of Athens, Greece that is famed for hosting art happenings and theater performances for up and coming artists. We will ideally be using part of the public bar space to exhibit an installation. This installation is schedueled to remain in place from the 21st of December to the 26th of February. 

    The group of people, who are contributing to this project and whom we hope to reimburse are:

    Ioli Andreadi, a practicing, talented, young  Director who works in Greece and abroad. She has generously helped prepare our platform and is helping with our installation.

    Aris Asproulis has, generously offered to help us with our comminications and advertising.

    Panos Michail, a talented Greek photographer who has been gracious in  offering to photograph us.

    Iakovos NAR a working artist and street artist who has supported this project and helped us build the installation.

    Thurdays- Sunday we will be present in the installation space. All this of course, comes with a budget we hope to build. Our ideal wish would be to reach a budget of 5,000 euros; This would cover costs to pay for building our installation, program, posters, costumes, lights, taxes and the reimbursing of a communications director and photographer. In short, this budget would cover the basic production costs.  

Other Ways You Can Help us:

HELP SPREAD THE WORD!!

story:
Short Summary

My name is Helen Posno and I have over 30 years of experience in the Toronto theatre community.  My new play, Challenging the Sea, has been funded by the Ontario Arts Council - Deaf and Disability Program - and will be produced at the Theatre Centre's BMO Incubator, January 2018. We hope to see you there!

Opening:Thursday, January 18 - Closing: Sunday, January 28, 2018.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Donations are needed towards covering the $5,000.00 shortfall in production monies for the upcoming performance.

Original art works by Photographer / Painter / Playwright / Textile and Video Artist Helen Posno are offered in appreciation of donations received:

  • $50.00: Receive a signed photography print. Select from Flowers 1 or Flowers 2.
  • $80.00: Receive a signed  - and framed - photography print. Select from Tree or Shore.
  • $100.00 - $250.00: Receive a signed - and framed - photography collage print. Select from Path or Angel.
  • $500.00: Receive an abstract painting. Select from Portrait or Abstract.
  • $750.00: Receive an original crochet piece.

Thank you!

The Impact

I have written and produced many plays, performances, and videos. Challenging the Sea is the most ambitious play that I have produced to date. The funds raised will enable much better production values.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

While financial contributions are of utmost import, you can also help by:

  • Telling people about this campaign
  • Telling people about the play
  • Attending the play

Thank you very much for your support.

story:
PERFORMANCES: November 1,2,3  9,10  16,17 at 8:00PM and 3:00PM

Actors Fund Art Center
160 Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn NY 11201

 

From Producer/Director Claire Beckman:

A Muslim in the Midst is a play about fear, prejudice, ideological differences, and our strivings for a common fellowship based on humanity. Despite occurring at the turn of this century, Rao's play resonates during our nation's current immigration crisis and the #metoo movement, as it navigates women's rights, the plight of immigrants and the threat of terrorism, on the human scale of a short road trip. 

 

For 15 years Brave New World Repertory Theatre has explored issues of race and social justice in America with acclaimed productions of classics like To Kill a Mockingbird, The Crucible, A View From The Bridge and The Plantation, based on The Cherry Orchard, set in Virginia in 1870.

As artists we have found that historical distance helps us gain awareness and perspective on issues that remain relevant, and with A Muslim in the Midst  we look to geographical distance to ease our understanding of the complex and painful subject of Islamophobia post 9/11.

I am honored that playwright Anand Rao has entrusted me with his play. The great acting teacher and my mentor Suzanne Shepherd says "All great works are very near to us, and very far." I hope to take the audience on a journey from near to far that will invite a deeper understanding of ourselves, our fears, and how the world changed on that school day 17 years ago. It may be too soon to tell a story about 9/11. This is a story about 9/14/01 in India.

My profound hope for this production is that it will attract Muslim and non-Muslim audience members alike, and that brave individuals will feel safe and welcome enough to stay and engage in talkbacks and audience discussions. If The United States is "the great experiment" then Brooklyn is a petri-dish. If the secular, non-partisan Art of Theatre cannot bring Muslims and Non-Muslims together for peaceful discourse in Brooklyn, then is it possible anywhere in the world?

In order for this to succeed we need your support. Annual funding from the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs, if granted, will not be accessible until after our production opens.

Please help us raise $5,000 = 1/4 of our total budget !

Our budget of $20,000 will pay for:

  • Our VENUE at The Actors Fund Arts Center in Downtown Brooklyn: $7,000
  • Our ARTISTS including an exceptional South Asian cast, creative team and crew: $8050
  • MARKETING AND PR: to reach a wide audience: $1,500
  • COSTUMES, SETS and LIGHTING expenses: $2,000
  • INSURANCE: $1450

Ticket sales will only bring in 40-50% of our budget as our ticket prices are low: Only $25 for general admission and $18 for seniors and students.

GET 2 of THE BEST SEATS IN THE HOUSE BY BECOMING A BNW MEMBER for only $150

OTHER PERKS INCLUDE: 

  • SHOUT OUTS On Facebook!
  • COMP TICKETS TO: Brave New Works 2019: Ditmas Park. The reading series where A Muslim in the Midst was the season opener in January 2018. Catch the next BIG thing!
  • A PRIVATE READING OF THE PLAY OF YOUR CHOICE IN YOUR HOME!

YOUR SUPPORT IS CRUCIAL! Theatre matters! Help make it accessible:

Be a part of ART! Help bring Anand Rao's play to a larger audience! THANKS TO THOSE OF YOU WHO HAVE HELPED BNW IN THE PAST! WE NEED YOU AGAIN!!!

Artists put it all on the line to do the work we believe in. It's risky, but we believe we have a RESPONSIBILITY TO TELL THIS STORY!

  • Several of the immigrant artists in our own company are  facing VISA challenges like never before under the current administration's new regulations. Let them know they matter!

Can't contribute a lot? That's okay! Buy a ticket! Get the word out! We look forward to seeing you at the theater!!

http://bravenewworldrep.org/current-season/

THANK YOU!!

SHOUT OUTS On Facebook!

YOUR SUPPORT IS CRUCIAL! Theatre matters! Help make it accessible:
Be a part of ART! Help bring Anand Rao's play to a larger audience! THANKS TO THOSE OF YOU WHO HAVE HELPED BNW IN THE PAST! WE NEED YOU AGAIN!!!
Artists put it all on the line to do the work we believe in. It's risky, but we believe we have a RESPONSIBILITY TO TELL THIS STORY!
Several of the immigrant artists in our own company are  facing VISA challenges like never before under the current administration's new regulations. Let them know they matter!

Can't contribute a lot? That's okay! Buy a ticket! Get the word out! We look forward to seeing you at the theater!!
http://bravenewworldrep.org/current-season/
THANK YOU!!

story:
LADY OF THE MOON You seem distressed.

CITY SLICKER I have fallen in love.

LADY OF THE MOON Being out here does that.

CITY SLICKER In the city I was sleek and empty. Here I feel a quivering, shameful openness to my body.

LADY OF THE MOON Who is it you ache for?

CITY SLICKER The Wooer. But the Wooer has a beloved. I'm fucked. Woo is me.

 

Pastoral Play

Inspired by the writings of Rictor Norton, the Healthy Oysters began exploring what a modern day pastoral comedy could look like, and how this might intersect with contemporary queerness. The pastoral setting became an ideal metaphor for queer space, and all the joy, chaos and ambiguity those spaces invite.

The play we made is about a bunch of rowdy shepherds and city folk hooking up with each other in the meadows. It features dumb jokes, original songs and takes very seriously the silliness of erotic desire

 

What Does This Fund?

We are looking to raise $5000 for our presentation at Dixon Place. All of this money will go directly in to funding our presentation. This $5000 will cover

  • Stipends for all artists involved.
  • Rehearsal space
  • Scenic and costume materials
  • Contingency/emergency funds
 

If You Want to Make a Tax-Deductible Donation

Sadly, indiegogo donations are not tax deductible. However, you can make tax deductible donations at our Fractured Atlas page. You'll be eligible for the same perks as any you might receive here!

 

Other Ways to Help

If you can't donate, spread the word! We're always looking to reach more people with this campaign. And if you want to work with us on the show, send an email to Eric at healthyoyster@gmail.com

 

The Healthy Oyster Collective

The Healthy Oysters are Eric Marlin, Sarah Lusche and Josephine Wheelwright. Founded in 2013 with actress Molly O'Keefe, we make socially conscious works in theatrically playful forms. To date, we have created three full length pieces. Our first show, If the Saints Arrive in Germany, was co-produced with Metro Arts Initiative in May of 2013. An adaptation of a Heinrich von Kleist short story, it explored the intersection of faith and community in a nunnery in sixteenth-century Germany. Our second show, Kingdom Crosses Over, had presentations at Dixon Place, PTP/NYC and Mots de Changer, Inspired by the Argentinian grotesco criollo tradition, Kingdom Crosses Over was a play with cello music about how we political coercion. Pastoral Play is our newest work, with a previous workshop at PTP/NYC. For more info on the Healthy Oysters, visit http://www.healthyoysters.com/

story:
WHY (we need you)

Five years ago I staged the Canadian premiere of the musical Bare. It was a great success and audiences were moved by it. What many people don't know is that the show, though successfully staged, suffered a huge financial loss and because the show was self-produced, it was my responsibility to shoulder that loss. The cast and crew went unpaid, the balance of the theatre rental went to a line of credit and bridges were burned with personal backers.

It has taken five years, and a lot of retail jobs to finally get back on my feet and to take another stab at staging something awesome. I am a little older and a little more realistic in my endeavours. I've learned from my mistakes and know to ask for help. I would love for my team of awesome and talented people to walk away from this production with nothing but great memories and maybe a little bit of cash for their trouble. Without the funds we hope to raise, we will not be able to offset the overhead production costs enough to make this show happen. 

WHO (we are)

The WatersEdge Theatre Collective is an independent, not-for-profit theatre collective that is committed to producing new works in music, dance and theatre created by Canadians or premiering works created internationally in Canada, while giving young artists an opportunity to perform in a professional, collaborative environment. Originally founded in the Niagara Region, the company moved to Toronto with the Canadian premiere of the rock musical bare in 2009. 

Gingers in Love is a contemporary, pseudo-sequel to Shakespeare’s A Midsummer Night’s Dream set in modern day Toronto. Narrated by an ancient Robin Goodfellow, it tells the story of Aries and Whitty, two star-crossed redheads whose magical love is the catalyst to a Shakespearean comedy of errors. It features a mix of original folk music by up-and-coming singer/songwriter Erik Kopacsi (Hair – National Tour, Jesus Christ Superstar – LOT, Toronto) and classic folk songs from the North American songbook, woven together with a bitingly witty book by playwright and director Bri Waters (bare, The Who’s Tommy, Jesus Christ Superstar – WatersEdge, The Rocky Horror Show – LOT, Toronto). 

WHAT (we need)

$5000!!

Funds raised will go towards covering:

  • the design, materials and construction of our set and costumes
  • the rental of a rehearsal hall
  • artist fees(!!)
  • advertising & publicity 
  • rentals (lighting & sound)
$5000 might not seem like a lot (or enough to cover all of these costs) but it will help our group offset the overhead investment we have already made to make this production a success and bring it to you!

WHERE (we're at)

TORONTO! 
This production, it's content, performers, artists, crew and designers are Toronto-based and are involved in this great city's many arts communities. Our company prides itself in creating opportunities for Canadians to premiere their work and showcase their talents. We don't rely on staging mass-produced, cookie-cutter, Broadway musicals and accept the financial risks that accompany this task. With your help, we can continue this great work.

HOW (you can help in other ways...)

We understand that some of you may not be in a position to support us financially, BUT you can support us in other ways! Please help spread the word about this campaign and the show OR if you would like to volunteer your time, please email us at watersedgetheatre@gmail.com. 

THANK YOU FOR YOUR AMAZING SUPPORT!

tells the story of Aries and Whitty, two star-crossed redheads whose magical love is
the catalyst to a Shakespearean comedy of errors. It features a mix of original folk music
by up-and-coming singer/songwriter Erik Kopacsi (Hair – National Tour, Jesus Christ
Superstar – LOT, Toronto) and classic folk songs from the North American songbook,
woven together with a bitingly witty book by playwright and director Bri Waters (bare,
The Who’s Tommy, Jesus Christ Superstar – WatersEdge, The Rocky Horror Show –
LOT, Toronto). 





   WHAT (we need) $5000!! 
Funds raised will go towards covering:

the design, materials and construction of our set and costumes
the rental of a rehearsal hall
artist fees(!!)
advertising & publicity 
rentals (lighting & sound)

$5000 might not seem like a lot (or enough to cover all of these costs) but it will help our group offset the overhead investment we have already made to make this production a success and bring it to you!

    WHERE (we're at) TORONTO! This production, it's content, performers, artists, crew and designers are Toronto-based and are involved in this great city's many arts communities. Our company prides itself in creating opportunities for Canadians to premiere their work and showcase their talents. We don't rely on staging mass-produced, cookie-cutter, Broadway musicals and accept the financial risks that accompany this task. With your help, we can continue this great work.
  HOW (you can help in other ways...)
We understand that some of you may not be in a position to support us financially, BUT you can support us in other ways! Please help spread the word about this campaign and the show OR if you would like to volunteer your time, please email us at watersedgetheatre@gmail.com. THANK YOU FOR YOUR AMAZING SUPPORT!

story:
WHAT is DEPARTURE! aka the SHOW 

Lua Shayenne & Co. in partnership with Amnesty International is proud to present the World premiere of DEPARTURE 00:00, a DANCEWORKS CoWorks Series Event, at the Lower Ossington Theatre October 11 to 14, 2012. 

DEPARTURE 00:00 is a 60-minute program of contemporary and traditional African dance from Mali and Guinea. Accompanied by live African drumming and music, the presentation features three powerful, moving and exhilarating new works choreographed by Toronto dance artist Lua Shayenne: War Child, based on the story of child soldiers; Landed Immigrant, based on the experience of new immigrants to Canada and African Suite, a trilogy that pays homage to the African continent.

 

WHO is DEPARTING! aka the COMPANY

 Lua Shayenne & Co. is a Toronto- based company that presents contemporary and traditional African dance works that explore current subject matters with the aim to be a vehicle for spiritual and social progress. Since its inception, the company has been gaining recognition by performing in major venues and festivals including Enwave Theatre, Afrofest, Irie Festival, Kuumba, Dusk Dances and more.

The fabolous DEPARTING are:

Choreographer                Lua Shayenne.
Dancers                                    Miranda Liverpool, Esie Mensah, Natasha Phanor, Lua Shayenne, Gigi Soleone and Allyson Trunzer.
Percussionists             Amadou Kienou, Derek Thorne and Walter Maclean.
Rehearsal director               Debbie Wilson
Composer                                 Reza Moghaddas
Lighting designer                Sharon Di Genova

HOW MUCH we need to DEPART!

We need YOUR generous support and encouragement as we actively seek to raise $5 000 from individual donors like yourself to make our production viable.

ANY amount is welcome!! 

 OUR COSTS!

BOX OFFICE - can't do without it or who'd be giving you your ticket?

$400

TECHNICIANS - someone needs to operate those complicated lights!

$644

POSTERS & FLYERS - we do need to get the word out!

$200

THEATRE RENTAL - we’d like everyone to have a place to sit.

$3,051

COSTUMES - we don't do naked shows.

$500

INSURANCE - we tried to get away with it, the theatre wouldn't have it.

$283

PROPS - just the basics.

$100

TOTAL 

$5,178 

 If you GIVE us more TO PART WITH:

You will help pay the artists who have toiled for the past year in putting this production together: Dancers, drummers, lighting designer, rehearsal director and why not the artistic director!!

Our artistic fees are over $13 000 - in case you felt really generous or just inherited a small fortune from a rich uncle or happen to be a happy Lottery winner! 

WHAT YOU GET for your one way ticket to freedom!

Take a look at the fabulous DEPARTURE gifts we’re offering:

African Dance Classes with Lua Shayenne herself

Zimbabwean soap Stone sculpture form NHARO! Fair trade store – www.nharo.com

Signed posters by the Company

Hugs from your favourite dancer or drummer

And the list goes on….and more will be added!

WHY!

To encourage us to keep PROMOTING African Dance both in its contemporary & traditional forms

Because we ADVOCATE inclusion and diversity

Because we BELIEVE that dance is a vehicle for social, moral and spiritual transformation.

….and simply because YOU LOVE DANCE!

To read more about our past work – check out our website at www.luashayenne.com

 

OTHERS WAYS YOU CAN HELP!

TELL YOUR FRIENDS!

BUY YOUR TICKET NOW – see info below

SHARE OUR VIDEO on Facebook, twitter, Linkedln, blogs… - you name it!

VISIT our WEBSITE - luashayenne.com for future performances!

 

SHOW INFO:

October 11-14, 2012

Lower Ossington Theatre | 100 A Ossington Ave. (N of Queen St. W), Toronto

Performances: October 11, 12 & 13 at 8pm • Sunday, October 14 at 5pm

Tickets: $25 in advance | $30 at the door | Groups of 5 - $100 package

Box Office: 416.915.6747 or online at www.ticketwise.ca

 

If you require additional information please contact us and we will be happy to answer any questions. 

FROM THE bottom and top of our hearts: THANK YOU!!!

story:
Everything great started as something small.

Feminism. Post-punk. Sex education. Railroads. Yoga. The internet.  British humor. Mutton chops. Hybrid cars. Al Pacino. Blazers. Krumping. The Real Houswives franchise. Kate Hudson's film career. These are all things that happened because someone had an idea, and wanted to use that idea to change the world. My project is completely unrelated to any of the examples above. I do however, believe in the power of creative expression as a means of social change. While Mosca de la Casa isn't a 'message' play, it does touch on a number of issues that deserve dialogue and recognition in an open setting. 

Project details (VIDEO COMING SOON!!):

Mosca de la Casa started as a senior thesis at Occidental College, and has been a work in progress for about two years. It's about a woman's struggle to define herself in extreme uncertainty.

A Colombian woman with a traumatic past struggles to find love and peace of mind in a foreign country, trapped in a marriage to a man she barely knows and faced with the resounding loneliness of a small Nebraska town.

NOELIA CALDERON has just arrived in Greer, Nebraska (Pop. 700). She is twenty-seven and a former escort for LatinaElite, an online ‘marriage agency’ that provides wealthy American men with their pick of beautiful Colombian brides. Noelia wed BOB DEUEL, a sixty-year-old factory owner from Greer, after flirting for several months over the agency’s website. Now left alone in a desolate house, Noelia struggles to assume a new identity of rural housewife, fighting off unrelenting ghosts from a traumatic history of abuse. While attempting to connect with those around her, Noelia falls in love with her sister-in-law LILLIAN, a woman on her own path of self-discovery. Through their brief connection, and an outward battle with figures from her past, Noelia learns that, ultimately, only she stands in the way of her freedom.


Sounds like a good time, right? Well, it is.

Why do I need cashish?

  • Because this biz is expensive. Let me explain:
  • Renting out a small, accessible space costs upwards of $200 per day. Unfortunately I can't do it by myself!
  • I need a team of brilliant actors to entertain you.
  • There must be food. There must always be food.
  • Since this is a fundraiser for CATW-LAC (see below!), I am not making any profit, so I would like to make what it costs to put the show up. I realize $2500 is a bit of a stretch, but if I could avoid going completely broke for the next five years, that would be amazing.

Why is this important?

If there's anything I've learned from watching hours and hours of television for academic and professional reasons, it's that this business of show sorely lacks a diversity of voice. There are so many fascinating untold narratives that are put on the back burner because they're not marketable to the 18-34 white demographic. My goal as a writer and as a person is to make sure POC and disadvantaged populations get their own individualized representation on film/television/stage; ultimately, Mosca is a step towards that goal.

All proceeds of the staged reading and workshop will go to Coalition Against Human Trafficking of Women-Latin America/Carribean, an organization that works to combat illegal sex trafficking via education and political advocacy on a regional basis. This branch focuses on Latin America. Many women like Noelia who are a part of international marriage agencies were previously longtime sex workers in their home country. Organizations like CATW work to make sure these women retain their rights and dignity, and that they have A WAY OUT.

The Cast (as of 07/14/12)

Noelia: Corina Calderon (http://www.imdb.com/name/nm3860877/)

Lillian: Veronica Alicino (http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0019585/)

Bob: Dave Pevsner (http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0678931/)

Greg: Tom Kiesche (http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0452622/)

Julie: Leyna Juliet-Weber (http://www.imdb.com/name/nm1274142/)

When?

STAGED READING will occur in Los Angeles between the 1st and 2nd week of September 2012. (TENTATIVE)

WORKSHOP details to be determined.

What else can you do?

If you can't donate, pleeeaase tell your friends! And let me know if you want to help with tickets/programs.

More specifics to come!

Thank you so much for taking the time to read or skim this. I truly appreciate it. Let's do this!

More specifics to come!

story:
Meet the Team:

 

Brian Patrick Murphy is an actor and producer whose television work includes the recent Netflix series "Seven Seconds", the Emmy nominated series "Tainted Dreams" as well as "Billions", "VINYL" and "Law and Order SVU". On film he had supporting roles in "Occupy Texas", "Back in the Day" and played Anthony LaPaglia's younger version in "A Good Marriage". His stage work includes "The Clearing" directed by Josh Hecht which he produced and acted in at Theatre at St. Clements, "Two Gentlemen of Verona" at Bryant Park, "Italian American Reconciliation" at Barrow Group and "Orange Lemon Egg Canary" at PS 122.

Lisa Fernandez has been seen on stage in productions of "Brilliant Traces", "Sweet Bird of Youth", "Two Nobel Midsummer Nightsmen" and "The Haunting of Sleepy Hollow". As a voice over artist she's worked on commercials for CSU Global, Frank Stryker Productions and Charles Koppelman, among others. She's studied Meisner training with David Newer and movement with Ted Morin at William Esper Studio, vocal production with Patsy Rodenberg and Master Class with Larry Moss.

Aimée Fortier returns to director's chair after directing the new play Denmark this summer that was featured in Forbes. A lifelong actor, she's been seen in the TV series "Adultish", "Mr. Robot" and "Sonny with a Chance" as well as in numerous films.

The Play

In a deserted bar in the Bronx, Danny, a 29 year old truck driver who likes to use his fists to settle self-perceived disputes, encounters Roberta, a 31 year old divorced mother who suffers terrible guilt from an incident involving her father which has made her mistrustful of men. Both are lonely, isolated and in desperate need of understanding. Danny offers Roberta some of his beer, and she comes over to where he is seated. During their conversation each reveals the anguish, anger and despair they share about their individual circumstances, taking unusual solace in the extremity of the other's emotions. Roberta invites Danny to spend the night with her, and his lack of comprehension brings out her tenderness. After a night together the hope for a meaningful relationship starts to surface for both of them until Roberta begins to doubt Danny's capability for change...as well as her own.

story:
About Clean - The Musical

Clean was first performed as a play with music in 2019 at the Brighton Fringe Festival. It was a huge success, selling out all performances during its run. Clean won the New Writing South's Best New Play award. The reviews from both industry and the public were heartwarming and encouraged us to continue with the bigger plan, to bring Clean - The Musical  to life!

Clean - The Musical  explores the lives of seven women living in the historic Roundhill (or Laundry Hill) area of Brighton through different eras, from 1880 to today.  Through each of the characters' stories and the way in which these are interwoven, it highlights common themes and shows how much has - and hasn’t - changed.  The strength and support of sisterhood underpins these women's lives  - from laundry work to women’s hospital to modern female friendships. 

Whilst gritty and emotionally powerful, Clean - The Musical is a celebration of sisterhood - and as the reviews and audience reactions testify - ultimately uplifting and inspiring.

Perhaps now more than ever in a world where hard won rights are under threat, these stories need to be told.

Casting:

Millicent (50s)  - (1880) Millicent works in the Tivoli laundry. Her children have all left home apart from her youngest who is about to go into service.

Helen (30s) - (1905) Dr Helen Boyle, founder of the first hospital in England for women with mental illness, with her partner Mabel Jones. Boyle cared for many women who would previously have been sent to the poor house and is celebrated as a lesbian and feminist icon.

Meg (20s) - (1928) Meg campaigns to encourage local women to vote after universal suffrage.

Dot (40s) - (1950) Dot’s husband owns a laundry that was involved in the 1950 smallpox epidemic.

Ruby (20s) - (1977) Ruby is running away from abuse and addiction. She joins a commune in a squat on the Upper Lewes Road.

Juliet (50s) - (2005) Juliet, a writer, is struggling with the menopause.  Sleepless nights trigger some difficult memories.

Tasha (30s) - (2018) Single and pregnant, Tasha returns to her now empty family home after living abroad for many years. She sees the area - and her life - through fresh eyes.

 

(Photo credit Peter Williams.  Thanks to our original cast - Sharon Drain, Abi McLoughlin, Rebecca Jones, Jenny Rowe, Cerys Knighton, Kerri Hedley-Cheney, Chelsea Newton-Mountney and Judey Bignell who appear in these pictures and in the campaign video)

 

The creators

Sam Chittenden is an award-winning playwright and director, and the Artistic Director of Different Theatre.  She has staged a number of successful fringe productions in Brighton, London and Edinburgh, including So You Say, Metamorphosis, Sary and Clean.

Simon Scardanelli - is a composer and songwriter with a long list of professional credits. He has released 6 solo albums, and was half of the duo Big Bam Boo who had a brief run of success in the USA & Canada in the late 80s.  He has written music for theatre, including several productions for Different Theatre, art installations, sub-aqua concerts and performance art. 

 

Our Dream

The one act version of Clean included two original songs, written by Simon, and it has been our plan for a while to turn this one act play into a full length musical.

Staging a production of any kind is an expensive business.  The musical version of Clean will require seven actors, along with a number of musicians and other creatives.  We are keen to take our project to the next level, staging a fully professional production next year and using this as a calling card to attract industry support.  

Our dream is to take the stories of these ordinary and renowned Brighton women to the West End.  We’d love you to be part of their journey.  

 

What We Need

We need to cover the costs of staging a production in May 2020, as part of Brighton Fringe, including the rehearsal time.  Most of this cost is to enable us to pay the singers/actors, musicians and other creatives in line with professional guidelines.  The script and songs are already written, but we do also need to time to develop the orchestration and workshop the new production.

There are also some costs associated with filming the production and creating a promotional brochure.

An outline of the costs is as follows:

Rehearsals (paying cast and crew; renting rehearsal space) - £7000

Promotional materials (filming the show; creating promo pack) - £1000

Fringe costs (registration fee, lighting hire, marketing) - £1000

Staging the show (venue rental, paying cast) - £4000 less estimated tickets sales of £3000 = £1000

TOTAL cost - £10000

If for whatever reason we do not meet our goal, we will still stage the production, but we will have to work with cast on an expenses plus profit share basis, and reduce the budget for marketing and promotional materials.

 

What You Get

There are some great perks on offer, from tickets to an exclusive preview show and 'Clean' t-shirts, to workshops and song-writing sessions, to being an Executive Producer or 'Archangel'.  You can help us with contributions as little as £5.   

Even if you aren't able to support us financially, you can help us spread the work by sharing the campaign using the share tools.

 

Risks

We have a strong track record of staging productions with over a dozen successful fringe productions to our name.  The main risk is of not being able to find the right cast with strong acting, singing and playing abilities.  With our reputation, and the ability to pay professional rates, we believe we can attract a great cast.  

 

Thank You

We hope you are excited about the prospect of Clean - The Musical coming to life, and that you will want to follow its journey.  Thank you for your help!

Sam & Simon

Juliet (50s) - (2005) Juliet, a writer, is struggling with the menopause.  Sleepless nights trigger some difficult memories.
Tasha (30s) - (2018) Single and pregnant, Tasha returns to her now empty family home after living abroad for many years. She sees the area - and her life - through fresh eyes.
 
(Photo credit Peter Williams.  Thanks to our original cast - Sharon Drain, Abi McLoughlin, Rebecca Jones, Jenny Rowe, Cerys Knighton, Kerri Hedley-Cheney, Chelsea Newton-Mountney and Judey Bignell who appear in these pictures and in the campaign video)
 
The creators
Sam Chittenden is an award-winning playwright and director, and the Artistic Director of Different Theatre.  She has staged a number of successful fringe productions in Brighton, London and Edinburgh, including So You Say, Metamorphosis, Sary and Clean.
Simon Scardanelli - is a composer and songwriter with a long list of professional credits. He has released 6 solo albums, and was half of the duo Big Bam Boo who had a brief run of success in the USA & Canada in the late 80s.  He has written music for theatre, including several productions for Different Theatre, art installations, sub-aqua concerts and performance art. 

 
Our Dream
The one act version of Clean included two original songs, written by Simon, and it has been our plan for a while to turn this one act play into a full length musical.
Staging a production of any kind is an expensive business.  The musical version of Clean will require seven actors, along with a number of musicians and other creatives.  We are keen to take our project to the next level, staging a fully professional production next year and using this as a calling card to attract industry support.  
Our dream is to take the stories of these ordinary and renowned Brighton women to the West End.  We’d love you to be part of their journey.  
 
What We Need
We need to cover the costs of staging a production in May 2020, as part of Brighton Fringe, including the rehearsal time.  Most of this cost is to enable us to pay the singers/actors, musicians and other creatives in line with professional guidelines.  The script and songs are already written, but we do also need to time to develop the orchestration and workshop the new production.
There are also some costs associated with filming the production and creating a promotional brochure.
An outline of the costs is as follows:
Rehearsals (paying cast and crew; renting rehearsal space) - £7000
Promotional materials (filming the show; creating promo pack) - £1000
Fringe costs (registration fee, lighting hire, marketing) - £1000
Staging the show (venue rental, paying cast) - £4000 less estimated tickets sales of £3000 = £1000
TOTAL cost - £10000
If for whatever reason we do not meet our goal, we will still stage the production, but we will have to work with cast on an expenses plus profit share basis, and reduce the budget for marketing and promotional materials.
 
What You Get
There are some great perks on offer, from tickets to an exclusive preview show and 'Clean' t-shirts, to workshops and song-writing sessions, to being an Executive Producer or 'Archangel'.  You can help us with contributions as little as £5.   
Even if you aren't able to support us financially, you can help us spread the work by sharing the campaign using the share tools.
 
Risks
We have a strong track record of staging productions with over a dozen successful fringe productions to our name.  The main risk is of not being able to find the right cast with strong acting, singing and playing abilities.  With our reputation, and the ability to pay professional rates, we believe we can attract a great cast.  
 

Thank You
We hope you are excited about the prospect of Clean - The Musical coming to life, and that you will want to follow its journey.  Thank you for your help!
Sam & Simon

story:
Just $15,000 is enough to bring SHINE: A Burlesque Musical to Vancouver


The Show

SHINE: A Burlesque Musical  is an original show with songs by Cass King & John Woods of The Wet Spots, and script by Cass King and Sam Dulmage. It combines the bawdy comedy of burlesque with a full book musical. It's a smart, sexy night out for grown-ups. SHINE is the HBO of live musical theatre.


The Story

At the crumbling but historic Aristocrat theatre, Shine Mionne and her chosen family of sexpots and misfits struggle to save the theatre from imminent gentrification in the guise of smooth-talking money man Richard Suit. Along the way Frankie, the newbie actor from out of town, and Grace, the dimpled Gender Studies student  are drawn into the vortex of life at The Aristocrat by a diva named Lulu. As Suit and Shine fight for control of the show, Lulu finds her leading-lady status jeopardized by Suit's meddling and a series of whirlwind affairs threatens to throw the impending opening into chaos.

SHINE is a tassel-twirling original musical about an infamous burlesque theatre and the family of talented misfits who try to save it from demolition… or worse, respectability.


The Goal

@ $15,000 - This is the minimum we need to put on our show.  It will cover the basics: venue fees, rehearsal space, minimal advertising and other pre-show expenses.

@ $25,000 - We also cover cast and crew pay, leaving more in the budget to improve the quality of production, while also giving us more resources to promote and advertise the show. 

@ $30,000 - We cover MOST of the show's fixed costs, allowing us to do all of the above, plus increasing the pay for our performers and crew.

An independent show this big can't happen without your support.

Bottom Line: The more you donate... the better we can make this experience for our cast, our crew, AND our audience.


Project History

SHINE was first conceived by Cass King and John Woods while on tour with their internationally acclaimed cabaret act The Wet Spots. After years of performing in burlesque venues around the world, Cass and John wanted to capture the ragged, glittered glory they found in those tight-knit, oft-endangered spaces. They joined forces with award-winning actor / playwright / screenwriter Sam Dulmage and began crafting a show.

SHINE first hit the stage at the Vancouver Burlesque Festival in 2009, where it played for two standing-room-only shows and was the runaway festival hit. It then quickly moved across town to The Waterfront Theatre - a commercial 225 seater in the Granville Island theatre district - where it sold out a two-week run.

In July 2010, SHINE was mounted for a successful two week run in Seattle, Washington at Theatre Off Jackson. It opened in New York City in August 2010 at the Ellen Stewart Theater at La Mama, for five performances in the New York Fringe Festival.

Since 2010, the creative team has dedicated itself to massive redevelopment of the show – refining the script, replacing merely catchy songs with utterly irrepressible hits, and preparing for a new production with a full live band. You can hear some of the new material at the official SHINE website.


Critical Response:

Time Out New York

“Hands-down more goosebumps per minute than any other  show... It’s ‘RENT’ for our generation... The music is Broadway calibre... If it doesn’t go on to a longer run, there is no God.”

Stage and Cinema

"SHINE is simultaneously smart and sexy.  The show expertly balances between sincerity and campy send-up, striking notes of nostalgia for vanishing venues while humorously highlighting the missteps that we make when trying to preserve the things we love."

Theatre Is Easy NYC

“The show is brilliant: brilliant performances, amazingly classy dancing, badass vocal performances and all around stellar and crisp acting. Bottom Line: You do NOT want to miss SHINE: A Burlesque Musical" ('Can't Miss' recommendation)

The Vancouver Courier

"Omigawd what rude fun… It has all the makings of a cult classic."

The Georgia Straight Vancouver

"A huge amount of fun. Everybody on-stage is having a fantastic time and that joy flows, barrier-free, into the audience. An anthem worthy of Broadway."

The Vancouver Ovation Awards

Winner - Outstanding New Work of 2009


The Creative Team

The talented people who are lending their skills to this Vancouver run bring several lifetimes' worth of experience in show business into one amazing project.

Cass King- Writer

Sam Dulmage- Writer

John Woods - Original Music and Lyrics, Producer

Simon Webb- Director

Blue Morris- Music Director

Diva Fandango- Choreographer

The Venue

We are excited to announce that the Vancouver run of SHINE: A Burlesque Musical will take place at The WISE Hall - 1882 Adanac St, Vancouver.

The WISE Hall is the epicentre of East Van burlesque and the first venue where SHINE was mounted as a scripted show, several years ago. The 2016 run will be a glam homecoming! SHINE’s story of a badass theatre under siege by market forces is also the story of the WISE Hall, so mounting the show in this space is particularly poignant. We thank you for your support.

Donate Today!


Strapped For Cash?

We get it. You can also help a lot by posting a link to this page on your various social media outlets!

story:
Short Summary

THE SHOW:

A cross-section of desperate, smart, sassy, affectionate, aware and determined women give and get support in spirited weekly (group therapy) meetings guided by Grace, a creative and savvy therapist. Dena, a hesitant new member, alters the chemistry of this "group" and stimulates a round of powerful, evocative and uplifting breakthroughs. As many contemporary issues are explored with humor, wit and sensitivity, the women bond to create a new kind of family.

This show was born in the late 80s when "group" was kicking into high gear.  Audiences today need to see this show to remind them that there is strength to be gained in sharing. People today spend too much time being isolated in their cars, sequestered behind earphones, plugged in to their own private playlists and libraries. As many young people today are discovering, there is joy to be had in shared experiences; like listening to music together on a turntable.

INSIDE OUT is a very positive, funny, feel-good evening. Now, twenty years older, it celebrates and embraces the dawning of the support group age. It's now set in the 80s. And come on, now, who doesn't love the 80s?

THE CREATIVE TEAM:

Hello. We are:

Doug Haverty (Book/Lyrics) Doug’s award-winning plays and musicals have been produced around the world. Could I Have This Dance? was named “Best New Play” by The American Theatre Critics Association. His works been presented at Cherry Lane, Charlotte Rep., Laguna Playhouse, Phoenix Theatre, Florida Studio, Theatre West, The Colony, Theatre 40, The Lyric, Here Performing Arts Center, Long Island Stage, Theatre in the Square, Lobero, just to name a few. Published works include: In My Mind’s Eye, Inside Out (A Musical), Could I Have This Dance?, Flavia & The Dream Maker (A musical). He’s been commissioned to write three musicals and one play. All kinds of wonderful actors have appeared in Doug’s plays including: Marilyn Chris, John Wylie, Teri Ralston, Lee Meriwether, Ann Crumb, Jan Maxwell, Kathleen Chalfont, Cass Morgan, Jennifer Tilly, Elizabeth Norment, Bonita Friederici, and Isabel Keating, just to name a few.

Adryan Russ (Music/Lyrics) writes for theater, film, television and recordings.  Her off-Broadway musical Inside Out, co-written with Doug Haverty, published by Samuel French, has played around the world. Love & Order, co-written with Haverty, was selected for the ASCAP/Disney Musical Theatre Workshop in Los Angeles, and Ebenezer, Return of the Scrooge, co-written with playwright Keith Huff, was selected for the ASCAP/Disney Workshop in Chicago. The Ugly Duckling, co-written with Lloyd J. Schwartz, was produced at Theatre West’s Storybook Theatre for kids. Everyone Has A Story: The Songs of Adryan Russ http://www.lmlmusic.com/artists/adryanruss/ showcases Adryan’s songs performed by David Burnham, Susan Egan, Jason Graae, Joan Ryan and Sharon McNight, among others, produced by Bruce Kimmel. A song co-written with Joel Evans appeared in the film Doubt with Meryl Streep and in The Falcon Theatre’s A Catholic Girl’s Guide to Losing Your Virginity.  With Lissa Levin, she co-produced Life’s A Stitch, a fundraiser for The Susan Love Breast Cancer Foundation at The Alex Theatre. Adryan is a member of ASCAP, The Dramatists Guild, and serves on the board of the Society of Composers & Lyricists www.TheSCL.com  Visit websites for more info:  www.adryanruss.com and www.playworksmusic.com

Bruce Kimmel (Director) wrote, directed and starred in the cult movie hit, The First Nudie Musical (available on a Special Edition Blu-ray).  He also co-created (with David Wechter) the story for the hit film, The Faculty, directed by Robert Rodriguez.  As an actor, Mr. Kimmel guest-starred on most of the long-running television shows of the 1970s, including The Partridge Family (recurring), Happy Days, Laverne and Shirley, MASH, Alice, and many others, including leading roles in several pilots for all three of the major networks.

Mr. Kimmel is a legendary Grammy-nominated producer of theatre music on CD, having produced over 180 albums. He has produced solo albums for Petula Clark, Helen Reddy, Jason Graae, Liz Callaway, Christiane Noll, Rebecca Luker, Brent Barrett, Sally Mayes, Judy Kaye, Judy Kuhn, and many others.  In addition to the albums he has personally produced, Kimmel has also released over four hundred classic cast albums and soundtracks, including his acclaimed remixes of the original cast albums of Follies, Promises, Promises and Sugar.  His label, Kritzerland, issues a new CD every two weeks.  For the past four years he has been producing and hosting a series of live entertainments based on the albums he’s produced, called Kritzerland at Sterling’s Upstairs at The Federal, which feature incredible singers and fun guest stars. He is also the creator, writer, and director of the popular web series, Outside the Box.  Most recently he directed a critically acclaimed production of Li’l Abner and taken the Kritzerland shows to New York.

THE PLAN:

We plan to mount a stellar anniversary production of the musical INSIDE OUT (A musical about giving and getting support in an all-girl “group”) to commemorate the 20th anniversary and re-release/re-mastering of the Original Off Broadway Cast Recording. A portion of the proceeds will go to the Dr. Susan Love Research Foundation (for a Future Without Breast Cancer). This show will be a celebration of women supporting women with an all female cast and all female band.

http://www.dslrf.org/breastcancer/

Our contributors will help us build this fine production with funds going toward: sets, lights, costumes, theater rental, marketing and cast salaries. The creative staff is donating their participation. This musicals deals with giving and getting support and finding family in shared interests.

THE CAST:

It is our intention to assemble a cast of six brilliantly talented and well-known musical theater actresses. So far we have:

Cynthia Ferrer
A regular on television's General Hospital and Port Charles; appeared in musical versions of: Happy Days, Sleepless in Seattle, 9 to 5, Dirty Rotten Scoundrels, Footloose and the Pre-Broadway tour of Turn to the Right.

Sandy Bainum
Broadway and First National Tour of 42nd Street as Anytime Annie, starred in productions at The Kennedy Center, Ford Theatre and Signature Theatre in musicals: Company, Parade, Ladies Swing the Blues, Showboat, Music Man and Kiss Me Kate.

Adrienne Visnic

Award-winning actress featured in The Most Happy Fella, On The Town, Dirty Rotten Scoundrels, A Little Night Music, Thoroughly Modern Millie, Into The woods, Les Misérables, Damn Yankees, and Pippin. 

Stephanie Fredricks
Broadway’s Wonderful Town, plays and musicals at Paper Mill Playhouse, Portland Stage Company, the El Portal Theatre; television’s All My Children, and the upcoming Henry Jaglom film, Ovation, in theaters this spring. 

Dana Meller

Broadway/National Touring companies of Les Miserables (Eponine), The Full Monty (Estelle) and productions at: Kennedy Center, North Shore Music Theatre, The El Portal Theatre as well as television's The Days of Our Lives, The Today Show.

Leslie Stevens

Broadway/National Touring companies of Victor/Victoria, La Cage aux Folles, Big and plays/musicals at Laguna Playhouse, I.C.T., Taper, Geffen, Pasadena Playhouse, GeVa and television's The Young and the Restless.


What We Need & What You Get

We are not a year-round producer of theatrical events. We are renting the charming Grove Theatre Center in Burbank (which in addition to offering great seating, provides tons of free parking both on street and venue lot). The concept calls for minimal settings and modest costume budgets; we'll be spending the bulk of the budget on theater rental, salaries for the cast, and publicity, so that we can present the music and musical play to its strongest effect. Since we do not have a subscriber base or permanent mailing list, we will be marketing this event heavily so that Southern California theatre-going audiences are aware of it.

If we do not reach our total goal, we will endeavor to produce the show with less funds devoted to marketing and have to rely on word of mouth. The budget is set to cover the pre-production and running costs for six weeks.

The Impact

When INSIDE OUT initially opened in Los Angeles, it was supposed to run for five weeks. It was a huge hit and ended up running for five months. It deals with five women in group therapy (and their therapist). Audiences — women AND men — really respond to it. While this was written in the late 80s, it was initially presented as a contemporary piece. Now, twenty years later, it is a period piece. We are embracing its origins (and relative newness then) and keeping it set in the 80s, which will also point up its ultimate timelessness.

INSIDE OUT was recently produced in Zurich, Switzerland (in English). We were unsure as to how the Swiss people would react to this piece. Most everyone in Switzerland speaks some English, but their primary languages are French and German. Plus group therapy is not widely available there and no one discusses their private or shared psycho-therapy. Well, the show went over like gang-busters, selling out immediately and warranting a return engagement six months later. The European audiences ate it up.

When INSIDE OUT opened at the Cherry Lane Theatre it was given a valentine rave review in the New York Times by Stephen Holden and has since been produced all over the country.

The message inside INSIDE OUT is still relevant today; that people helping people is one of the most valuable things human beings can do for one another. This is evidenced in the play and, hopefully, will be evidenced in the production of this play. The frosting on top of all of this is that a portion of the proceeds from the production will go to the 1983-founded Dr. Susan Love Research Foundation. This “army of women” is dedicated to not only finding a cure for Breast Cancer, but as Dr. Love states, “the key to ending breast cancer is to learn how to stop it before it starts.”
CAST ALBUM BONANZA PACK PERK (See Perks)


Risks & Challenges

Any kind of theatrical endeavor is risky. We can start out with the best intentions, best cast, best direction, and so much depends on audience reaction. To date, there has always been a wonderful reaction to this show. Many things can dramatically affect the build of a show like this; weather, financial climate, other theater events at the same time, and word-of-mouth. We have a relatively short run. Typically audiences wait to hear what everyone else thinks, then they book tickets. We will have to rely on great word of mouth and a compelling need to book tickets immediately. Everyone will have to understand that this is a special event and limited run.

Other Ways You Can Help

We realize that many people are hard-pressed to give money to causes like this and budgets are still strained. There are other ways to participate and help us make this special event a success:

—  Spread the word. Take postcards and bookmarks to groups of people who might be interested.

—  Initiate a group. Bring a group of ten and we’ll give you two free tickets.

—  Host with us. Come to the theater an hour before show and play “usher” or “usherette” and help us ensure everyone has a great time at the theater.

—  Even if you cannot donate at this time, you can share the information about this Indiegogo campaign. Just forwarding this information could be helpful if it reaches the right person.
