Sandy BainumBroadway and First National Tour of 42nd Street as Anytime Annie, starred in productions at The Kennedy Center, Ford Theatre and Signature Theatre in musicals: Company, Parade, Ladies Swing the Blues, Showboat, Music Man and Kiss Me Kate.
Adrienne Visnic
Award-winning actress featured in The
Most Happy Fella, On The Town, Dirty Rotten Scoundrels, A Little Night Music,
Thoroughly Modern Millie, Into The woods, Les Misérables, Damn Yankees, and
Pippin. 



Stephanie FredricksBroadway’s Wonderful Town, plays and musicals at Paper Mill Playhouse, Portland Stage Company, the El Portal Theatre; television’s All My Children, and the upcoming Henry Jaglom film, Ovation, in theaters this spring. 


Dana MellerBroadway/National Touring companies of Les Miserables (Eponine), The Full Monty (Estelle) and productions at: Kennedy Center, North Shore Music Theatre, The El Portal Theatre as well as television's The Days of Our Lives, The Today Show.


Leslie StevensBroadway/National Touring companies of Victor/Victoria, La Cage aux Folles, Big and plays/musicals at Laguna Playhouse, I.C.T., Taper, Geffen, Pasadena Playhouse, GeVa and television's The Young and the Restless.

   What We Need & What You Get 
We are not a year-round
producer of theatrical events. We are renting the charming Grove Theatre Center
in Burbank (which in addition to offering great seating, provides tons of free
parking both on street and venue lot). The concept calls for minimal settings and modest
costume budgets; we'll be spending the bulk of the budget on theater rental, salaries for the cast, and publicity, so that we can present the music and musical play to its strongest
effect. Since we do not have a subscriber base or permanent mailing list, we
will be marketing this event heavily so that Southern California theatre-going
audiences are aware of it.
If we do not reach our total goal, we will endeavor to produce the show with less funds devoted to
marketing and have to rely on word of mouth. The budget is set to cover the pre-production and running costs for six
weeks.   The Impact 
When INSIDE OUT initially opened in Los
Angeles, it was supposed to run for five weeks. It was a huge hit and ended up
running for five months. It deals with five women in group therapy (and their
therapist). Audiences — women AND men — really respond to it. While this was
written in the late 80s, it was initially presented as a contemporary piece.
Now, twenty years later, it is a period piece. We are embracing its origins
(and relative newness then) and keeping it set in the 80s, which will also
point up its ultimate timelessness.

INSIDE OUT was recently produced in Zurich,
Switzerland (in English). We were unsure as to how the Swiss people would react
to this piece. Most everyone in Switzerland speaks some English, but their
primary languages are French and German. Plus group therapy is not widely
available there and no one discusses their private or shared psycho-therapy.
Well, the show went over like gang-busters, selling out immediately and
warranting a return engagement six months later. The European audiences ate it
up.


When INSIDE OUT opened at the Cherry Lane
Theatre it was given a valentine rave review in the New York Times by Stephen Holden and has since
been produced all over the country.


The message inside INSIDE OUT is still
relevant today; that people helping people is one of the most valuable things
human beings can do for one another. This is evidenced in the play and,
hopefully, will be evidenced in the production of this play. The frosting on top
of all of this is that a portion of the proceeds from the production will go to
the 1983-founded Dr. Susan Love Research Foundation. This “army of women” is
dedicated to not only finding a cure for Breast Cancer, but as Dr. Love states,
“the key to ending breast cancer is to learn how to stop it before it starts.” 
CAST ALBUM BONANZA PACK PERK (See Perks)  


Risks & Challenges  
Any kind of theatrical
endeavor is risky. We can start out with the best intentions, best cast, best
direction, and so much depends on audience reaction. To date, there has always been
a wonderful reaction to this show. Many things can dramatically affect the
build of a show like this; weather, financial climate, other theater events at
the same time, and word-of-mouth. We have a relatively short run. Typically
audiences wait to hear what everyone else thinks, then they book tickets. We
will have to rely on great word of mouth and a compelling need to book tickets
immediately. Everyone will have to understand that this is a special event and
limited run.   Other Ways You Can Help 

We realize that many people are hard-pressed
to give money to causes like this and budgets are still strained. There are
other ways to participate and help us make this special event a success:
— 
Spread the word. Take postcards and bookmarks
to groups of people who might be interested.
— 
Initiate a group. Bring a group of ten and
we’ll give you two free tickets.
— 
Host with us. Come to the theater an hour
before show and play “usher” or “usherette” and help us ensure everyone has a
great time at the theater.
— 
Even if you cannot donate at this time, you
can share the information about this Indiegogo campaign. Just forwarding this
information could be helpful if it reaches the right person.

story:
About Spartan Mambo

Spartan Mambo is the official salsa performance team at San José State University. Our goal is to enrich the lives of SJSU students and members of the San Jose community through performance salsa dance.

We perform at numerous events throughout the school year, both on and off campus. Some of our past events have included the Spartan Basketball games, Fire on the Fountain, the San Francisco International Salsa Congress and the World Latin Dance Cup.

Our Goal

This year, our team will be traveling to the College Salsa Congress in Los Angeles. The College Salsa Congress is the largest collegiate salsa competition in the country, bringing together students from over 25 colleges and universities who compete for the title of College Salsa Champion.

We are seeking to raise $4,000 through this Indiegogo campaign. The money will go towards our travel & lodging expenses, event registration fees, and costumes and apparel. We have a large team this semester, so we have a lot of expenses. Anything you can contribute is appreciated!

The Impact

Your contribution will help us to get to the competition and compete! Help our team win the College Salsa Championships and bring the trophy back to the Bay Area!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't have the money, we understand! If you could just help us spread the word, that means a lot to us! Just share this link on Facebook or e-mail it to a few of your friends to help us reach our goal. Thanks you for your support!

story:
hi, my name is isabella and i am 14 years old.  i have been dancing since i was 3  and studing ballet seriously since age 7.

I am raising money to fund my summer intensive ballet program and for a publicity photoshoot. This campaign is important to me because the summer intensive will help prepare me for another year of intense training and the photoshoot will help me get publicity for my dancing as well as opening doors for many opritunities. This contribution will help me reach my goals as a professional dancer. 
My total fundig need is $4,000. $3,000 of this will go toward my training this summer. $1,000 will go toward my publicity photoshoot.
I'm an optimistic young person who works hard to meet my goals. All funds raised will go toward helping my goals as a professional dancer. 
Your contribution will make it possible for my dance carreer training to keep moving forward. I hope to be a positive influece on other young dancers as i work toward my goals. In addition to your contributions, please share my cause with your friends and family. Don't forget to use indiegogo share tools! 
                                                                                             Thank you,
                                                                                                     Bella

story:
Hello, my name is Cicely Whitehead and I am a 21 year old actor from Brighton. After a gruelling 4 years of applying to drama schools across the UK, I have been successful in gaining 1 of only 16 places at one of the most prestigious and leading schools, Drama Centre London on their BA Acting course.

Attending drama school has been a goal of mine for years and something I have consistently worked towards through participating in local theatre including Brighton Little Theatre and The Brighton Laboratory and attending as many workshops as possible in order to prepare for drama school auditions.

Over the past 4 years auditioning, I have personally paid for travel costs (sometimes to the opposite end of the country!), audition fees and various books whilst holding down 3 jobs simultaneously in order to fund this. Aged 17 I successfully gained a place with the National Youth Theatre of Great Britain and self-funded the two week course through various fundraising and part-time weekend work in order to take part in this amazing opportunity.

However, aside from achieving 100% student satisfaction rates for training and hosting an incredible alumni including Tom Hardy, Michael Fassbender and Colin Firth, Drama Centre also happens to be in one of the most expensive areas of London!
Whilst my ambition and determination has got me this far, there is now a real need for additional help, as my student loan and maintenance grant both fall short of the amount required for living and travel costs. Part of what makes the standard of training at Drama Centre so high are the long hours, ending anywhere between 8.30 and 10.00pm from 5-6 days a week, making the possibility of taking on a job during term-time highly unlikely. As a first-year student, bursaries are not available from the school but I will be applying for any that I can for my second and third years.

As a result, I need your help! I have been able to find the cheapest accommodation available and intend to live on as little as possible once in London, but living and travel costs still amount to more than I can afford with my loan.
Up to this point, I have done everything I can to raise more money, working extra shifts, selling my wardrobe and the contents of my bedroom (!), but having done the maths, I now realise it is time to ask for help. If you could make any donation, however small, it will be hugely appreciated. Any amount can help massively and I will be eternally grateful.

Thank you for reading my story,
Cicely x

Find out more about the school and training here:

https://youtu.be/sF4HcqKo0y0

story:
THE PLAN

We are planning to stage two plays by Samuel Beckett: Krapp’s Last Tape, and the shorter Ohio Impromptu--it's been 30+ years since either of these has been staged in Memphis. The show will run from September 11-20, 2015, at TheatreSouth in the First Congo church at 1000 S. Cooper.

WHO WE ARE

We are two Memphians who have been involved in theater and performing arts for many years.

Tony Isbell will be playing Krapp in Krapp’s Last Tape. This is a bucket-list role for Tony, who has long been a mainstay of the Memphis theater community. He has numerous Ostrander nominations and awards, both for acting and directing, including for his performance as Salieri in Amadeus and for directing Glengarry Glen Ross at Theatre Memphis. He recently directed Rapture, Blister, Burn at Theatre Memphis and last year played the role of Mark Rothko in Red at Circuit Playhouse. He has always been an admirer of Beckett’s work and has previously directed productions of Waiting for Godot and Endgame.  He believes that 500 years from now, Samuel Beckett will be the only 20th-century playwright still being read and discussed.

Adam Remsen was a filmmaker and actor for many years before refocusing his attention on live theater several years ago. He has received several Ostrander nominations for his parts in various shows, but is thus far playing the Susan Lucci role on awards night. Adam did extensive graduate study on Beckett’s short plays, including Ohio Impromptu, but this is his first participation in a Beckett production.

The idea for the show arose from a Facebook conversation in which Tony expressed his wish to play Krapp someday. The two struck up a conversation about staging Krapp's Last Tape themselves, and decided to add Ohio Impromptu in order to strengthen the program, as the two plays both touch upon similar themes of memory, nostalgia, and loss.

WHAT WE HOPE TO RAISE

We are not relying on this campaign to cover the entire cost of production. Our goal is to raise $1,920 to help with the following costs:

  • Theater rental: $1,200
  • Script rights for six performances of both plays: $720

Of course, donating has its perks:

  • For a $25 contribution, you will get a ticket to the show for the night of your choice.
  • For $45, you get two tickets.
  • For $100, you get two tickets and a poster signed by Tony and Adam (or whatever combination thereof you’d like).
  • For $200, you can attend a pre-opening dress rehearsal of the show, and socialize with the cast and crew afterward.

For a $2,000 donation, just tell us what you want and we’ll probably do it. We are not proud.

Thank you!

story:
•  PAGE2STAGE ENTERTAINMENT & FULL HOUSE PRODUCTIONS

  • The Wonderful Wizard of Oz -- A New Musical

      This production has been in the works for twelve long years. The writer has been directing and working on readings of this project since grade school. The project had five readings in an Off-Broadway Theatre Festival in NYC before putting up a workshop of that script in 2007 in Seattle, Washington. 

    The Workshop helped us see that we needed to tell the real story of the Book, not of the MGM film. This is how we have created an action-heavy retelling of an American Classic, with the freedom to tell a more in-depth story. We have added some lines here and there, as well as songs from the 1903 Broadway musical, which made Oz a household name.

    Our retelling is more of an origin story; a true American Tale. The audience will learn about the stories that helped shape Oz into what it is.

    Dorothy’s house falls into Oz, crushing one of the evil witches who held an evil, terrible reign over the land. Dorothy has been orphaned and left to live out the rest of her days with her mother’s twin sister, Emily Blue. She has to learn to put her emotional feelings about the loss of her City life on hold while she and her little dog travel along a very dangerous and, at times, murderous Yellow Brick Road.

    She learns about how the Wizard was not the first King of Oz, and how his taking the throne put evil forces into play. She may be the only hope for a bright and cheery Oz.  The story is the same as you might have read as a kid, or in school, but with much more to the story than meets the eye or the ear.

  • My name is M L Gershowitz, and I have been working in the Entertainment business since I was twelve years old, as a actor in community theatre and moved into film when I was round 17 or 18 in 1997. As a Stage Manager in couple of Off Broadway houses and in different Theatre Festivals, worked and learned from the best NYC had to offer, and then moved into Film later as a PA (Production Assistant.) and Extras Wrangler on film company's like Lion's Gate, and MGM, and North By North West. But Theatre has always been my first and one true Love and have been trying to get my name on a Broadway show since I was twelve. I have found the right creative people to help me with my Oz Musical.

  • My Company is working with Full House Productions to get my dream to the stage so that we have something that will wow the Audience, and the twelve Broadway Producers interested in the project, and the Local Producers with the Balagan theatre company, and a London Producer as well.
  • The Name Company's we have working with us are, Spotlight Fashions on the Costumes for the show, Jigsaw Renaissance as a sponsor and the Steam Punk rat heads Paul Thibault and Klay Jones who own there own building company's and have done work for film and tv and theater before.
  • I have spent my teenage life and younger life in and out of Hospitals with a heart condition, and used the World of Theater an of the Land of Oz to get through all the trials and the Heart troubles and many operations on my body. So that I had a more deep understanding of these Oz leads and who this little Orphan Dorothy Gale was, since I myself was adopted and have Great family despite them not being any blood relations. 
  • Had five readings of the NY script with the songs of the film, and the story of the book, but decided when I moved out here in the Emerald City so to speak, that this needed to be a tale by the book and bring back the appeal of the original Broadway show from 1903. We have original songs, along with songs from the 1903 musical that the public unless you are a Ozian fan have not heard or ever heard before.
  • I want to bring back what those producers took away from Baum and Tietjen when they wrote their first draft of the script trying to keep to the Book.
  • We have Colin Chaston a London Producer is interested in bringing the show to London after the fall production. If we can raise these funds than we will get a show good enough to get to London.
  • What you will help us achieve is getting the Score ready for a Orchestra, getting the already created and designed 120 Costumes made by Spotlight Fashions that you have seen our first video better and finish up what we don't have but need. Will help with getting the set and back drops created and cover helping us find and train our three Toto's for the show, along with keeping the Director and the main Composer off the treats while doing this.
  • We have a Great musical that is just itching to be seen and heard, we just need your help to get us to the point of a out of town run before moving forward towards New York City and a London run of the show.  The Everett Historic Theatre is a 110 year old theater house where Nat King Cole and other famous artist treated that stage and brought in a crowed Please help us get  us a Great Ozian run from Oct 31st till Nov 24th.

What We Need & What You Get


  • What we Need to get this Show on its feet and looking Wonderful and Sounding like a Broadway Musical is 60,000, to cover all of the areas I am about to list.
  • 1)  Finish up the Score to the show and work on it full time till August.
  • 2) Get the rest of our costumes made and designed for the show.
  • 3) Advertising for the show with adds on Buses and Graphic Novels of the back story's of the main five leads. Along with papers and magazines and posters and flyers, and pizza for our street team. 
  • 4) Covering the musicians to play in the pit.
  • 5)  Pay our actors and actress. And pay for training for our Toto's.
  •  6) And covering the company that will be making our sets and props.
  • What you will get for helping us is your name or company's name in our show bills and on our advertising, and lots of fun and Ozzy hard to find unique gifts, that will be worth money once the show gets going, but will be cool gift ideas for the holidays of family and friend who love the world of Oz and collect them.
  • If we don't reach our full goal, we will still put up the show on what we have raised, and will make it the best it can be, and who ever donated will get there gifts and their name in the show bill and on the adds if you have a Company.

The Impact

     Every one loves Great story's and better great Characters and in the case of        Musical's songs and music that brigs lots of emotions and excitement to the person seeing or hearing the show or CD they are listening to. Every One loves the Wizard of Oz cause of its story and its message  to the world. We will tell Baums story and hope to have lots of people hear his and our music.

  • This is a large show for me, but I have produced local readings and a workshop for paying audiences, and a show called Hot Babes in Toyland which I directed and acted in, its a show that I acted in in NYC Off Broadway as part of a Christmas Festival in 2003. I have been around the theatre world and the film world.
  • If you love great Theatre and Great costumes and little dogs, this show is the show to help fund from the first show that's produced. Most of the actors that will be cast will be local except for our evil wicked Witch of the West who's a Nashville singer who's just getting off a Broadway review tour and then jumps into the world of Oz. Help us put on a Great show and get some local Seattle and Everett actors and actresses seen by Broadway and London Producers.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean You can’t help:

  •  You can spread the word about us and our Indiegogo  and the show itself. Spread the world on Facebook, twitter, and get people talking about Oz.
  • You can use the Indiegogo share tools!

Will help with getting the set and back drops created and cover helping us find and train our three Toto's for the show, along with keeping the Director and the main Composer off the treats while doing this. 

We have a Great musical that is just itching to be seen and heard, we just need your help to get us to the point of a out of town run before moving forward towards New York City and a London run of the show.  The Everett Historic Theatre is a 110 year old theater house where Nat King Cole and other famous artist treated that stage and brought in a crowed Please help us get  us a Great Ozian run from Oct 31st till Nov 24th. 

What We Need & What You Get
What we Need to get this Show on its feet and looking Wonderful and Sounding like a Broadway Musical is 60,000, to cover all of the areas I am about to list. 

1)  Finish up the Score to the show and work on it full time till August. 

2) Get the rest of our costumes made and designed for the show. 

3) Advertising for the show with adds on Buses and Graphic Novels of the back story's of the main five leads. Along with papers and magazines and posters and flyers, and pizza for our street team. 
4) Covering the musicians to play in the pit. 

5)  Pay our actors and actress. And pay for training for our Toto's. 

 6) And covering the company that will be making our sets and props. 

What you will get for helping us is your name or company's name in our show bills and on our advertising, and lots of fun and Ozzy hard to find unique gifts, that will be worth money once the show gets going, but will be cool gift ideas for the holidays of family and friend who love the world of Oz and collect them. 

If we don't reach our full goal, we will still put up the show on what we have raised, and will make it the best it can be, and who ever donated will get there gifts and their name in the show bill and on the adds if you have a Company. 

The Impact     Every one loves Great story's and better great Characters and in the case of        Musical's songs and music that brigs lots of emotions and excitement to the person seeing or hearing the show or CD they are listening to. Every One loves the Wizard of Oz cause of its story and its message  to the world. We will tell Baums story and hope to have lots of people hear his and our music. 
This is a large show for me, but I have produced local readings and a workshop for paying audiences, and a show called Hot Babes in Toyland which I directed and acted in, its a show that I acted in in NYC Off Broadway as part of a Christmas Festival in 2003. I have been around the theatre world and the film world. 

If you love great Theatre and Great costumes and little dogs, this show is the show to help fund from the first show that's produced. Most of the actors that will be cast will be local except for our evil wicked Witch of the West who's a Nashville singer who's just getting off a Broadway review tour and then jumps into the world of Oz. Help us put on a Great show and get some local Seattle and Everett actors and actresses seen by Broadway and London Producers. 

Other Ways You Can HelpSome people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean You can’t help:
 You can spread the word about us and our Indiegogo  and the show itself. Spread the world on Facebook, twitter, and get people talking about Oz. 

You can use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
If you go back a year ago, can you believe where you are? 3 years. 5 years. A decade. Two decades. Can you believe where you are? What an imposing and brilliant sound, The ticking of the Hand. What lethally beautiful control It has at its Command.

Built from and inspired by a series of 365 poems written daily for a year, THE GOLDEN DRUM YEAR celebrates the collection of everyday moments that shape our lives. This is a multi-sensory theatrical experience, combining poetry, prose, moving image and music to re-create the series of daily events that comprise a year in the life of people who live in New York City. 

The story follows Eugene, but everyone calls him Eu. We witness Eu’s world unfold and swirl around him while he grasps for meaning and purpose through a year of his life in a world of new places and new faces.  

THE GOLDEN DRUM YEAR was collaboratively created with an ensemble of performers, designers and a director working with the co-creators to use the poems as building blocks for this experience. After three years of creative development, we are thrilled to be presenting this world-premiere production.

We have assembled an extraordinarily talented, multiethnic cast and production team to realize this production. 

But we can’t do it alone. As a company that holds ourselves and our collaborators to the highest artistic and professional standard,we believe in:

  • Equitable and responsible fees for our artists
  • Access for audiences of all cultural and economic backgrounds
  • A community of supporters to make our mission possible

We hope you’ll join the community of extraordinary individuals who have already come together to make this piece a reality and contribute to this campaign!

About Radical Evolution:

Beto O’Byrne and Meropi Peponides co-founded Radical Evolution in 2011, to create high-quality theatre that examines the multiethnic experience and our role in the world as 21st Century Citizens. We produce live events across the spectrum of artistic disciplines, with a focus on collaboratively created theatre and performance.

Radical Evolution is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Radical Evolution must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
Short Summary

d'shire dance collective was founded in San Diego, CA in 2007, by Deven P Brawley. In 2014, ddc has made roots in it's new home in the Mid-West. The company creates repertory which draws on life experiences and the culture that surrounds us. From these life experiences; Brawley, has developed a repertory of work that ranges from explosive and passionate to intimate and restrained.

Deven P Brawley and d'shire dance collective are thrilled to have been invited to perform at Art Lab J's -  2nd Annual Detroit Dance City Festival .

But, we need your help to get there and we have less 

than 19 days till the festival!

The Impact

The Detroit Dance City Festival is a HUGE event for d'shire dance collective. Deven is overjoyed at the opportunity to share the collective with new audiences as well as friends & family. The move to the Mid-West has been a challenge, but this begins a long line of artistic endeavors for Deven and ddc, so your support is welcomed and appreciated.

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise at least  $500 to cover the tour expenses. These costs include travel, Per Diem for the artist, Production Assistant , costumes, and housing for all four collective members. In addition, money raised will cover production fees, publicity, and production materials.

So, what exactly does that mean? Let us break it down for you.

$25 donation will cover the cost of one company members food for one day. Help Dennis Davis get a nice chicken sandwich! 

$50 donation will costume company member, Derrick Oldenkamp, for all performances. Ensure that Derrick does not have to dance naked!

$200 donation will cover the cost of company members safe and comfortable sleeping quarters for 2 nights in Downtown Detroit. Help the collective sleep tight!

  • Why: This is a rare opportunity which will challenge me as a choreographer, help my work and all these incredible dancers gain exposure and hopefully lead to future artistic endeavors.  I have been a choreographer for as long as I can remember and have long aspired to have my collective reach new audiences. This festival seems to be a natural progression towards that goal.
  • Who: The dancers comprising d'shire dance collective are all phenomenal Michigan-based artists.  
    ddc 2014-2015 Season artist: 
    Deven P Brawley - Artistic Director
    Dennis Davis - Dance Artist
    Derrick Oldenkamp - Dance Artist
    James Heiser - Collective Production Assistant
  • WORKS TO BE PERFORMED: 

The Bullet with the Butterfly Wings 
Debut- Believe Benefit 2014

Interconnection
Debut- Midwest Regional Alternative Dance Festival 2013

About DDCF

ARTLAB J is pleased to present the 2nd Annual Detroit Dance City Festival (DDCF) in downtown Detroit. The mission of Detroit Dance City Festival is to educate audiences about the impact of dance, provide opportunities for artists to share their work, and create artistic networks between Michigan, Chicago, the United States and the world. The Detroit Dance City Festival will showcase the work of over 40 local and national performing artists and companies.

The Detroit Dance City Festival (DDCF) and South Korean based Gwang Jin International Summer Dance Festival (GSDF) has created a new international exchange initiative in order to cultivate cross-cultural artistic experiences and continue developing Detroit as a global epicenter for dance. One choreographer presenting work at this year’s Detroit Dance City Festival will be selected to present their work as a part of the GSDF in South Korea next year. This is an exciting opportunity for Michigan-based artists to connect and work with artists from around the world

The two pieces presented provide audiences the chance to see the full spectrum of Deven's unique voice as a choreographer. More excitingly, our work this season features some of Brawley's most acclaimed contemporary dance work, including Interconnection and The Bullet with the Butterfly Wings.

With over 7 years of experience producing, presenting and creating professional dance performance and workshops, we are asking YOU to help make this a BIG year for d'shire dance collective and our move to the Mid-West.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign! Share!
  • Remember, you can use the Indiegogo share tools!

See the sidebar for the unique perks you get when you participate in this exciting project!

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
Short Summary

Have you ever thought what it is like to be a bilingual, or what it is like to live in a foreign country ON YOU OWN? This brand-new play is based on a real story of a young woman who left her own country to pursuit her dream, to look for her identity, and her own definition of 'home'.

What We Need & What You Get

You contribution will cover the cost of the venue- It means a lot to me to perform this at Asian Arts Initiative (asianartinitiative.org), only one non-profit multi-disciplinary art organization specialized to Asian art community in Philly.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Come see the show!! Talk about it!!https://www.facebook.com/events/815646101782423/

story:
What:

MIAMI IS SINKING / PASTELITO GUERRERAS
By: Thomas Daníel Valls
directed by: José Rivera Jr.

Saturday, July 12th 2014 
Dixon Place, 161 Chrystie St, New York, NY 10002

Starring: 

Daniela Rivera
Adriana Santos
Cecilia Leal
Jennifer Vargas 

Production Manager: Heather Knobel
tage Manager: James M Wyrwicz
Assistant Stage Manager: Vanessa Csordas-Jenkins
Stage Design: Frankie Olivia
Costume Design: Machel Ross
Dramaturg: Heather Knobel 

A part of the Summer Hot! Festival at Dixon Place.

MIAMI IS SINKING / PASTELITO GUERRERAS tells the story of the final hour of Miami before it sinks back into the ocean, and the four best friends who have sworn a sacrificial blood bath upon each other in honor of it. 

Miami is a disaster zone. After it's been evacuated, It's declared a quarantine zone by the government. Anybody's who's stayed behind is destined to be killed in a giant ocean swell that's going to destroy all of Miami. Anybody trying to escape the city is gunned down. 

But Lupe and Jo have made a pact to profess their true love to one another on the final moments before Miami is swallowed up by the sea. Cris and Lips tag along, planning to perform a sacrificial ceremony for the whole world to witness. But not all is as it seems. 

Jo, who had since moved to New York City, made a mistake a long time ago that cost the rest of them their future. Now, Cris plans to use this ceremony as a cover to exact her revenge, and prove to Lupe that true love comes in the form of strength, and not devotion. The moment Jo returns from the big city, Cris will attempt to redeem her place in Miami, by pouring out Jo's blood.

Using pop music, dance, and butterfly knives, these four best friends fight to trump each other's love for one another, and defend their devotion to Miami, and the idea that any other city, especially New York, is nothing but an illusion, and a distraction from admitting what home truly is.

What We Need & What You Get

We need $1500 for costumes, props, set, and delivering an uncanny theater experience for members and allies of the LGBTQ community. 

$500 - Set
$500 - Paying our hardworking technicians, designers, directors, and actors. 
$300 - Props
$150 - Costumes
$50 - Publicity 

There are perks to be had, so be sure to check them out!

    The Impact

    The Dixon Place Summer Hot! Festival is a tremendous opportunity for queer artists to congregate in a beautiful space to tell stories from all corners of the city. 

    The longest running-queer theater festival in the World, HOT! serves as the model for other queer festivals across the globe and has become a performance destination for emerging talent in the LGBTQ community.  

    This year’s HOT! festival, featuring more than fifty artists, and the team for MIAMI IS SINKING is ONE of them.

    This is an INVALUABLE opportunity to share and witness community at its, well, hottest. 

      Risks & Challenges

      We are facing incredible challenges: Dixon Place is giving us ONE NIGHT ONLY to create an entire world for our audiences to become immersed in. Your donation and support will ensure that we have the funds and resources available to equip our team with the materials needed to build a Sinking Miami as swiftly as possible. 

        Other Ways You Can Help

        Spread the word. Share our videos. COME support Miami Is Sinking / Pastelito Guerreras when it is presented at Dixon Place and be sure to check out the tremendous line up at Dixon Place for this year's Summer Hot! Festival!

Festival!

story:
Alexander Academy is a donation-based dance studio and performing company that offers quality instruction to the Maui community. Our outstanding instructors, all who have danced professionally on the mainland, share their expertise and passion for their art form with more than 250 students.

Coming from diverse social, cultural, economic and professional backgrounds, our students find common ground at the Academy. They range in age from three to seventy and come from all over the island to learn in a friendly 'ohana (family) atmosphere. Generations of dancers have passed through the same studio doors, sharing the art of dance from one family member to the next.

Since 2009 under the direction of Danelle Watson, Alexander Academy has self-produced a full-length show, providing its students a complete dance experience from the ballet barre to the stage.

What We Need

As a donation-based company, we never turn away a dancer who wishes to participate but lacks the funds to do so. The only requirement for performing in our full-length productions is showing up at the audition and making a commitment to the performance season.

Unfortunately, our belief system does not change the fact that dance is an expensive art form, and this is especially true when putting on a full-length dance show for over 150 dancers!

Each performer pays a performance fee to participate in our annual production, but these fees barely cover the real cost of their costumes, let alone the four months of rehearsals, theater rental, necessary props, and other production costs that the Academy incurs in preparation for the show.

This Indiegogo campaign is a new addition to the many fundraisers we hold each year to cover our production costs, and we are hoping to raise an additional $3000 to cover the remaining expenses of 2014’s Swan Lake. 

If we raise more than our goal, the leftover money will fund:

  • our week-long summer camps and intensives
  • new guest teacher workshops 
  • a new student choreography class and a subsequent performance to share our students' creations 

All these programs follow our donation-based policy, so trust that your contribution is helping make the art of dance affordable for someone who otherwise would be financially barred from participating.

The Impact

No dancer’s training is complete without the opportunity to share their talent and skill onstage. A community audience legitimizes and gives purpose to the training our dancers have worked so hard to achieve. 

These annual productions benefit our dancers in more ways than just getting a pretty tutu and a photo opportunity. Fifteen-year-old Hanna Claerbout began dancing a mere five years ago at the Academy. In that time frame, she has grown from a beginner ballet dancer to having completed a summer intensive at the prestigious Kirov Academy in Washington D.C., and earning the top solo role for Swan Lake. “I was shy and lacked confidence before attending classes at the Academy", Hanna says, " having performing opportunities has brought out something in me that I never knew existed. I love to share my passion with others, it’s one of the greatest feelings.”

Tatiana Camit, a previous student now enrolled in a dance program in New York City, says,“The Academy very quickly became a second home for me and dance became my life. Students are very friendly, close, and welcoming, characteristics not commonly found in the dance world. The Academy offered me a fun, encouraging, and positive learning environment that helped my dancing progress quickly”.

Mother of Hanna and fellow dance student Yasuko Claerbout:

“Not only do parents get to share an incredible experience with their children, but the children see their parents in a new light, working hard towards a goal.  Also, when parents are dancing side by side with other people's children as well as their own, the community of support is deepened. So rather than competing with each other, Alexander Academy parents support one another’s children.”

Sophomore Olivia Gomez, who has danced with the Academy for four years says, “Without the teachers’ knowledge and encouragement, I definitely wouldn't be the person I am today. I’m starting to plan my future [and] because of Alexander Academy, I know I can make it far in the dance world because they’ve taught me, no matter what you look like, where you’re from, or what type of dancer you are, there is a place for you in the world of dance.”

Other Ways You Can Help

Alexander Academy values a person’s time, energy, and resources as much as any financial contribution an individual can make. If you are unable to donate at this time, we would be just as appreciative of you sharing your brain, brawn, and networking resources with us to help our studio grow. Please share our campaign with your friends, family, coworkers, strangers at the coffee shop, whomever!

We are always on the lookout for folks with specialty skills to help us maintain our aging studio building, whether it be carpentry work, landscaping, cleaning, etc. Our volunteer and work-trade opportunities are listed on alexanderacademy.info and if you have something to share with us, please holler!

Much mahalo for reading this and for supporting our dancing ‘ohana in whatever way is possible for you.

So rather than competing with each other, Alexander Academy parents support one another’s children.”
Sophomore Olivia Gomez, who has danced with the Academy for four years says, “Without the teachers’ knowledge and encouragement, I definitely wouldn't be the person I am today. I’m starting to plan my future [and] because of Alexander Academy, I know I can make it far in the dance world because they’ve taught me, no matter what you look like, where you’re from, or what type of dancer you are, there is a place for you in the world of dance.”Other Ways You Can HelpAlexander Academy values a person’s time, energy, and resources as much as any financial contribution an individual can make. If you are unable to donate at this time, we would be just as appreciative of you sharing your brain, brawn, and networking resources with us to help our studio grow. Please share our campaign with your friends, family, coworkers, strangers at the coffee shop, whomever!
We are always on the lookout for folks with specialty skills to help us maintain our aging studio building, whether it be carpentry work, landscaping, cleaning, etc. Our volunteer and work-trade opportunities are listed on alexanderacademy.info and if you have something to share with us, please holler!
Much mahalo for reading this and for supporting our dancing ‘ohana in whatever way is possible for you.

story:
Hello, I'm Greg Mackender, the resident composer for Kansas City's own Heart of America Shakespeare Festival.  This year's production of The Winter's Tale marks my 22nd season with the Festival (yes, I've been in the park every summer since the first production!).  Every year I've written and recorded original music for the Festival, but this season I'd like to add a new level of challenge and creativity: live performance of the music.  Over the years I've engaged many of the best performers in Kansas City to record my music for the production, and this year I hope to have some of these musicians join me in playing the music live during the performance. We're very excited about bringing this new element to our stage, harkening back to Shakespeare's time when music could only be played live.

Adding live music comes at a price, however, and we need your help.  We're attempting to raise $10,000 from private and corporate contributors, and from the many fans of the festival such as yourself who attend year after year.  All donations from this campaign go directly to  the Heart of America Shakespeare Festival, to an account earmarked to support the 'Live Music' project. HASF has 501(c) 3 non-profit status, so you are entitled to the tax deductions that entails.  The largest expense is the salaries of the musicians, hired for the period of time from the beginning of the rehearsal process through the run of the show.  Additional expenses will be sound and communication rental purchases, and costuming.

Pictured above are two longtime festival collaborators, Sascha Groschang/ Cello, and Laurel Parks/violin, along with myself in the studio.  They perform together as a duo known as 'The Wires'.  Check out the video below to view and hear some of the music from past festivals: 


I invite you to check out the many perks available to our donors!  All donors will have access to The Winter's Tale music production website.  This is a private site that I create, prior to the show's opening, to enable the Director and other Designers to see my research and preliminary work, and for Actors to use in rehearsal.  Once the show opens, the site becomes public and has a page for downloading music from the show.  This year it will also have a contributors page, where donors to this fund can be listed. The site will go up in March, and you will be able to follow the creative process as first drafts of music cues begin to appear for different scenes.  And yes, there will be a comments page, and I welcome your input.  Check out the other perks that come with different donation levels.

As always, the Festival remains free to the public, but of course we depend greatly on our many fans to contribute at whatever level they're able.  If you can't contribute at this time, share this site freely with anyone who you think might be interested, and by all means come out this summer and enjoy the show!  Be sure and visit the Heart of America Shakespeare Festival website for more details on performance dates: http://www.kcshakes.org

story:
SPECIAL SALES:

25 & Under: 3 Tickets / $25 each - $85

60 & Over: 2 Tickets / $30 each - $65

(includes taxes and fees)


HOLIDAY SPECIALS (Starting Memorial Day weekend):

Get  1  General  Admission  Seat  for  $38!

Get  2  General  Admission  Seats  for  $72!

Get  3  General  Admission  Seats  for  $99!


#BBoyBluesThePlay / #BBBintheATL / #PooquieNLittleBit

Executive Producer * Frank Gatson, Jr.
Co-Producer * HIPAtlanta
Producer * Creative Ammo, Inc.
Director * Stanley Bennett Clay


THE DATE: August 2, 2014
THE TIME: 8:30 p.m.
THE PLACE: Balzer Theater @ Herren's - 84 Luckie Street NW - Atlanta, GA
HOSTED BY: Lonnell Williams of 3LWTV

THE HISTORY

B-Boy Blues * The Play made its debut as the closing show during the Downtown Urban Theater Festival (DUTF) in New York in March of last year. Tickets sold out in three days, nearly a month before the Festival began—the first time this happened in the Festival's eleven-year history. The play went on to win the DUTF's Audience Award.

Because of popular demand, the DUTF brought the show back for their Encore series in early June—and those three Equity showcases also sold out months before the performance dates. And the third time was definitely the charm for the show's DC premiere at Howard University's 300-plus seat Ira Aldridge Theater: the show become only the second in the DC Black Theatre Festival's history to sell out, and the first to do it online. But once wasn't enough for DC: calls to bring the show back were answered by Al Sura, Inc., which co-produced the sold out encore at the Heritage Center in October.

And the bitter vortex temps and threat of snow didn't stop Philly from showing us a lot of brotherly (and sisterly) love and giving us another nearly sold out performance at the Painted Bride Art Center in February (and on a Tuesday night)!



IT'S ALL ABOUT YOU!

The B-Boy Blues * The Play web home has been flooded with requests (well, more like demands!) for us to come to the ATL for over a year—and, now, you have the power to make it happen! Your contribution will help cover round trip airfare from New York, lodging, and salaries for a company of 13; theater rental, insurance, and labor costs; rehearsal studio booking; production fees and taxes; and miscellaneous items (gotta feed the actors!).

You don't have to live in the ATL to support; fans across the country and abroad who pledge will receive joodies like the premiere eBook version of B-Boy Blues or its 20th anniversary edition. 

Those that wish to purchase seats for the August 2nd show have a few options: 

- First/Second/Third Row Premium Seats or a Special Guest/VIP Package, which can also come with admission to the Official After-Party, a complimentary producer credit, an autographed book, and a behind-the-scenes look at how Raheim & Mitchell's story is brought to life

- Pooquie's Ten-Pack - 10% off 10 tickets / Pooquie's Twenty-Pack - 20% off 20 tickets (if you are interested in purchasing a block of more than 20 tickets, send your inquiry to james.earl.hardy@gmail.com)

- Holiday Special, beginning Memorial Day weekend: 1 General Admission Seat/$38, 2 General Admission Seats/$72, 3 General Admission Seats/$99

- The 25 & Under Special: A 3-Pack of $25 tickets for attendees 25 and under ($85)

- The 60 & Over Special: Two General Admission Seats for attendees 60 and over ($65)

[NOTE: Taxes/fees are included in quoted prices, and tickets will be waiting at the box office the evening of the performance under the payee's name.]

And for Pooquie & Little Bit's #1 fans, there is the Ultimate BBB Gift Pack: a Thank You in the Playbill, an appreciation phone call from me, collectible B-Boy Blues postcards and bookmarks, a rare BBB series t-shirt, a BBB Play cast poster, and a new, out-of-print, first edition autographed copy of the novel, all for just $200!

With folks as close as Memphis, Nashville, and Birmingham (and as far as Boston, Chicago, Detroit, Oakland, and L.A.) planning to make the trek, don't wait until the last minute—GET YOUR TICKETS NOW!

Your unyielding devotion to Pooquie & Little Bit will open the door for us to visit other cities, bringing us closer to an off-Broadway/Broadway run and, eventually, B-Boy Blues * The Film. So join the BBB Movement and be a part of history!


THE SYNOPSIS

Opposites do attract. Take Mitchell Crawford, a 30-year-old Ivy-League educated editor of Your World, a newsmagazine for high school students, and Raheim Rivers, a 23-year-old homeboy from Harlem and high school dropout who is a messenger. When Middle Class Boy meets Working Class Boi, the attraction is palpable and explosive. For Mitchell, Raheim is the lean, mean love machine of his dreams, while Mitchell is the willing and convenient compact cutie Raheim can have anytime he wants (and does).

Their lust affair does have some bumps in the road: they clash over using "nigga" as a term of endearment and Raheim's possessive nature, while Mitchell's snobbish, sarcastic best friend, Eugene "Gene" Roberts, and Raheim's child 'hood homie, Derrick "D.C." Carter, pressure them to end it. But, it's clear to Gene, D.C. and everyone else in their circles—Michelle "Michi" Snipes, Your World's receptionist; Barry "B.D." Daniels, Mitchell's ditzy yet delightful BFF; Angel Cortez, Raheim's other homie; and Mrs. Rivers, Raheim's mom—that there's much more than hookin' up going on. Which is why no one is more surprised than they are when they fall in love.


CONGRATS TO B-BOY BLUES * THE PLAY ON BEING NAMED THE OUTSTANDING NATIONAL ARTISTIC EXPRESSION PROJECT OF 2013 BY PRIDEINDEX OF CHICAGO!



B-BOY BLUES: The Novel
* released in November 1994 by Alyson Publications
* praised as "the first gay hip hop love story" by E. Lynn Harris
* 1995 Lammy Finalist (Best Small Press Title)
* prominently featured in Spike Lee's Get on the Bus
* passed the 100,000 sales mark in 2000
* will be reissued in a 20th Anniversary Collector's Edition in November 2014



* Check out the mini-doc shot by original cast member/comedian Sampson McCormick (aka "B.D."):

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DswENcJ0NLo


* Check out these links about BBB * The Play:

http://www.musedmagonline.com/2013/06/why-you-must-see-james-earl-hardys-b-boy-blues/

http://www.epgn.com/view/full_story/24616549/article-Gay-hip-hop-novel-comes-to-life-on-stage?instance=detour_feature_main

http://johnstoltenberg.wordpress.com/2013/06/27/b-boy-blues/


* Share the campaign with EVERYONE! 


* "LIKE" and follow us @ https://www.facebook.com/bboybluestheplay


* Email: PooquieandLilBit@aol.com

story:
Equine Dell Arte is OUT of The Starting Gate!
The only Shakespeare-on-horseback company in the world.

Inspired by Commedia Dell Arte (Italian Renaissance "Art of Comedy"), Shakespeare, and all things "horsing around", Equine Dell Arte's 1st full length production 'O! For a Horse with Wings' will take you on a whimsical wild ride!  Galloping through a montage of music, magic and mayhem actors and horses team up to bring you a performance like you've never seen before!

Equine Dell Arte is an ensemble company comprised of professional actors, students, people with disabilities and/or under-served populations, and horses (of course!) working together to empower, enlighten, and entertain in an outdoor theatrical setting.  EDA is a for profit company that donates to non-profit therapeutic entities.

EDA was conceived by Susan Kelejian and came into being in 2013.  In the past year we've held acting workshops and performed at 2 fundraiser events for the Shadow Hills Riding Club (www.ShadowHillsRidingClub.org).  The reception and popularity of those performances and workshops have lead to the demand for a full length, stand alone performance, "O, For a Horse With Wings!"

Since Equine Dell Arte began with SHRC, and we continue to work closely with them and their horses, a portion of all proceeds from the performances will go back to supporting their amazing therapeutic programs, including:
  • Saddles and Serenity (People in recovery from addictions)
  • Saddles for Soldiers (US veterans)
  • Equine Assisted Activities and Therapies (Children and adults with special needs)

WHERE DOES ALL THE MONEY GO?! -- A question I'm sure you've asked more than once!

Though we are keeping productions costs low, we are performing in a horse arena, so we still have some basic expenses:

  • $4,000 - 8 Horses for 2 months (horse use from ranch, basic equipment, fly spray, ranch, supplements, hoof care, special feed and veterinary supplies etc)
  • $1,000 - Lights
  • $1,000 - Costumes (materials to make for 30 actors AND horses!)
  • $500 - Set Design/Props (Weapons, saloon doors, etc. )
  • $250 - Marketing  (flyers, postcards)
  • $5,000 - Production Staff (3 months split between: Artistic Director, Director, Asst. Director, Producers, Stage Manager, Music Director, Asst. Stage Manager, Costumer, Lighting Designer, Stage Combat Choreographer, Horse Instructors)

(We realize that the budget items exceed the asking amount listed for this campaign, and are optimistically hoping that along with the ticket sales, we can meet our actual budgetary goal of $11,750.00.)

All funds raised by this IndieGoGo will go towards the production of "O, For a Horse With Wings." 30% of the proceeds from performances in September will go towards Shadow Hills Riding Club Therapy programs, while 70% goes back into Equine Dell Arte for further productions.


What do you get aside from a darn good show?

  • You get to support the only Shakespeare on horseback company in the world (at least that we have found!).
  • You will receive undying love and public thanks in programs and shout outs before shows
  • Original and creative souvenirs from our production, depending on your level of sponsorship.

Other ways to help!

First and foremost, spread the word!  Please like our Facebook page and share this campaign to help us reach as many people as possible.

If you are local to the Los Angeles area, we can always use volunteers to help with ushering, ticket sales, and concessions. Get in touch!

And, of course, please come see the show in September!

A few of the remarkably talented, spirited actors in our Company:

.

. .

story:
Who are we and what are we doing?

Funny you should ask...

  • We are Slightly Altered States, a not-for-profit theater company made up of actors, writers, and improvisers. We are devoted to darkly funny, slightly-absurd material that deals truthfully with the extraordinary in everyday circumstances.  Nobody’s making any kind of money here, this is all a labor of love, so we believe firmly it should be a wonderful, respectful, and fulfilling experience for all those involved: our wonderful team and audience alike.

  • Our dream of producing Mr Landing Takes A Fall seemed impossible three years ago, let alone seven when the first version of the play was written!  Now it is actually going up at the Flea! Our theater company is three years old, with critically-acclaimed, sold out, and published productions behind us, and we are finally ready to present our dream show. We have the play, we have the space, but we can't do it without YOU! 

  • YOU would be a vital part of making this project a reality in this moment of imminent need. We are in the midst of previews and rehearsals and we open in less than a week, and it would mean the world to us if you could help us meet our goal in time, and be a part of our wonderful, joyous, work-to-the-bone team!
 
Your help will go toward:
  • Theater rental
  • Set materials
  • Design Team
  • Printing materials
  • Hospitality
  • Clean-up and move out

Perks:
  • Signed Posters
  • T-shirts
  • Credit on web
  • Credit in program
  • Tickets
  • Whiskey
  • Our eternal gratitude
  • If we hit our goal, Sari and Dave will take pies to the face and upload the video
  • Did we say whiskey?

If we do not reach our goal, your help will go to:
  • Theater rental
  • Set costs
  • Anything and everything else

Why this matters:

Help keep us from going down the paths of monstrosity and depravity!


  • We are committed to keeping alive old school New York theater.
  • We put up shows in which quality transcends budget.  This show in particular we decided that we would treat it as Off Broadway even though we are limited to only 16 performances by the Showcase Code.  
  • Since forming in 2011, we have put on productions to sold out houses and critical acclaim.  This time we are taking a big leap both artistically and financially...

Challenges

Artistic endeavors are inherently risky, especially in Off-Off Broadway theater.  In a way, this project is (hopefully) just the first stage of a labor of love.

  • We have made it our mission to put on an Off Broadway caliber show even though we are only on a showcase code.  This means first and foremost, that it is expensive.  Projects like this are only possible with the help of a great team and community, and so we rely on you to help us to the finish line.
  • We are so close to opening.  We have had a whirlwind process of rehearsals and previews.  Everyone has been putting in so many hours and getting so little sleep to make the best possible show.  Even with so much hard work by such competent people, we still need your help to bring it all together!

Not All About the Benjamins

  • If you can't donate, do not worry!  Please come see the show, spread the word, shout it from the rooftops, whatever you're comfortable with.

theater company made up of actors, writers, and improvisers. We are devoted to
darkly funny, slightly-absurd material that deals truthfully with the
extraordinary in everyday circumstances.  Nobody’s making any kind of
money here, this is all a labor of love, so we believe firmly it should be a
wonderful, respectful, and fulfilling experience for all those involved: our wonderful team and audience alike.

Our dream of producing Mr Landing Takes A Fall seemed impossible three years ago, let alone seven when the first version of the play was written!  Now it is actually going up at the Flea! Our theater company is three
years old, with critically-acclaimed, sold out, and published productions
behind us, and we are finally ready to present our dream show. We have the play, we have the space, but we can't
do it without YOU! 


YOU would be a vital part of making this project a
reality in this moment of imminent need. We are in the midst of previews and rehearsals and we open in less than a week, and it would mean the world to us if you could help us meet our goal in
time, and be a part of our wonderful, joyous, work-to-the-bone team!
 
 Your help will go toward:
Theater rental
Set materials
Design Team
Printing materials
Hospitality
Clean-up and move out

Perks:


Signed Posters
T-shirts
Credit on web
Credit in program
Tickets
Whiskey
Our eternal gratitude
If we hit our goal, Sari and Dave will take pies to the face and upload the video
Did we say whiskey?

If we do not reach our goal, your help will go to:
Theater rental
Set costs
Anything and everything else 
  Why this matters: Help keep us from going down the paths of monstrosity and depravity!



We are committed to keeping alive old school New York theater.
We put up shows in which quality transcends budget.  This show in particular we decided that we would treat it as Off Broadway even though we are limited to only 16 performances by the Showcase Code.   Since forming in 2011, we have put on productions to sold out houses and critical acclaim.  This time we are taking a big leap both artistically and financially... 
  Challenges Artistic endeavors are inherently risky, especially in Off-Off Broadway theater.  In a way, this project is (hopefully) just the first stage of a labor of love. 
We have made it our mission to put on an Off Broadway caliber show even though we are only on a showcase code.  This means first and foremost, that it is expensive.  Projects like this are only possible with the help of a great team and community, and so we rely on you to help us to the finish line.
We are so close to opening.  We have had a whirlwind process of rehearsals and previews.  Everyone has been putting in so many hours and getting so little sleep to make the best possible show.  Even with so much hard work by such competent people, we still need your help to bring it all together! 
  Not All About the Benjamins If you can't donate, do not worry!  Please come see the show, spread the word, shout it from the rooftops, whatever you're comfortable with.

story:
Update: Now offering T-SHIRTS!!!

These bad boys are LIMITED EDITION, meaning ONLY AVAILABLE THROUGH THE INDIEGOGO CAMPAIGN with a donation of $30 or more!!!!!!! They WILL NOT be available after the campaign ends!!!!!!!

We are also offering VIP TICKETS to our October 13 burlesque fundraiser at the Brick in Williamsburg, Love Machines and Rude Mechanicals: An Evening of Robot Burlesque. 


(photo by Tilly May)

VIP tickets include reserved seating, a goodie bag, and *possibly* a lap dance if you're well-behaved. These are available with a $30 donation!!!
Less than two weeks to go, guys! Thank you for everything!!!
-------------------------------------------------

Sex With Robots?

Hi! Mariah and Danny here, co-curators of the Sex With Robots Festival, presented by Caps Lock Theatre. What is the Sex With Robots Festival, you might ask? It's a series of short plays about sex with robots! We've got a formidable group of playwrights assembled to write these here plays, and they are: Mac Rogers, Natalie Zutter, Richard Lovejoy & Eric Meyer, Micheline Auger, J. Julian Christopher, Leah Nanako Winkler, and us...Danny Bowes and Mariah MacCarthy--plus a song by Nat Cassidy. I know, right? You're totally salivating right now. And not just because you're thinking about sex with robots.

It's happening November 5-10, 2013 at the Secret Theatre in Long Island City. And it's going to cost some dollars!

Here's what we need money for...

$2,000 for performance space rental

$800 for rehearsal space, props, and costumes ($100 per play)

$200 for postcard printing

$2,000 to pay the artists: So often, in festivals like these, artists work for free, even though it ends up being a crapload of work. We say BOO to that--especially since these plays are gonna be all kindsa steamy, and our performers very well might be baring more than just their souls. We're anticipating having AT LEAST 20 artists involved. Anything we make above and beyond our goal will go to the artists.

What you get in exchange for your money:

We will perform part or all of ANY SONG YOU REQUEST and put it on the Internet!

Let me clarify what I mean by "perform": We might sing it. We might perform it as a dramatic monologue. We might dance to it. We might make teddy bears dance to it. YOU DON'T KNOW WHAT WE'RE GONNA DO. We did one of these last year for The Foreplay Play, if you're curious as to what kinds of performances we might be doing.

Any donation of any amount gets a "thank you!" on Facebook and twitter. Every little bit counts! Seriously, a dollar helps. One dollar.

$5 gets you a haiku.

$10 means Mariah performs your haiku on video.

$15 gets you up to 30 seconds of the song of your choosing.

$25 gets you up to a minute.

$55 gets you the whole song.

$75 gets you the whole song PLUS A COMP TICKET TO THE FESTIVAL!

$100 gets you an ORIGINAL RAP by Mariah, plus TWO comps!

Etc.

Once you've donated, email capslocktheatre@gmail.com to request your song! Or, leave it in the comments on this Indiegogo page (not on social media, we might not see it there). We'll endeavor to record and send your video as quickly as possible, though if we go all-out it might take a bit longer!

These are the people performing songs on video for you:

Me (Mariah MacCarthy):

I'm not much of a singer, but I can rap like a boss, and sometimes dance around to Katy Perry in sunglasses. I also believe in glitter.

 

Danny Bowes (co-curator, awesome human):

Danny will do whatever you tell him to.

 

Sex with Robots/Pussyfest playwright Micheline Auger:

I'm not sure what Micheline is willing to do on video but I have a feeling I'm about to find out.

 

Sex with Robots playwright Natalie Zutter:

Natalie said doing a video for this sounded "kinda thrilling." Hold us, kiss us, thrill us, Natalie. We're yours.

 

Elizabeth Seldin, who you may recognize from Mrs. Mayfield's Fifth-Grade Class of '93 20-Year Reunion and the latest Pussyfest:

E-Sel sings, raps, plays accordion, and is generally a beast.

 

Emily Rupp, who you've seen at "Naked People Are Magic" and both Pussyfests as a performer and "Ukelady":

She sings, plays guitar, plays ukulele, plays flute...OK never mind, there is nothing E-Rupp does NOT do (pardon the double negative).

 

Diana Oh, of Magic Trick, The Foreplay Play, "Naked People Are Magic," a Ukelady of Pussyfest...basically she's a permanent fixture of Caps Lock:

She sings, plays ukulele and broken guitars, and dances around dressed like a cat.

 

Jody Christopherson, who brought The Vagina Choir to the latest Pussyfest, with her co-conspirator Michael de Roos:

Jody sings and composes/arranges music, performs in Greencard Wedding, and is bringing lioness realness to this photograph. Michael de Roos is the other half of Greencard Wedding. This is Michael, looking upsettingly handsome:

 

Lindsey Austen, of The Foreplay Play, Mrs. Mayfield's Fifth-Grade Class of '93 20-Year Reunion, the last Pussyfest, and our stage kitten in Magic Trick:

Lindsey sings and whistles and is really cute when she dances. 

 

Catherine Lefrere, who taught us about chicken sexing at the last Pussyfest:

She sings, she dances, she's excellent at staring wistfully into the sky on rooftops.

 

So there you have it, folks! Your Robot Sex song-and-dance team! Whenever there are new videos, we'll share them on Facebook and twitter, and we'll put a few here in the "Updates" as well (but not all of them - we don't want to bombard your inboxes). Make sure you're following us on all the social medias to keep up!

If you're unable to donate right now, there are still so many ways you can help! We encourage you to team up with a friend or four and split the cost of a song! Just have everyone donate separately and then email us at capslocktheatre@gmail.com to let us know the names of all the donors; we will make your wildest karaoke dreams come true.

Can't donate at this time? Feel free to share the campaign via facebook, twitter, email, carrier pigeon, smoke signal, interpretive dance, or however your little heart desires. We are also very open to GUEST ARTISTS! If you want to sing or shake your booty with us on video, email capslocktheatre@gmail.com to get involved!

Love and sex robots,
Mariah MacCarthy, Caps Lock, and the Sex With Robots Team

story:
A show that's part zombie horror, part comedy, and part Shakespeare's Henry V! 

WHO:  hiSTORYstage (www.historystage.org), the stage performance company of Historic Interpretations, Inc. (www.historicinterpretations.org). 

WHAT:  William Shakespeare's Land of the Dead, an award-winning new script by John Heimbuch, makes its North Carolina debut with our production!

WHERE & WHEN:  Common Ground Theatre (www.cgtheatre.com) in Durham October 10-13, and Burning Coal Theatre at the Murphey School (www.burningcoal.org) in Raleigh October 24-27.

HOW:  Only with YOUR help!

WHY:  Our goal with this production is to meld entertainment with history to create an unforgettable event which will not only entertain, but sneak a little eduction in on the side.  

LONDON, 1599

Shakespeare's Henry V opens at the new Globe Playhouse, but while the actors strut and fret, an excess of bile plagues the populace outside.

After the opening of his newest play, William Shakespeare must once again defend his work - fending off the embittered clown, Will Kemp, while trying to appease Francis Bacon, a wealthy lawyer who has come with an idea to pitch.  But when the company's costumer is bitten by a plague-ridden madman, and then Queen Elizabeth and her men arrive seeking safety, life in the playhouse takes a turn for the worse.

As the affliction spreads through London, the Globe is placed in quarantine and the survivors must fight for their lives.  Can they escape?  Is there a cure?  Is artistic integrity ever worth dying for?

"John Heimbuch's script is witty, clever, peppered with self-referential humor and wonderful wordplay on some of the Bard's best lines." - Brian Leehan, Minneapolis Star Tribune

"Both Shakespeare and horror nerds will enjoy this brilliant Elizabethan production of bloody proportions, taking zombies into new and exciting terrain."  - Brian Smith, Fangoria Magazine

This event can only be a success with YOUR support. 

Your contribution will help to cover the costs of production, including props, sets, make-up, costumes, and buckets of stage blood - as well as the rental of equipment for special effects!

We have a wide variety of rewards and perks available to our contributors.  We don't just want you to contribute - we want you to become part of our community and this production!  Join us to make theatre magic happen!

So, treat yourself to a show which will make you laugh, startle you, and entertain you in the spirit of the Halloween season.  You may just learn a little about Shakespeare's England at the same time - if you can avoid the bite of the Afflicted.

Everyone who gives at least $18 will receive a ticket to a performance.  Because seating at each performance is limited, we will contact you to reserve the performance of your choice as quickly as possible.  You might want to have a back-up in case one particular show is full - tickets are already selling!  Getting your tickets through Indiegogo saves you the service charge of our ticket broker, Brown Paper Tickets (www.brownpapertickets.com)

IF YOU WANT MORE THAN ONE TICKET, simply contribute any multiple of $18 and select the $18 (BITER) Reward.  You'll get that number of tickets.  Or, get four tickets for $15 each with the $60 (OUTBREAK) Reward.  Higher contribution levels allow you to receive other gifts, such as t-shirts, zombie make-overs, promotional consideration, and tickets to our Mardi Gras Masquerade Ball and Banquet on March 1, 2014.

Our T-Shirt Design

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Spread the word by sharing our campaign on Twitter, Facebook, and Google Plus using the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Volunteer to be an usher, part of our street team to put up posters, or hand out flyers at coming events

story:
Last summer I had the pleasure of seeing Nicked and Dimed at the Hudson Theater in Hollywood. Playing a number of roles newcomer Jackie Joniec startled me with her skill, natural facility onstage and obvious talent. I've known Jackie for a while as a wonderful chef, and a successful entrepreneur - she's the owner of the very successful Body Builder's Gym in Silverlake - but not as an actress. Her performance was a revelation.

Also plying her craft in Nicked And Dimed was veteran actress Kathleen Ingle. She was, as she always is, outstanding.


In a flash I thought 'these two need to do 'night Mother.' A play more or less lodged in my mind as belonging to Kathy Bates and Anne Pitoniak, who I saw do it at the Mark Taper Forum in the 19....uh... let's just say it was BTI (before the internet) and no one named Bush had been President yet. 

We got together and read the play and I knew my instinct was not only true, but that Jackie and Kathleen would forever dislodge Anne and Kathy in my mind. 

I'll be honest - we tried to mount 'night Mother last fall on a tiny budget. It was clear this was a disservice to the layered work both actresses were bringing to rehearsal and the play itself. We needed a full production. So we decided to "reboot", raise the money, and do it the right way. A way that honors Norman's sublime, startling masterpiece and both the skilled talented actors. 

The money raised will be used in a straightforward manner - nothing hidden here:

  1. Theater rental. We want a good 99 seat space in the Silverlake, Atwater, Los Feliz area...but are certainly open to other areas if the space is right. 
  2. Props and sets: If you know the play you know it is prop heavy and certain elements of the set are essential (one door in particular).
  3. Publicity, p.r., also publicity and p.r. We want and expect to have butts in seats. Getting the word out will matter. 
  4. Fees for a designer and stage manager. Very good designers and stage managers can be gotten in L.A. for stunningly reasonable prices. We shall do this. We need the money to do this. 
  5. Rights. Gotta pay the writer after all. 


Why this matters? Our production will bring together 2 fine actresses in roles, quite frankly, they were born to play.And it is community theater in the truest and best sense.  Be a part of it. Give what you can today.

story:
What Is This?

An independently produced Equity Approved Showcase of Paula Vogel's How I Learned To Drive is being presented at Theatre 54 @ Shetler Studios in New York City on October 11th through 13th. This show is being made possible by the determination and creativity of theatre artists from different experiences and disciplines coming together to bring this show to life.

This is not a comissioned revival, and this is not something where everyone involved has hundreds of thousands of dollars to spend. This is something that is being built from the ground up, beginning with almost nothing. People are doing this show because they love theatre and have a passion for storytelling in this format. Getting involved here means you are truly involved in making something special.

Who Is Involved?

The director and producer of this production is Jordan Friedman, who previously put up Proof at The Bridge Theatre, and has worked with a variety of New York City theatre companies. For this production he is producing and directing this independently without the financial assistance of another company. In addition, actors, designers and other hard-working production staff will come together, and all of them will benefit greatly from your assistance.

Cast:
Lil' Bit: *Crawford M. Collins
Uncle Peck: David M. Farrington
Female Greek Chorus: Mary McNulty
Male Greek Chorus: Stephen Powell
Female Greek Chorus: *Hannah Dubner

*Appearing courtesy of Actors Equity Association.

Staff:
Director: Jordan Friedman
Scenic Designer: Young Juang
Lighting Designer: Mitch Ost
Costume Designer: Johanna Pan
Sound Designer: Jake Williams

Why This Show?

How I Learned To Drive is a play with a dynamic and compelling story that takes many unconventional directions and risks with its structure, and such structure presents a complex but worthwhile challenge to stage for an audience. Plays such as this that can balance both hilarious comedy and heartbreaking tragedy give theatregoers an experience that will be remembered. In addition, this is a timeless piece that was enjoyed by audience members 20 years ago, and will be enjoyed 20 years in the future.

How Can You Help?

Donating directly to this campaign will be greatly appreciated and will ensure that every person involved in the show can do their jobs to the best of their ability. With the exception of IndieGogo's fees, all of the funds rasied through this campaign will go directly towards the various production costs of putting on independent theatre in New York City, as well as ensuring that every person who works on the production can get the compensation they deserve.

What Is The Money Being Used For?

The funds will help to offset the production costs of How I Learned To Drive. This includes:
*Renting the performance venue and rehearsal spaces.

*Providing the designers the budget they need to create the world of the play.

*Compensating everybody involved in the production as much as possible to ensure that all of their hard work gets rewarded.

*Various fees, including securing the rights, union paperwork and marketing the show.

Last Thoughts:

This production already does matter to many people, and the intent is for it to matter to many more. Anything you can provide to help this production grow and reach out is valued beyond what words can say.
