story:
We did it...and we want to keep on doing it!

With the support of our patrons and donors, people just like you, Next Iteration Theater Company (NITC) set out and completed its first professional theater season. We met our mission as we:

  • Brought under-represented voices with amazing playwrights, casts and crew:

    Playwrights (3 female, 2 male): 1 Latino; 1 African American; 1 Asian; 2 Anglo 
    Cast (10 Female, 10 male): 5 Latino; 6 African American; 4 Asian; 5 Anglo 
    Designers & Crew (4 female, 4 male): 2 Latino; 6 Anglo

  • Compensated our actors, designers, and crew

  • Joined forces with others other companies to produce ReadFest Houston, a free-to-the-public play reading festival of 6 Houston theater companies

  • Made our theater productions accessible to the diverse Houston community with pay-what-you-can tickets & ASL-interpreted shows

We want, we need to keep making accessible and diverse theater for Houston audiences.

Play your part and make your tax-deductible contribution so NITC can keep going and bring you more thought-provoking theater to Houston! Contribute today.

We will be announcing our new season in September at our Season Announcement Party, but for a sneak peak...

  • We are working to bring make the ReadFest Houston a biennial event in Houston
  • A workshop play by a playwright we already know and love in March 2017 at the Match
  • The Second Annual Intercultural Play Reading Series in May 2017 at the Match

Here's how your donation will make our work possible:

At NITC we spend the bulk of our money on paying artists. We believe that everyone deserves a living wage and we are on our way to provide that...one step at a time. Here's what we will spend your donation on:

  • Artist Compensation (actors, designers, stage managers, tech): $29,938

  •  Productions Costs including materials: $10,000

  •  Performance Venues: $10,200

  •  Audience Outreach and Marketing: $6000

  •   ASL interpreters: $3500

  •   Keeping the company going: $11,000

  •   Fundraising: $6500

This campaign is an integral part of our fundraising to ensure that we can bring our work to Houston audiences. Make your donation and become part of the village that raises NITC!

Your tax-deductible contribution* will go toward paying the artists and theater technicians who will bring this art to you!

Risks & Challenges

Raising funds for art and artists these days seems to be getting harder and harder. That's why we are crowdfunding and coming directly to you! What is society without culture and the arts? What is the voice of the people without the inspiration and questioning that happens when we come face to face with art and artists? We are searching for people who are as committed as we are to fund NITC. We would love to have you as part of our NITC village. And we want to know your story, your relationship to theater. Share it in the comment section or send us an email. But tell us! We can't do this without you. Here's what we are striving to continue to do:

  • At NITC we are tenacious. We believe passionately in what we are doing. We are cultivating audiences that want to experience our diverse voice. We are finding actors, musicians, writers and artists across the genres who want to be a part of NITC. As our community of artists grows, we will reach more of you with our work.
  • We believe in you. We believe that theater brings something unique to each audience member and each participant. Very few things allow us such a communal and at the same moment deeply personal experience. With the help of crowdfunding, good old fashion fundraising, and our tenacity we believe we can fund NITC and share our dreams with you.

Other Ways You Can Help

At NITC we can always use help in other ways. There are so many things you can do to get on board with us:

  •   Spread the word about this campaign: Email this link to those who care as much as you do, use your favorite social media channels, or the Indiegogo share tools right on this page!
  •   Buy tickets to the shows: watch our website for more information coming soon
  •   Volunteer: contact us via our website to let us know how you would like to get involved     in bringing more living, breathing, thought-provoking theater to Houston

Next Iteration Productions is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non­profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Next Iteration Productions must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only. Any contribution above the value of the goods and services received by the donor is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.
story_txt:
We did it...and we want to keep on doing it!
With the support of our patrons and donors, people just like you, Next Iteration Theater Company (NITC) set out and completed its first professional theater season. We met our mission as we:

Brought under-represented voices with amazing playwrights, casts and crew:Playwrights (3 female, 2 male): 1 Latino; 1 African American; 1 Asian; 2 Anglo Cast (10 Female, 10 male): 5 Latino; 6 African American; 4 Asian; 5 Anglo Designers & Crew (4 female, 4 male): 2 Latino; 6 Anglo

Compensated our actors, designers, and crew
Joined forces with others other companies to produce ReadFest Houston, a free-to-the-public play reading festival of 6 Houston theater companies
Made our theater productions accessible to the diverse Houston community with pay-what-you-can tickets & ASL-interpreted shows

We want, we need to keep making accessible and diverse theater for Houston audiences.
Play your part and make your tax-deductible contribution so NITC can keep going and bring you more thought-provoking theater to Houston! Contribute today.

We will be announcing our new season in September at our Season Announcement Party, but for a sneak peak...

We are working to bring make the ReadFest Houston a biennial event in Houston

A workshop play by a playwright we already know and love in March 2017 at the Match
The Second Annual Intercultural Play Reading Series in May 2017 at the Match


Here's how your donation will make our work possible:
At NITC we spend the bulk of our money on paying artists. We believe that everyone deserves a living wage and we are on our way to provide that...one step at a time. Here's what we will spend your donation on:

Artist Compensation (actors, designers, stage managers, tech): $29,938
 Productions Costs including materials: $10,000
 Performance Venues: $10,200
 Audience Outreach and Marketing: $6000
  ASL interpreters: $3500
  Keeping the company going: $11,000
  Fundraising: $6500

This campaign is an integral part of our fundraising to ensure that we can bring our work to Houston audiences. Make your donation and become part of the village that raises NITC!

We believe in you. We believe that theater brings something unique to each audience member and each participant. Very few things allow us such a communal and at the same moment deeply personal experience. With the help of crowdfunding, good old fashion fundraising, and our tenacity we believe we can fund NITC and share our dreams with you.

At NITC we can always use help in other ways. There are so many things you can do to get on board with us:

  Buy tickets to the shows: watch our website for more information coming soon

story:
Who we are, what we're doing.

No Stakes Theater Project is a fiscally-sponsored organization that supports the development of emerging theater directors through staged readings, fostered collaborations, and productions of exceptional work. In 2017, we're expanding our mission to include an initiative that supports actors.

Instead of producing a traditional theater season, we have implemented WINGSPAN - a series of staged readings designed to foster and encourage the creative risks of emerging directors. In 2017, we will mount two workshop productions. Both will be helmed by emerging directors looking to take on big artistic risks in order to grow.

Our theory is: the more we, as artists, take the initiative to step outside of our comfort zones, the better our work will be.

With your help, we can continue to provide emerging Chicago theater artists  with opportunities to grow. We want you to be a part of that!

Where is it all going?

$5,000 gets us started, covering half of our 2017 season. Your funding will pay for production rights, venue rental, rehearsal rental, and the various supplies needed to produce live theater (scripts, contracts, basically lots of paper). We will treat your money with respect, and you can rest assured that it will be used solely for the art and the artists, which ultimately benefits you!
If you look to your right, you will see all of the wonderful perks coming your way should you be so gracious as to donate to our cause. All of our perks seek to involve you in our creative process. We want each and every one of you to be a part of the work that we do.  However, perks are limited, so don't let them pass you by!
Should we not reach our goal your funding will still go directly towards our 2016/17 season. However, we have full confidence that we can meet our goal with the help of all of you! 


The Impact

We have constructed a seven-reading season to showcase emerging directors, bringing in over 50+ artists in the community, with many more to come. To accompany our season, we have created a live-lit podcast to showcase even more local artists and storytellers.

We have also partnered with a local venue in Edgewater called Uncommon Ground, which has introduced our work to over 150+ individuals who would normally not be seeing theater.

Your contributions will allow us to continue to bring the city of Chicago challenging and thought-provoking work that facilitates the continued growth and development of its burgeoning artists. It is only with your help that we can achieve this impact.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that times are hard, and that you can't always contribute financially. That's ok! There's still plenty you can do to get our campaign out into the world. Indiegogo has provided some great sharing tools on this campaign page for you!

Word of mouth also does wonders. So, tell a friend about our campaign today and we will be forever grateful!

story:
From the Playwright:

My name is Emma Stanton, I’m a playwright in the graduate program at Columbia University, and I’m delighted to introduce to you my thesis play, No Candy.

At the center of No Candy is a multi-generational community of Bosnian Muslim women who survived the Srebrenica genocide and, years later, open a gift shop for tourists who visit the Srebrenica memorial. While No Candy is very much about how trauma inhabits the body and shapes a community, it is also about the persistence of humor, art, and absurdity in an unimaginable time.

What made me want to write No Candy is that I’ve been thinking about the communities comprised solely of women, and why they are formed, how they function, and what is the presence of men, if any, if it isn’t physical. And in August 2014, when the Yazidi community came under persecution by ISIS and the women forced into sexual slavery, I began to think about the female community again, but in the context of ethnic and gendered persecution. I was reminded of the Bosnian Muslims during the Bosnian War, specifically during the Srebrenica genocide. And it was through this landscape of Bosnia that gave me access to explore this particular kind of trauma and how a community of women sustains and rebuilds itself years later after the war. While trauma functions as a baseline within the play, what I am more interested in exploring in the lives of these women is how a community rebuilds itself through humor and absurdity. In my conversations with Bosnian artist Sejla Kameric, who was a teenager during the Bosnian war, she very much insists on the duality of lightness living alongside atrocity and trauma. That during the war, there were sunny days, babies being born, theater being produced, and somewhere, some teenager was listening to Nirvana in their headphones and ignoring their parents. There’s a kind of absurdity in that duality, of living during war, and I believe in it. I believe it is at the center of these women in the play and at the core of their recovery.

We are so excited about this collaboration! What is unique about the collaboration behind NO CANDY is the creative exchange between Chicago and New York. Before I left for Columbia University’s MFA program, I was working regularly with a community of actors, designers, and directors. However, since being in New York, I’ve met some really stellar group of designers and producers. And so, I’d like to take the opportunity of my thesis to nurture my relationships in both cities and create a partnership between the two groups of collaborators! It is the hope that with this kind of collaboration, the play will have the opportunity to be seen and produced in both.

We need your help to make this production happen! Since we will be rehearsing with a phenomenal team in Chicago, we’re looking to raise $2000 to help cover the costs of bringing them to New York and performing throughout the week. Your donation will help us from buying metro card to our actor, to cover our always-expensive rehearsal space, to building our fantastic set, 
A little goes a long way and will be very much appreciated!
No Candy will be performed at The Signature Theater in New York April 28th at 2:30pm, April 30th at 7:30pm, and May 1st at 2:30pm.

About the Playwright

Emma Stanton is a Chicago and New York theater artist, with an interest in documentary and site-specific theater. She has worked with such companies as Redmoon Theater, American Theater Company, About Face Theatre, Double Edge Theater, Steppenwolf Theatre Company, Oracle Theater, 600 Highwaymen, En Garde Arts, and Walkabout Theater Company, of which she is Associate Artistic Director. She was a recipient of a Civics and Arts Foundation Playwriting Award for Emerging Artists in Chicago and most recently, her play Bojko and The Glacier was a semi-finalist for a Princess Grace Award. Currently, Emma is working on a commission by Bosnian artist Sejla Kameric, teaching a documentary theater class at Wadleigh High School for the Performing Visual Arts in Harlem, and in April 2016, her play No Candy (directed by Devon de Mayo)will be presented at The Signature Theater in New York as part of Columbia University’s graduate playwright thesis festival. Her mentors for her thesis are David Henry Hwang and Caridad Svich. BA: Boston College; MFA: Columbia University, 2016. www.emmadalbeystanton.com


About the Director

Devon de Mayo is the co-founder and co-artistic director of Dog & Pony Theatre Co.  Most recently, Devon served as the Resident Director for the Broadway production of The Audience under director Stephen Daldry.  Her directing & devising credits include Guerra: A Clown Play (performances in Chicago, New York, Albuquerque, Madrid, Bogota and Mexico City); The Whole World is Watching (Dog & Pony); The Twins Would Like to Say (Dog & Pony, Steppenwolf Garage Rep); and As Told by the Vivian Girls (Dog & Pony). Her directing credits include: Jet Black Chevrolet (side project); Lost in Yonkers (Northlight Theatre); Compulsion (Next Theatre); Everything is Illuminated (Next Theatre); An Actor Prepares (TAPS, University of Chicago); Roadkill Confidential, The Further Adventures of Hedda Gabler, Clouds (Dog & Pony); Infiltrating Bounce (Luminaria Festival, San Antonio); Second Story (Serendipity Theatre Collective); Crumble (Lay Me Down Justin Timberlake) (Finborough Theatre, London); Constriction (Collaboraction, Sketchbook), 52 (Canal Cafe, London); and Laba Laba (Bali, Indonesia). In addition to the University of Chicago, Devon teaches at Northwestern University and previously served as the Director of Education at Northlight Theatre. She received her MFA in Theatre Directing from Middlesex University in London and has studied at the Russian Academy of Theatre Arts (GITIS) in Moscow and the Indonesian Institute for the Arts in Bali.


The Cast

Amber Robinson, ASJA


Lucy Carapetyan, FAZILA


Carolyn Malloy, OLENA




Jessica Thigpen, ZLATA


Abby Pajakowski, MAJA



Lorraine Freund, UMA


Andrew Hager, ORIC

story:
The Rocky Horror Picture Show in ASL!

Support #DeafTalent in this super fun production of The Rocky Horror Picture Show in ASL.  

"A loving couple, a few lost monsters, and a sweet transvestite from transsexual Transylvania sing and dance through a campy, sloppy salute to horror movies and sexual liberation. Bring your sense of humor."

The Rocky Horror Picture Show is a cult classic film that is known for its passionate fans showing up to a movie theater to act out the entire show in front of the screen.  Every Friday and Saturday for the last 40 years, you could be sure to find Rocky Horror being performed somewhere in the world, with productions ranging from audience members re-enacting the show to elaborate productions with a rehearsed cast, flashy costumes, and fabulous props. 

Our production lives somewhere in the middle of that.  

Meet, ASL Rocky NYC.

Our show is performed completely in American Sign Language (ASL) with Deaf and hearing actors in front of the movie playing on a screen. The film will play with captioning alongside our signing actors. To make our rendition a more visual experience, we use real choreography, real props, and real costumes. This creates a better Deaf experience, and a more super fun show! Sounds awesome, right?  We think so too.

Where does my money go?

We will be using all proceeds directly on this production (and hopefully have some funds left over to start planning the next production)!  We are asking for your help to fund:

  • Accessibility
  • Rehearsal Space
  • Costumes
  • Theater Rental 
  • Insurance
  • Props
  • Rights to the Movie
  • Stipends for our Artists

We thank you for your support, and look forward to seeing you all at the show!

story:
(English follows)

Démarche artistique

La force d'Aurée Danse-Création réside en sa capacité de jeter un regard contemporain sur les rythmes traditionnels haïtiens afin de faire ressortir l’universalité de leurs messages.  Au fil de nos multiples expériences professionnelles dans le monde de la danse, nous avons pu constater que malgré les différentes formes de danse,  le fond et le but ultime de cet art sont la recherche d'émerveillement et la soif de redécouvrir la beauté.  Forte de ce constat, Aurée Danse-Création est allée à la rencontre de danseuses interprètes qui sont d’origines haïtienne, québécoise, brésilienne et mexicaine, pour créer Sezam.  À travers leurs forces techniques et leur grand potentiel d’interprétation, le public pourra vivre des émotions qui émanent d’un concept universel. Ce travail se fera en référence aux pas traditionnels haïtiens et à notre style de création qui marie rigueur technique et texture émotionnelle.

 Nous avons besoin de vous!

Nous voulons amasser 5 500$ CAD à la fin de cette campagne. Votre générosité et votre support nous permettront de rémunérer de façon décente tous les artistes et de leur garantir des lieux de travail sécuritaires pendant notre processus de création. Vos dons iront non seulement aux danseuses interprètes, mais aussi aux musiciens, chanteuse, techniciens, caméraman, photographe, couturier,maquilleuse, conseillers artistiques, infographes de Sezam. Ils sont tous des artistes passionnés qui collaborent avec Aurée Danse-Création. Sezam sera présenté à Montréal le 20 mai 2017!

Récompenses

  • Remerciement personnalisé (courriel et vidéo) de la part de la directrice artistique d'Aurée Danse-Création. De plus si vous avez un message d'espoir à faire passer pour le temps des fêtes, cela nous fera plaisir de le partager pour vous sur notre page Facebook;

  • Mention de votre nom sur la page Facebook d'Aurée Danse-Création,  la page de l'événement Facebook et dans l'album numérique des photos publicitaires de Sezam;

  • Deux photos numériques HD exclusives de l'équipe "en mode création";

  • Invitation à une répétition de Sezam et à notre soirée d'avant spectacle pour rencontrer nos artistes;

  • Ajout de votre nom sur la liste officielle des COMMANDITAIRES ainsi que des  billets VIP pour la présentation du 20 mai 2017 à Montréal.

 Votre IMPACT 

Notre quotidien en tant qu' artistes est rempli de défis et ces derniers deviennent encore plus évidents en période de création. Nous voulons utiliser notre art pour faire notre part dans notre société. Nous devons travailler de longues heures et surmonter des moments difficiles afin d'atteindre un niveau d'excellence à la hauteur de vos attentes. Grâce à votre contribution, nous parviendrons à garder le cap pour arriver à ce niveau d'excellence et livrer un produit de qualité. Nous ne laisserons rien au hasard et peaufinerons tous les détails pour que Sezam soit un succès, le 20 mai 2017. C'est notre promesse!

En contribuant à Sezam, VOUS fournissez des ailes à notre art pour qu'il s'élève et éclaire dans un monde en quête d'inspiration, de beauté et de solutions. 

Équipe de tournage:

Interprètes: Véroushka Eugène, Paloma Olan, Fedora Mathieu,Maria Isabel Rondon, Sendy-Loo Emmanuel.

Chorégraphe: Shérane JP Figaro

Vidéo: Pierre Mainville

 

D'autres façons d'aider

Si vous ne pouvez pas contribuer mais que vous voulez quand même faire partie de Sezam: vous pouvez passer le mot en utilisant les outils de partage Indiegogo !

MERCI !!

 

Artistic approach

The strength of Auree Danse-Creation lies in its ability to take a contemporary look at the traditional Haitian rhythms in order to bring out the universality of their messages. In the course of our professional experiences in the dance world, we have realized that despite the various forms of dance, the ultimate goal of this art form is the search for wonder and beauty. For this new creation, we will work with dancers from different origins: Haiti, Québec, Brazil and Mexico. With their technical strengths and their great potential for interpretation, the public will be able to experience incredible emotion, through a universal concept. This work will be done in reference to traditional Haitian steps and our style of creation that combines technique and emotional content.

 

We need you!

We want to raise $ 5,500 CAD at the end of this campaign. Your generosity and support will enable us to pay decently the artists participating in Sezam and it will guarantee them safe workplaces during our creative process. Your donations will go not only to the dancers, but also to the musicians, singer, technician, cameraman, photographer, fashion designer, makeup artist, artistic advisers, etc.  They are passionate artists who collaborate with Auree Danse-Creation. Sezam will be presented in Montreal on May 20, 2017!

 

Rewards

  • Thank you emails and videos from the artistic director of Aurée Danse-Creation. Furthermore, if you have a special message of hope for the Holiday Season, we will be more than happy to share it for you on our Facebook page;
  • Your name on the Facebook page of Auree Danse-Creation, (Facebook event and digital photo album);
  • Two exclusive digital photos (HD) of the team during our "work in progress" session;
  • Invitation to a rehearsal of Sezam and to our pre-show event to meet our artists;
  • Your name on the official list of SPONSORS and VIP tickets for the premiere on May 20th, 2017.

 

Your IMPACT

Our daily life as artists is challenging and it gets even harder during our creative process. We have to work long hours and overcome difficulties in order to reach a level of excellence that meets your expectations. We want to use our art form to do our part in our society. With your contribution, we will be able to stay focused in order to reach this level of excellence and deliver a spectacular show. We will do whatever it takes to scrutinize every part of our process so that Sezam will be a success on May 20, 2017. This  is our promise!

By contributing to Sezam YOU provide wings to our art form and enable it to rise and inspire in a world in search of beauty, inspiration and solutions.

 

Team (video shooting):

Dancers: Véroushka Eugène, Paloma Olan, Fedora Mathieu, Maria Isabel Rondon, Sendy-Loo Emmanuel.

Choreographer: Shérane JP Figaro

Video: Pierre Mainville

 

Other ways to help

If you cannot contribute but still want to be part of Sezam: you can spread the word by using Indiegogo sharing tools!

 

 THANK YOU !!

(English follows)
Démarche artistique
La force d'Aurée Danse-Création réside en sa capacité de jeter un regard contemporain sur les rythmes traditionnels haïtiens afin de faire ressortir l’universalité de leurs messages.  Au fil de nos multiples expériences professionnelles dans le monde de la danse, nous avons pu constater que malgré les différentes formes de danse,  le fond et le but ultime de cet art sont la recherche d'émerveillement et la soif de redécouvrir la beauté.  Forte de ce constat, Aurée Danse-Création est allée à la rencontre de danseuses interprètes qui sont d’origines haïtienne, québécoise, brésilienne et mexicaine, pour créer Sezam.  À travers leurs forces techniques et leur grand potentiel d’interprétation, le public pourra vivre des émotions qui émanent d’un concept universel. Ce travail se fera en référence aux pas traditionnels haïtiens et à notre style de création qui marie rigueur technique et texture émotionnelle.


 Nous avons besoin de vous!
Nous voulons amasser 5 500$ CAD à la fin de cette campagne. Votre générosité et votre support nous permettront de rémunérer de façon décente tous les artistes et de leur garantir des lieux de travail sécuritaires pendant notre processus de création. Vos dons iront non seulement aux danseuses interprètes, mais aussi aux musiciens, chanteuse, techniciens, caméraman, photographe, couturier,maquilleuse, conseillers artistiques, infographes de Sezam. Ils sont tous des artistes passionnés qui collaborent avec Aurée Danse-Création. Sezam sera présenté à Montréal le 20 mai 2017!
Récompenses

Remerciement personnalisé (courriel et vidéo) de la part de la directrice artistique d'Aurée Danse-Création. De plus si vous avez un message d'espoir à faire passer pour le temps des fêtes, cela nous fera plaisir de le partager pour vous sur notre page Facebook;
Mention de votre nom sur la page Facebook d'Aurée Danse-Création,  la page de l'événement Facebook et dans l'album numérique des photos publicitaires de Sezam;
Deux photos numériques HD exclusives de l'équipe "en mode création";
Invitation à une répétition de Sezam et à notre soirée d'avant spectacle pour rencontrer nos artistes;
Ajout de votre nom sur la liste officielle des COMMANDITAIRES ainsi que des  billets VIP pour la présentation du 20 mai 2017 à Montréal.


 Votre IMPACT 
Notre quotidien en tant qu' artistes est rempli de défis et ces derniers deviennent encore plus évidents en période de création. Nous voulons utiliser notre art pour faire notre part dans notre société. Nous devons travailler de longues heures et surmonter des moments difficiles afin d'atteindre un niveau d'excellence à la hauteur de vos attentes. Grâce à votre contribution, nous parviendrons à garder le cap pour arriver à ce niveau d'excellence et livrer un produit de qualité. Nous ne laisserons rien au hasard et peaufinerons tous les détails pour que Sezam soit un succès, le 20 mai 2017. C'est notre promesse!
En contribuant à Sezam, VOUS fournissez des ailes à notre art pour qu'il s'élève et éclaire dans un monde en quête d'inspiration, de beauté et de solutions. 

Équipe de tournage:
Interprètes: Véroushka Eugène, Paloma Olan, Fedora Mathieu,Maria Isabel Rondon, Sendy-Loo Emmanuel.
Chorégraphe: Shérane JP Figaro
Vidéo: Pierre Mainville
 

D'autres façons d'aider
Si vous ne pouvez pas contribuer mais que vous voulez quand même faire partie de Sezam: vous pouvez passer le mot en utilisant les outils de partage Indiegogo !

story:
Short Summary

Natalia Knowlton and Kara Chamberlain began working together as CrossLine Theatre in 2013. Both Canadian, they got their start at the Edmonton Fringe Festival. They wanted to create theatre inspired by every day experiences, that questioned the society we live in and the social norms and traditions that box us in. They hope to inspire discussion, education and action through their performances.

Three years later and CLT has crossed the pond and several boundaries to create work that does all of the above. 

After an incredible first run at Camden People's Theatre's Calm Down, Dear feminist theatre festival in London, CLT's newest play 'CREAM PIE' is about to embark on a run at Brighton Fringe Festival.

CREAM PIE is an exploration into mainstream porn, porn consumption and the impact of porn on the millennial generation. #PORNGEN  

We don't talk about porn enough...and we certainly don't talk about the effects of it enough - CLT is here to change that.

You Need HOW Much?!

That's right. We need £1000. This may sound like a lot. In fact, we know it sounds like a lot ... because it is. 
It is a lot of money. 
Taking theatre to a fringe festival is a lot of money. Taking theatre to fringe in a city that's not your home is a lot of money. Taking theatre to a fringe in a city that's not your home with actors that need feeding and props that need painting and lights that need lighting is a LOT of money...oh and not to mention the cost of marketing, insurance, rehearsal space (the list goes on...). 
BUT it's also worth all of that money. To start a discussion. To get people talking about things we're all too afraid to talk about but that we need to talk about because there's a whole generation having their whole concept of sex being skewed because nobody's talking about it and they're relying on porn for an education. 
It's worth all of that money to educate - we're working in association with Brook, who have the AskBrook service for people who have questions about sexual health. How great is that?
It's worth all of that money to get CREAM PIE to Brighton Fringe, so we're asking you wonderful people to help us.

Other Ways You Can Help

We totally understand that asking people for money is a long shot and that not everyone has pennies to spare - but if you'd like to help us, there's lots of other ways that you can!

You can follow @CrossLineTheatr on Twitter

You can give us a like on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/CrossLineTheatre/ 

and

You can come and see us at Brighton Fringe: https://www.brightonfringe.org/box-office/shows/view/cream-pie

story:
www.thedianatapes.com

James Clements.........................................................Writer/Producer/Actor

Jorge Morales.............................................................Producer/Actor

Sam Hood Adrain.......................................................Producer/Actor

Ana-Cristina Schuler..................................................Actress

Adam Welsh................................................................Sound/Video Design

Mairi MacInnes............................................................Costume/Set Design

This tense thriller presents the true story of one of the greatest media scandals in British history – the publication of Andrew Morton's book about Diana, Princess of Wales, which ended her marriage and shook the monarchy to its core. The show moves between Morton’s office, the sitting room where the Princess recorded her darkest secrets onto cassettes, and the dingy West London cafe where one of her best friends surreptitiously handed them over. The subterfuge and deception are brought to a scorching climax that changed celebrity, privacy, and the Windsor family forever. The question remains: who was the victim, and who the victor?

The production will premiere at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival in August 2016. The writer, James Clements, is a theatre artist who lives between New York and Glasgow, and this production will marry the strong creative and artistic heritage of both locations to create a diverse team and an original piece that is socially relevant, powerful, and unapologetic. This play will give voice to a woman that was spoken for her whole life, and aim to explore the trauma's that marred her bright, but brief, existence.
The show will play at theSpace UK at Niddry Street August 22nd through the 27th.

Your funding is so appreciated and so necessary to the creation of this piece. We believe it is a story that must be told, and that the Princess's true story deserves to be heard. The money we raise will go toward - 

  • Renting the venue (the Space @ Niddry Street) for the show's run
  • Transporting cast, crew and materials from New York to Scotland
  • Props, costumes, publicity materials and set needs in Edinburgh
  • Accommodation for theatre artists during the run of the show
  • Registration costs for the Fringe Festival
As an expression of our gratitude for helping us tell this vital story, we will offer a range of perks including signed posters, signed scripts and free tickets to performances. We have been developing this piece for a long time, and truly believe it is a socio-historical necessity that it is told. We can't imagine a better venue to premiere it than this wonderful theatre festival, and any funding we do raise, even if not the full amount, will allow us to move closer to this becoming a reality.

We hope this play will - 

  • Allow us to tell the story of a woman who we all invaded and utilised to understand ourselves and our society from her perspective.
  • Allow us to consider the role of the media in our cultural institutions and governing bodies, and the impact it has on our perceptions, then and now.
  • Begin dialogues around agency and ownership of personal histories and stories - who writes them, who consumes them, and who they impact.
  • Take responsibility for humanizing an iconic person, and giving language to a individual so often identified simply by images.

While we hope to sell enough tickets to cover some of our costs, the Edinburgh Fringe is a highly competitive and busy environment. As emerging artists, trying to establish our voices, we truly need the funding for this project to proceed, and to get this important story heard. Without funding, this project will struggle to be realised, but with even some funds raised, our talented and committed team will put together a performance that does the story, and its protagonist, justice.

Some challenges include - 

  • Transporting our team and our sets from New York to Scotland.
  • Finding ways to accommodate international artists during the Festival.
  • Using technology to allow the piece to develop across continents successfully.
  • Combining two different networks of artists from different continents, and encouraging cross-cultural dialogue.

If you find yourselves unable to contribute financially at this time, we would still deeply appreciate your help in any way that you can.

  • Please share our campaign with everyone that you think might be interested or supportive of our work.
  • Please come and see our show - we desperately want it to be seen, and that contribution is, in itself, so powerful.
  • Please reach out to our team with questions, stories and ideas about your relationship and memories of the Princess of Wales.

story:
Who are Fair Equity?


Fair Equity Website


Fair Equity is a brand new political party, from our very inception in early 2014 we have already grown from strength to strength.

We believe in a fairer politics, we believe in common sense politics and most of all we believe in an equal society where people on low incomes have a lower tax rate than multimillionaires and large corporations who use tax loop holes to avoid tax.

Our aim is to change the current political landscape, for so long politicians have made a career out of their position and have used it to garner more money for themselves, they have forgotten that they serve the people and when they ignore their electorate they are no longer fit for purpose.


More money for the lower paid - less money for the overpaid

People in this country need a living wage and not a minimum wage, those who work hard should be rewarded with it. They should have a life not a month to month existence, people should be able to save for their futures and ensure they have a solid basis rather than paying out bill after bill which leaves them with nothing, bills that I may add that are further more lining the pockets of the already rich!


Our Three Main Aims Are:

1. Proportionate 'to earnings' Taxation 
(people on a smaller wage are taxed less, those on a large wage taxed high)

2. An end to massive Inheritances

3. Equally Support all people in UK 


We currently have 70 candidates who will be standing in the 2015 General Election and a large membership base. All our candidates and members come from a wide spectrum of society, we have disabled people, gay people, unemployed people, students, full time mothers, single families, working families etc. Most importantly we are ordinary people who are making a stand.


What do we need from you?

We need your contributions so that Fair Equity can move to the next level, no matter how big or small your contribution is, it is more than welcome and will help us reach our goal.

Your money will go to a variety of uses, the first and most important will be to cover the registration fee with the electoral commission, we want to register the party so that we are a bonafide political party and all our candidates are able to stand in the 2015 General Election.

We would also use a proportion of the money raised so we can improve the website, as it was created on a budget.

A significant amount would go into our PR and Advertising campaign, we need posters, t-shirts, stickers, adverts in the media/press, rosettes, banners, campaign/party videos and interviews. Essentially all the necessary means to get the Fair Equity Party out there. We need to get our message across to the wider public and let them know that there is another option, that not all politicians are self serving cretins and that your voice can and will be heard... that's what we stand for.

Lastly a proportion of the amount raised will go towards hosting our first Party Political Conference, here we will discuss and vote on many important issues that will affect the party and our policies as a whole.


Why help us?

Our aim is to ensure people have a voice, that the current form of politics with it's self serving politicians and their agendas that only benefit the upper class/old boy networks comes to an end.

We want fairness and an equal society, we're not after a shallow promise of change... we are after total system reform.

There is currently a movement for change within the UK and the world at large, this ofcourse is the truther, anonymous and political/system change movement. People all over the world are calling for change, for revolution. They want a world that works for them and we believe in that. We need to ensure that we are all free to say as we want, be who we want and overall be free from a system of perpetual debt enslavement.

Together we can help change this world, Fair Equity is not alone either as there are many other independent parties out there who are looking to act as the voice of the people, the voice that we are all being denied by the current political elite.

People need to be able to get ahead in life, it's time for people to make a living and not just an existence and that's what we here at Fair Equity want to bring about. Real and lasting change!

With your help we will get out there and show people there is another way.

Other Ways You Can Help?

Don't worry if your unable to contribute, you can help us in a variety of ways. We are looking for more candidates to stand in the 2015 General Election, we are looking for new members and supporters, we need people who are able to get on social media and help spread the word about Fair Equity. We need people who can work as part of our campaign teams at election time, people who can get out there with our candidates and canvas their local areas.

story:
Free Shakespeare-in-the-Parks celebrates 45 years!

You may join Friends of PAE with a donation of any size. Your financial support provides sets for our success in bringing financially accessible theatre to broader audiences. Thank you for considering becoming a Friend.

Portland Actors Ensemble’s free Shakespeare-in-the-Parks has become a treasured Portland summer tradition, reaching over 50,000 audience members during our last decade alone! PAE has produced at least one Shakespearean play every summer since 1970, making the company one of the oldest continuously operating theatres in the city. Shakespeare-in-the-Parks is a highlight of the summer for our dedicated audiences, and provides a unique, engaging and entertaining introduction to Shakespeare for those who have never experienced his plays before. 

We are proud to present our 2014 Summer Season!

•   Antony & Cleopatra, directed by Elizabeth Huffman, will be the 10th Annual Twilight Tragedie, running June 19 - July 26.

•  A Midsummer Night's Dream, directed by Douglas Lay (who brought us Cymbeline last year) will be our 45th annual touring Shakespeare-in-the-Parks, running July 12 - Labor Day.

Portland Actors Ensemble past and present.

PAE enhances and serves our community by offering live performances free of charge to all, regardless of ability to pay, or hear, or see. Some theatres in town charge $40, $50, even over $60 per ticket! We believe everyone deserves to experience the power and beauty of William Shakespeare's work, so not only is every performance free to everyone, but each production also features at least one sign-interpreted performance and one audio-described performance (if at all possible). For many of our audience members, particularly families with children, our free productions may be the first time they’ve experienced the excitement and immediacy of live theatre.

Your contribution will support our ability to work with the best local artists to provide memorable productions, and continue our tradition of accessible, professional theatre!

Whether your family and friends have made attending a PAE production a decades-long tradition, you’ve only been to one of our shows, or you are unexposed to our company and our work, we hope you’ll support our ability to bring accessible to one of Portland’s beautiful parks in a community near you. We invite you to become a 2014 member of Friends of PAE so you may enjoy the benefits of annual membership while supporting the integral work we continue to do.

Join Now!

Gifts are tax-deductible (minus the fair market value of any thank-you gifts you may receive, of course). If you would like your gift to be fully deductible, just let us know that you do not need any "perks". Your donation directly supports the operations of Portland Actors Ensemble, including artistic costs associated with both Antony & Cleopatra and A Midsummer Night's Dream. Our fundraising in the weeks before summer productions begin is crucial to our success and our ability to continue providing high quality, free theatre for all.  Donate now to show your support for PAE, and demonstrate to your community you are invested in sustaining this Portland tradition. Gifts of all sizes add value to our mission!

Larger Gifts:

If you are able to make a gift greater than $1,000, please contact us at support@portlandactors.com to discuss additional benefits!  We welcome the opportunity for larger partnerships, and would be happy to discuss one with you.

Just let us know if you want your gift to remain anonymous.

Not able to donate at this time? There are many other easy ways to help.

If you aren't able to contribute funds at this time, we understand.  There are many other ways to help promote the mission of Portland Actors Ensemble:

•  Share this campaign via Facebook, Twitter and email. Word of mouth continues to be our best marketing tool, and your endorsement to your friends, family and co-workers is deeply appreciated!

•  Visit the support page at our new website at www.portlandactors.com to learn easy ways to support PAE in just a few minutes and no extra money out of your pocket.

•  Arrange for your workplace to sponsor Portland Actors Ensemble by having your gifts or community engagement person contact us at support@portlandactors.com, OR talk us up to them and give us their contact information if they seem receptive!

•  Become a Facebook friend of PortlandActorsEnsemble for news and updates.

•  Volunteer to help at performances: email volunteer@portlandactors.com.

•  Help us advertise our performances in your community by distributing posters and postcards.  Check the website for printable versions as the summer approaches.

•  Make sure that there is an audience tomorrow: bring children, grandchildren and friends to a PAE performance, and share the love of theatre with a whole new generation!

•  Most of all, come and enjoy a performance with your friends and family!

Good Will for All!

Video clip provided by Heather Welch.  For more of her videos of PAE, visit www.youtube.com/user/HMWelch76/videos

Photo by Garry Louie of Sara Jane Fridlich as Imogen in Cymbeline

story:
A little about Me!

Hi! My name is Marie Watson, I am 10 years old and attend Banneker Achievement Center in Gary, IN. I am a cheerleader, on the spell bowl team, perfect attendance and honor roll student and my BIGGEST PASSION IS DANCE!

I am in my 8th year at DancExcel where I take ballet, modern, jazz, hip hop, african and tap. I am apart of Asia's Dance Factory during the school year as well. Both of my parents danced growing up and it comes natural that dance would be in my heart.


What We Need

The cost of this experience is big! Approximately $5,000!

We are only asking for help for the tuition costs which is $1,550.

Between family and friend contributions we hope to cover the expenses of the list below on our own:

Room and Board $2,750

Airfare: $408+ taxes

Dance Wear: approximately $200

Experience Days: $175

The Impact

We would appreciate all the contributions to get Miss Marie out to LA. Since she was accepted in May, her family and friends have been doing numerous fundraisers and efforts to get closer to the goal of $5,000.

With YOUR help we can make sure she gets there!

Other Ways You Can Help

Share the links to donate on your social media!

story:
Who am I ?

Hello Film Fans.  I'm Jeff Meyer and watching movies on celluloid is a true love of mine. So much so, that for the past 9 years I've put together countless film screenings at The Palace Theater here in Syracuse, NY. From westerns, cult classics, or horror marathons, we’ve kept the 35mm torch burning.

As digital becomes the dominant format in cinemas, the depth and beauty of 35mm film is on the verge of extinction. But digital can’t compare to a restored film print or the nostalgic grit of a grindhouse print. From being touched by artists or directors, to being screened in some of the most amazing film houses in the world, each print holds its own history. Some films have not yet made the transfer from film to digital, and might never be, leaving future film fans unable to experience it on the silver screen.

Recently, the analog processor for our 35mm projector broke. I'm raising funds to get a new processor, pay for a certified Dolby Audio Technician to adjust/equalize the audio after the repairs and to help cover shipping expenses. With your contribution, you'll be able to help save 35mm film screenings in Syracuse with improved sound quality and updated film audio technology.

Without these repairs, the Palace Theater will do away with the film projector entirely and go strictly to a digital format. 35mm will survive as long as fans like you and I keep it alive. LONG LIVE 35mm!

 

What I Need & What You Get:

This is what I need:

  • Updated sound processor
  • Dolby Certified Audio Technician to EQ system
  • Repairs to the Subwoofer
  • Tech to re-wire the audio rack

$1400 will cover all that needs to get done to improve the system.  The most expensive being the Dolby Sound Tech. Any funds raised over the goal will go towards expenses for the 2015 Salt City Horror Fest.

This is what you get:

  • A better viewing and listening experience
  • Opportunity to see over a dozen 35mm films
  • Satisfaction knowing you were part of a goal to save film screenings

Each perk involves different levels of film viewing events.  Recently we were blessed with a Brew & View 35mm Film sponsor.  The goal is to program four Brew & View 35mm Film screenings late 2014 and early 2015.  Depending on the perk you choose, you'll receive passes to the Brew & Views and the 2015 Salt City Horror Fest.  As contributions pour in, I will immediately put them towards the goals.

The Impact

Since I was a kid, I’ve always wanted to see the movies I grew up with on the big screen the way they were supposed to be viewed.  Granted, I could take most films and screen it via digital, but that is not where my heart is.  The Palace has no time, or resources to put towards this project.  It is up to all of us to pull ourselves and our love of film together to raise the goal of $1400.

I’ve been doing 35mm film screenings for almost 9 years, I plan on doing this for another 9. Pretty sure you all would like this to keep going.

Risks & Challenges

This risks involved in raising funds for the audio project are simple.  There are no risks.  Either it gets fixed or we watch movies on film with crappy audio or on digital.  For your information – The 35mm Film sound processor is unrelated to anything the Palace screens digitally. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please get the word out and help us reach our goal.  As contributions role in, I will start putting them towards each project and will update with video as to the progress of said project.  Please use the Indigogo share tools. All extra funds over our will go towards the Brew& View 35mm film series and The 2015 Salt City Horror Fest.

story:
The Project

A production of Sarah Ruhl's Eurydice, set to go up at the end of August 2014 in Massachusetts.

Inside the Director's mind

My name is Kaitlyn Crockett and I am the director / producer for Eurydice. As a twenty-something college student, I have directed many shows in the past, including both original pieces and previously-written works. I've grown up in the theater for as long as I can remember and have worked with multiple companies and school programs in Massachusetts. 

Not only is my desire to create theater a force to be reckoned with, but the same goes for my fellow peers. We all had a need to create together this summer; however, we did not find any opportunities around that fulfilled our creative needs. I was prepared to let this summer breeze by just like every other, when one small but determined voice in my head said: Why should we let that stop us? And thus, the idea to self-produce and direct a show was embroider into my skull.

I read Eurydice over a year ago and immediately fell head-over-heals in love: the story, the characters, the surreal reality, the style . . . the whole world of the play. When searching for a play, it seemed to be the ideal fit: both for me as a director and the rest of our group as actors. As a group, we like to be challenged and to grow as artists. 

My goals as a director and producer are twofold: 1) to provide people with unforgettable theatrical experiences, and 2) to share stories that bring the community together. Not only does this project fulfill our desire to create as young artists, but it allows us to share our passion and stories with all of you.

EURYDICE? By Sarah Ruhl? What's that about?

Is it easier to remember or to forget? That is one of the questions posed by playwright Sarah Ruhl in her surreal, poetic, and water-filled dream of a play.

Eurydice and Orpheus are young newlyweds very much in love. Shortly after their wedding, Eurydice is drawn to an interesting man who claims to have a letter from her deceased father. This encounter takes a turn for the worse. In her attempt to escape from the clutches of this Nasty Interesting Man, she trips and falls down several flights of stairs . . . and dies.
After her death, Eurydice is transported to the magical Underworld and is reunited with her deceased father - only to find that her memory has been washed away.

Sarah Ruhl has taken the original Greek myth about the musician Orpheus and his doomed lover and turned it upside-down and shaken it like a snowglobe. A powerful story about love, family, loss, and the choices we must make, Eurydice is a play that will grab onto your heart and soul until you chose to let it go.

We Need YOUR Help!

Our fundraising goal is $500, and with Indiegogo fees that means that we are raising $550. However, that is the bare minimum that we would need in order to produce this show.  If more money was raised, we would have greater resources in order to bring you a more professional show and a more theatrical experience.

This money will go towards:
  • perks for the lovely donators
  • printing programs and posters
  • building a playing space / set
  • buying and creating costume pieces
  • sparse but necessary props
  • fun special effects (WATER FALLING FROM THE SKY?!)
  • high-quality music
  • a basic sound system
  • lighting equipment
  • licensing and performance rights
  • creating an overall atmosphere to transport the audience into this world we have created
At the end of the day, storytelling does not require unlimited funds. Because of our outdoor facilities and found rehearsal spaces, we are saving ourselves a lot of money in order to focus our budget on aspects that will enhance the story and experience for all who attend. 


Give and Ye Shall Receive . . . Perks!

If you donate to our production, not only will you receive our eternal gratitude and endless good thoughts, but possibly also:

  • A credit in our program of your donation!
  • A Eurydice candle!
  • A DVD copy of our production!
  • A signed Eurydice program / poster from the cast!
  • A song written and performed for you! (includes beatboxing and riffing)
  • A massage from Eurydice herself, who is a licensed massage therapist!

The Impact

This production has a myriad of benefits. In a world where realism in theater has become a norm and the same ten shows are produced every year, we strive to bring our community a different kind of story. Eurydice is important because dealing with choices and growing up are all parts of the human experience. Everybody can relate to love, loss, grief, happiness, and being vulnerable because we are all human. It's important to have a way to express, acknowledge, and experience that with others in a safe environment. 

Every actor and person working on this production is not only talented, but willing to work on this show without pay due to their sheer passion and love for the community and each other. Everyone believes so strongly in the story, we simply must tell it in some way. 

Our production of Eurydice is a "thank you" to our community. It is our way to give back to those who have supported us and provided us with so much of our experiences. We are all young artists, looking to use our talents to form experiences with our communities by sharing stories. Eurydice is one of those many stories, and we hope to give you an experience you will never forget. 

    Risks & Challenges? We're ready for 'em!

    I am not going to lie to you. There are many risks and challenges that must be taken and conquered (respectively) when producing any show. The performance space not being up to code, being rained out, not having a profit, and more. We are prepared for such problems

    • We are performing in an outdoor space, rain or shine. (Rainy weather would only enhance the performance.) The backyard being donated to our use is extremely nice and spacious; we are lucky and grateful to have it.
    • We are not looking to make a profit. We will only have a donation box and that money will go towards our actors' educational funds.
    • We are building our own sets and doing all of the hard labor ourselves, which not only helps keep us under budget by not paying somebody for the construction/assembly of the space, but gives us the experience of delving further into all facets of theater.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    It is understandable if you cannot donate money at this time - not everybody can. If you would still like to support us, here are some other options:

    • Have a red tricycle that you don't use anymore? If you have materials that we may need (set materials, props, costumes, lighting, sound equipment, etc), then please write to us saying that are interesting in providing your services elsewhere, besides in monetary-form! This story requires unique items such as a red tricycle, a water pump, a pair of 1950's bathing suits, The Complete Works of Shakespeare . . . to name a few. Feel free to ask us for specifics - you may have an item that we are looking to borrow!
    • See those Indiegogo sharing tools? Use 'em! Tell people about our campaign. Spread the word around like jam on toast. Mmm, yummy.
    Thank you so much for taking the time to read about and support our production of Sarah Ruhl's Eurydice!

      Introduction video and photos to come soon.

      THE CAST

      Eurydice ................................................................................................ Kelly Maglio
      Her Father ....................................................................................... John Bachelder
      Orpheus ..................................................................................................... Joey Tyler
      A Nasty Interesting Man/Lord of the Underworld ............................. Josh Ray
      The Stones:
           Big Stone .......................................................... Charlette Renault-Caragianes
           Little Stone .................................................................................. Cookie Dibiase
           Loud Stone ............................................................................... Cassandra Milne

      THE CREW

      Producer / Director / Designer ................................................. Kaitlyn Crockett
      Stage Manager ............................................................................ Matt Vacherweill
      Make-up / Hair Design ............................................................... Cassandra Milne
      Music Consultant .......................................................................... Nathan LeBlanc

The performance space not being up to code, being rained out, not having a profit, and more. We are prepared for such problems 
We are performing in an outdoor space, rain or shine. (Rainy weather would only enhance the performance.) The backyard being donated to our use is extremely nice and spacious; we are lucky and grateful to have it. We are not looking to make a profit. We will only have a donation box and that money will go towards our actors' educational funds.
We are building our own sets and doing all of the hard labor ourselves, which not only helps keep us under budget by not paying somebody for the construction/assembly of the space, but gives us the experience of delving further into all facets of theater.   Other Ways You Can Help It is understandable if you cannot donate money at this time - not everybody can. If you would still like to support us, here are some other options: 
Have a red tricycle that you don't use anymore? If you have materials that we may need (set materials, props, costumes, lighting, sound equipment, etc), then please write to us saying that are interesting in providing your services elsewhere, besides in monetary-form! This story requires unique items such as a red tricycle, a water pump, a pair of 1950's bathing suits, The Complete Works of Shakespeare . . . to name a few. Feel free to ask us for specifics - you may have an item that we are looking to borrow! See those Indiegogo sharing tools? Use 'em! Tell people about our campaign. Spread the word around like jam on toast. Mmm, yummy.

Thank you so much for taking the time to read about and support our production of Sarah Ruhl's Eurydice! Introduction video and photos to come soon.THE CASTEurydice ................................................................................................ John BachelderOrpheus ..................................................................................................... Joey TylerA Nasty Interesting Man/Lord of the Underworld ............................. Josh RayThe Stones:     Big Stone .......................................................... Charlette Renault-Caragianes     Little Stone .................................................................................. Cookie Dibiase     Loud Stone ............................................................................... Kaitlyn CrockettStage Manager ............................................................................ story:
Taking PLace is a choreographic residency and experiment in creative process that brings together dance makers K.J. Holmes (NYC), Peter Kyle (NYC), Bebe Miller (Columbus), CoCo Loupe (Baton Rouge), and Claire Porter (NYC) in Ohio for the creation of new work with local dancers and a world-premiere concert event. The process - including workshops, rehearsals, interviews - are open to the public, and to guerilla-documentation. AND NOW, we are honored to join the trio of international dance festivals that Meta-academy invites you to engage online with this summer-Taking Place (July 1-13 in Columbus, OH, USA), Impulstanz/(July 21 -August 18 in Vienna, Austria), and Bates Dance Festival(July 21-August 11 in Lewiston, ME, USA). 

photographer unknown

Our guest artists live together, create dance and curate the concert event; collaborating with each other by working with dozens of local dancers and remotely with Meta-Academy participants from around the world. An adjudication process will provide commission for at least one Columbus choreographer to join the artists for the process and the production. Local musicians, photographers, video artists, and international media specialists are also collaborators of this creative process experiment.

This big EXPERIMENT costs a little money.

NEW OPPORTUNITY!! Meta-Academy participants will engage with our guest artists via live-broadcast interviews; embodied google hangouts; and participation in threaded conversations on concept and process. We’ll share photos, videos, sound and text recordings as impetus for interaction and creation, and they can all be edited online to create participants' own documentary instances of what's Taking PLace . This is a wonderful new opportunity for us and we are intrigued to see what will happen!

Read more about our collaborators from meta-academy .

I'm Nicole Garlando, coordinator of the experiment Taking PLace. I'm a dance maker, performer, teaching artist, and arts administrator. Since moving to Columbus in 2011 I've helped to open Feverhead, a funky lil dance and arts space; received a Choreographic Fellowship, Project funding, Professional Development and Technical Supply grants from the Greater Columbus Arts Council; I serve as company administrator for Bebe Miller Company; and facilitate and collaborate in events throughout the city.  

I got the idea for Taking PLace after serving as an intern last summer at Bearnstow, where I studied with Peter Kyle, Claire Porter and K.J. Holmes, among several other creative facilitators. My arts administration work for Bebe Miller Company and Feverhead collaborations with CoCo Loupe have made these 5 artists important mentors to my creative process, dance-making, and question-asking. I saw an opportunity for collaboration - for them and for Columbus dancers - and along with some incredible committee members, have created the time and space for it. I need your help in raising the last bit of cash to pay the guest and local artists involved.

photo: Julieta Cervantes

Taking PLace is funded-in-part by the Greater Columbus Arts Council under the fiscal agency of theShort North Stage. Co-sponsors The Garden Theatre and the Department of Dance at The Ohio State University have donated space and time for rehearsals and performances, and our media sponsor WCBE  has provided us with free airtime. And now-Dance-tech.net is facilitating our presence in the 2014 Meta-Academy. We are immensely grateful for our local funding, private donations, and generous in-kind resources! 

What We Need & What You Get

We want everyone working so hard to be paid!! Our collaborators are: 5 guest choreographers, 20 local dancers, 2 local photographers, 2 local video artists, 3 local musicians, and 2 international media artists. Our guests' artistic caliber is high - including a Guggenheim Fellow and a Bessie Award Winner - and the local talent is stellar. The dedication of committee members and cast members is unprecedented. 

How we'll spend the money:

After fees paid to Indiegogo and to our fiscal agent, which total 11.75% of funds raised, all dollars go to paying the artist stipends.

The Impact

You can help this BIG little project as we enter the global spotlight, and help connect communities around the world with choreographic knowledge, creative process, methodologies, ideas and more... who knows what may happen?!  

Taking PLace is the second Columbus dance festival I've coordinated. The first was Locality 2012 a Columbus bicentennial celebration funded in part by the Ohio Arts Council and the Greater Columbus Arts Council. It was a highly successful weekend festival and site-specific tour of dance in our city's spaces. It featured a stage concert and a gallery of creative process, workshops, and a 4-hour bus tour for which we commissioned 12 local choreographers to create new work. Taking PLace is the second iteration of a Locality event, only now we can bring people from around the world to our process AND give them pieces to take back.

photo: JJ Sulin

Risks & Challenges

The opportunity to deepen our work with dance-tech.net and serve as the kick-off for this year's Meta-Acadamy came just two weeks before the start of our residency! This is a very big effort in a short time. Since then, we've organized the collaboration and conceptual engagement, scheduled three Google Hangouts and Live-Broadcast Interviews, added more Guerrilla Documentation opportunities, uploaded video, text, sound and process ideas, and now have the interface to interact remotely with it. This all translates into more human and material resources including artist time and energy along with media management of our group on dance-tech.net, throughout the residency and after it 'ends' (the residency lasts 13 days in Columbus, the Meta-Academy interactions are ongoing). We have dedicated committee members and a brilliant team of collaborators who are excited for this experiment… so away we go!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to contribute, you can still help us get the word out about what's Taking PLace. Share our campaign link and talk about our project with family and friends. If you believe in what we're doing and tell them about us, they will too!

photo: Steven Schreiber


THE COMMITTEE:

TAKING PLACE is produced with the help of committee members: Rashana Smith (professor at Ohio Wesleyan University, founder of Motor Dance), Sharon Udoh (aka musician Counterfeit Madison, The Apes, and The Dew Droppers, Feverhead collaborator), Eve Hermann (Feverhead operator, writer, photographer), Gabby Stefura (dance educator at Fort Hayes Arts and Academics High School, Columbus Moving Company member), Christeen Stridsberg (dance educator at Otterbein University, Wittenberg University, Columbus Moving Company member), Paige Phillips (freelance choreographer), Brady Calestro (founder, Mondokio), and Jeff Fouch (Artistic Director/Founder Columbus Moving Company, performer Kristina Isabelle Co).

www.takingplacecolumbus.com


photo: Craig Bortmas

story:
My Name is Susan Massie, I am from Perth Scotland but currently living in Glasgow where I studied my BA (Honours) Drama Degree gaining a 2:1 in affiliation with Sunderland University.

From a young age I have always wanted to perform. Being on stage is where I am happiest, I love to entertain people and love the audience reaction – there is no better feeling!

My name is Sarah Jane Downs, I am 25 years old and originally from Paisley however grew up in a small village in the Scottish highlands called Achnasheen. I left Achnasheen at the age of 18 and returned to Paisley where I studied acting and performance for 3 years at Reid Kerr College. In 2012 I graduated from Sunderland University along side Susan with a 2:1 BA (Honours) Drama Degree. 

Susan and I along with two other university students formed Great Scot Theatre co and toured around Scotland with our popular play ‘Burns: If it werenae for the lassies'. The short play tells the story of the women who influenced the life and works of Robert Burns and includes songs and poems. The play was awarded a 1st by Sunderland University, which was the first and only 1st given by the university for this particular module. 

Since gaining our degree we have been lucky to be involved in various small scale acting roles however on the 19th July this year we both attended an audition for a new musical called ‘One Fond Kiss’ which has the potential to change our lives.

One Fond Kiss is a new musical written by the extremely talented Tish Tindall of Rock Academy Performing Arts and is based on an idea by David Gest & Michael Jackson. Tish and David teamed up to produce this amazing piece of Musical theatre after David rediscovered some lost recordings he and Michael Jackson had worked on years ago, this encouraged David to revisit his visions of a Burns musical but wanted it to be performed in Scotland with undiscovered Scottish talent….. and low and behold Sarah Jane and I have been chosen as one of the lead females!

We are still in disbelief that we have actually been chosen and cannot thank Tish, Diane and of course David enough for this amazing opportunity to be a part of a world premier!!

However this project is currently unfunded until we gauge the response to it, after the premier there is a very good chance the musical will tour at which point it will be funded.

Due to living in Glasgow and rehearsals being in Lossiemouth we are really struggling with the cost of travel and accommodation. We have worked out it is going to cost us over £3500 in total to participate in the project – this is how much we believe in it and how confident we are that good things can come from us being a part of this!

We are currently looking for funding to help us with these costs, we both have our own commitments at home and just don’t have the money to be able to afford this alone. We are approaching local councils, Arts funds, creative Scotland and now we are reaching out to the kindness and support of our family, friends and strangers to help us be a part of a potentially life changing opportunity. We are not asking for the full amount but any help you can offer would be appreciated beyond belief – we realise there are so many other causes you can choose to support and we are way down on that list but this is a once in a life time chance for us so we need to take the chance and ask for support.

Thank you for looking at our page.

story:
From £1 to £1000, your support helps...

We want receive enough funds to buy the lights we need, light the piece professionally and pay our incredible technician Ciaran who is as much of the team as the dancers! We want to promote the work,give it the exposure it deserves and of course put on a great show. 

Using Latin and Hip Hop dance theatre and culture, Ladylike, explores what it is to be ‘ladylike’ and and challenges our notions of gender, sexuality and identity. Ladylike invites the audience to explore a range of themes in juxtaposition, including masculine & feminine, fight & flight, consent & rape, oppression & liberation. 

Cultural dances/ customs explored include the dances of Orisha deities & the Rumba dance of flirtation Guaguanco- dances from Cuba, which can be traced back to West & Central Africa in origins, as a result of the slave trade. There is also reference to Hip Hop, the Apache line of Uprocking from NYC, breaking and the overtly sexualised Reggaeton.

Simple props, music (composed by Sabio Janiak), language and light projections have been well considered to accentuate meaning, as well as beautiful costumes designed by Jodie-Simone Howe.

 

What We Want:

£600 to build our own skypan lights, made by Hub Cap creatures  http://www.hubcapcreatures.com/

£300 to pay Ciaran Cunningham, the 5th member of Ladylike- our technician

 

Short Summary about the Artists

Ella Mesma: With a background in Latin Dance since 2000, she took up Breaking because she wanted to express herself in a way where it wasn't all about her looks, she decided to train as a contemporary dancer for two years in London, graduating with a postgraduate diploma from The London School of Contemporary Dance in 2011. She also have a politics and sociology degree from Leeds University. She loves to create, and is passionate about seeing real high-level Latin and Hip Hop Dance in the Theatre in the UK. 

As the choreographer and director of Latin Hip Hop Dance Theatre Company Ella Mesma Company (2011), her work has been described as ‘stunning,’ ‘provocative’ and ‘unabashedly emotional’ (The Guardian).

She established Latin dance company Element Arts, in Leeds in 2005 and then began producing Roots of Rumba (an annual Latin Dance Theatre Festival which gives Latin dance artists a platform for their work) in London in 2013. Her Latin accolades include Passista (First soloist) in Rio de Janeiro carnival 2006, Rainha Da Bateria for London School of Samba 2008, The Channel 4 Comedy Gala 2016 and a fellowship in Cuba & Brazil in 2015 (Winston Churchill Memorial Trust). She also teaches and has been commissioned to create work and run workshops across the UK and internationally.

In 2013, she was selected as a future Dance Leader for the ABLE leadership program, and in 2015, awarded a Bench fellowship for emerging choreographers. She is currently Associate Dance Artist at Dance City in Newcastle. As a performer, she has worked internationally including tours with Russell Maliphant Company, Southpaw Company, & performing for the Olympics Opening Ceremony, Wendy Houston’s ‘Stupid Women’, Warsan Shire (as featured in Beyonce’s ‘Lemonade’)'s ‘The Ugly Daughter’ and Adidas  

Anna is Anglo-Argentine, and studied dance and athletics from a young age. She studied dance at Facultade Angel Vianna in Rio de Janeiro and worked with Gustavo Cirico, Frederico Paredes, and Deborah Colker. Anna worked with Vertigo Dance Company in Israel in 2015. Anna is a Tango Dancer and assists for the Leandro Palou Tango Academy. She has taught workshops for Come Dancing and Strictly Come Dancing.

Lianett was born in La Habana, Cuba, and trained at the National School of Art in Cuba (ENA), graduating in 2005 with a gold title. In 2006 she joined the National Company of Contemporary Dance in Cuba and has toured Internationally with them, as well as Havanna Rakatan, Balletronic and Carmen la Cubana.

Azara has been practicing various styles of HipHop including breaking for the last 10 years. She is also a live artist and actress. Performance experience includes Indigo2, Wembley Stadium, and The Olympics opening Ceremony. Azara was runner in The Winter Pride Art Awards 2016 with her debut solo piece ‘I Am Woman’.

Hsing Ya, born in Taiwan is an International Contemporary dancer. East and West training practices including Ballet, Modern, Gaga, Tai-Chi, Yoga & Belly dancing make her a diverse artist. She is also a choreographer and teacher. Her performance experience includes in Taiwan includes Feng Dance Theatre, Dance Forum Taipei Company, WC dance company. Since she came to UK in 2016, she has performed for Appetite Dance Productions and recently joined Ella Mesma Company. Hsing Ya has also taken part in a Choreography Residency at Watermill Center, Long Island in New York, The American Dance Festival and The Taipei Artist Village.

Sabio is a Composer, producer, multi-instrumentalist based in London, Sabio has a masters degree in classical percussion (Academy of Music in Poland) and music production and performance (London Centre of Contemporary Music-). Sabio plays more than 150 instruments and his experience of working together with world famous artists, have contributed to enhancing his rare musical sensibility and interest in the science of sound.

Ciaran has worked at Melton Mowbray Theatre and Barry Young's Star Dust as well as gaining a BTEC in Technical Theatre (Brooksby Melton College), BA (hons) in Technical Theatre Studies at East15 acting school resulting in a full time position at Terry Tew Sound and Lighting. Ciran was charged with overseeing the Lighting and Rigging departments for 3 1⁄2 years before freelancing. He has lit work for Ballet Black, The Young Vic, New York Theatre Ballet and Gecko to name a few.

Jodie-Simone has created the costumes for this work, which will be completed ready for the 1st September and will be used from the first days of rehearsals in October. Jodie has been working within the Creative Arts for the past 5 years in Costume and Visual Aesthetics within Dance Theatre. Her experience as a researcher in marketing, television and radio, along with her passion for art and dance have given Jodie a well-rounded background in creative arts. She has worked with the Company since 2012. She has made costumes for Ivan Blackstock, Young Vic and Breakin Convention to name a few.

 

The Impact

Sadler's Wells liked our work so much that we will be premiering it in London at Sadler's Wells, with our very own Wildcard on 8th June 2017.

We want to reach a mixed audience including those not usually interested in dance through this issue based work. My intention is to  attract a mixed audience, including men as there are inferences relating to masculinity (not to just preach to the converted).

With the theme of gender in society and specifically perceptions of women’s role is universal, and following Michelle Obama's wonderful speech in October, and the surprising US election results, I feel this work has arrived at a poignant time. 

To date, people have said:

'Strong & Empowering' Richmix

'Brilliant show and Q&A session' Mandinga

'Timeless and current issues that women continue to face everyday' The Tabernacle 

'Absolutely stunning and provocative piece I saw last night , thank you for the inspiration and celebration of your exploration!!!' Yorkshire Dance

'Completely engaged- enthralling, emotional, inspiring and grounding work' Mercy Nabirye

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that sometimes its just not possible to donate but..... you can help by sharing our campaign too. 

Below are the links if you would like to help:

Website: www.ellamesma.co.uk

Twitter: @EllaMesma

Facebook: /EllaMesma

Instagram: @EllaMesmaCo

Crowdfunding Campaign: https://www.indiegogo.com/campaigns/lighting-up...

Sadler's Wells show: https://t.co/E9ndQK240L

THANK YOU! 

For your passion, for taking the time to read this campaign, for sharing, and for making a difference.

Big thanks from the Ladylike team
