In 2013, she was selected as a future Dance Leader for the ABLE leadership program, and in 2015, awarded a Bench fellowship for emerging choreographers. She is currently Associate Dance Artist at Dance City in Newcastle. As a performer, she has worked internationally including tours with Russell Maliphant Company, Southpaw Company, & performing for the Olympics Opening Ceremony, Wendy Houston’s ‘Stupid Women’, Warsan Shire (as featured in Beyonce’s ‘Lemonade’)'s ‘The Ugly Daughter’ and Adidas  
Anna is Anglo-Argentine, and studied dance and athletics from a young age. She studied dance at Facultade Angel Vianna in Rio de Janeiro and worked with Gustavo Cirico, Frederico Paredes, and Deborah Colker. Anna worked with Vertigo Dance Company in Israel in 2015. Anna is a Tango Dancer and assists for the Leandro Palou Tango Academy. She has taught workshops for Come Dancing and Strictly Come Dancing.
Lianett was born in La Habana, Cuba, and trained at the National School of Art in Cuba (ENA), graduating in 2005 with a gold title. In 2006 she joined the National Company of Contemporary Dance in Cuba and has toured Internationally with them, as well as Havanna Rakatan, Balletronic and Carmen la Cubana.
Azara has been practicing various styles of HipHop including breaking for the last 10 years. She is also a live artist and actress. Performance experience includes Indigo2, Wembley Stadium, and The Olympics opening Ceremony. Azara was runner in The Winter Pride Art Awards 2016 with her debut solo piece ‘I Am Woman’.
Hsing Ya, born in Taiwan is an International Contemporary dancer. East and West training practices including Ballet, Modern, Gaga, Tai-Chi, Yoga & Belly dancing make her a diverse artist. She is also a choreographer and teacher. Her performance experience includes in Taiwan includes Feng Dance Theatre, Dance Forum Taipei Company, WC dance company. Since she came to UK in 2016, she has performed for Appetite Dance Productions and recently joined Ella Mesma Company. Hsing Ya has also taken part in a Choreography Residency at Watermill Center, Long Island in New York, The American Dance Festival and The Taipei Artist Village.
Sabio is a Composer, producer, multi-instrumentalist based in London, Sabio has a masters degree in classical percussion (Academy of Music in Poland) and music production and performance (London Centre of Contemporary Music-). Sabio plays more than 150 instruments and his experience of working together with world famous artists, have contributed to enhancing his rare musical sensibility and interest in the science of sound.
Ciaran has worked at Melton Mowbray Theatre and Barry Young's Star Dust as well as gaining a BTEC in Technical Theatre (Brooksby Melton College), BA (hons) in Technical Theatre Studies at East15 acting school resulting in a full time position at Terry Tew Sound and Lighting. Ciran was charged with overseeing the Lighting and Rigging departments for 3 1⁄2 years before freelancing. He has lit work for Ballet Black, The Young Vic, New York Theatre Ballet and Gecko to name a few.
Jodie-Simone has created the costumes for this work, which will be completed ready for the 1st September and will be used from the first days of rehearsals in October. Jodie has been working within the Creative Arts for the past 5 years in Costume and Visual Aesthetics within Dance Theatre. Her experience as a researcher in marketing, television and radio, along with her passion for art and dance have given Jodie a well-rounded background in creative arts. She has worked with the Company since 2012. She has made costumes for Ivan Blackstock, Young Vic and Breakin Convention to name a few.
 

The Impact
Sadler's Wells liked our work so much that we will be premiering it in London at Sadler's Wells, with our very own Wildcard on 8th June 2017.
We want to reach a mixed audience including those not usually interested in dance through this issue based work. My intention is to  attract a mixed audience, including men as there are inferences relating to masculinity (not to just preach to the converted).
With the theme of gender in society and specifically perceptions of women’s role is universal, and following Michelle Obama's wonderful speech in October, and the surprising US election results, I feel this work has arrived at a poignant time. 
To date, people have said:
'Strong & Empowering' Richmix
'Brilliant show and Q&A session' Mandinga
'Timeless and current issues that women continue to face everyday' The Tabernacle 
'Absolutely stunning and provocative piece I saw last night , thank you for the inspiration and celebration of your exploration!!!' Yorkshire Dance
'Completely engaged- enthralling, emotional, inspiring and grounding work' Mercy Nabirye
 

Other Ways You Can Help
We understand that sometimes its just not possible to donate but..... you can help by sharing our campaign too. 
Below are the links if you would like to help:
Website: www.ellamesma.co.uk
Twitter: @EllaMesma
Facebook: /EllaMesma
Instagram: @EllaMesmaCo
Crowdfunding Campaign: https://www.indiegogo.com/campaigns/lighting-up...
Sadler's Wells show: https://t.co/E9ndQK240L
THANK YOU! 
For your passion, for taking the time to read this campaign, for sharing, and for making a difference.
Big thanks from the Ladylike team

story:
Short Summary

CARMILLA is a stage adaptation of the Gothic novella by Joseph Sheridan Le Fanu, one of the earliest works of vampire fiction, predating Bram Stoker's Dracula by 26 years. Set in a Victorian world, CARMILLA explores themes of queer sexuality, gender, sexual agency, and toxic masculinity through burlesque, horror, camp, drama, romance, and sensuality.

Pointed Cap Playhouse is thrilled to present the world premiere of CARMILLA at the St. Ambroise Montreal Fringe Festival with 6 shows May 31st-June 8th, and at The Toronto Fringe Festival with 10 shows July 4th-15. 

Pointed Cap Playhouse is a collaborative theatre & burlesque company led by Sly Feiticeira and St. Stella, focused on innovative, immersive, interactive productions exploring roles of gender, stereotypes, and interpretation of classic tropes using theatre, comedy, music & striptease. As two full-time artists, we strive to create uniquely beautiful experiences for our audience while respecting the time, talent and craft that each of our artists brings to the production. This is where we need your help!

CARMILLA is a "profit-share" production, meaning all proceeds are split between our team. Most of these proceeds come from ticket sales. However, there are many costs that go into producing independent theatre and ticket sales alone - even if both runs sold out - would not come close to fairly compensating the many hundreds of hours collectively put into this labour of (eternal) love. 
 

The CARMILLA Team includes:
Dora Award Winner Heath V. Salazar
Dora Award Nominee Sebastian Marziali
Burlesque Hall of Fame performer St. Stella

CARMILLA is brought to you by some of the creative team that brought you sold-out Lysistrata at Toronto Fringe 2017.
Praise for Lysistrata:

  • “Between the slapstick and strip teases, the power of love, laughter, and freedom are fearlessly affirmed. This is, in all seriousness, the best burlesque I have seen in Toronto.”
    -Mooney on Theatre
  • NNNNN - Now Magazine
  • Nominated for a My Entertainment World Critics Pick award, Best Ensemble.

What We Need
 

Here's a breakdown of our anticipated costs:

$200/actor for costumes

$900 for transportation to Montreal

$400/night for accomodation in Montreal

$570 for MTL Fringe fees

$750 for TO Fringe fees

$250 for promotional materials

$226 for accessible toilet rental for TO Fringe

$500 for lighting rental

$500 for rehearsal space rental

+ as much profit on top of this as we can muster so that all our artists and crew are compensated fairly, being a profit-share production!

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If money is tight but you'd still like to spread the love:

    • Use the Indiegogo share tools to share this campaign!
    • Follow Pointed Cap Playhouse on social media:
      • instagram.com/pointedcapplayhouse
      • facebook.com/pointedcapplayhouse
      • twitter.com/pointedcapplay

story:
The Coup de Comedy 2020 is canceled  :-(
Help us get a head start on 2021! :-)

Hello iRev Family,

Based upon the current global situation and the directives of UCI’s Chancellor, we are saddened to announce that the Coup de Comedy 2020 (CdC 2020) is canceled.

It was not an easy decision, but we strongly feel it is the right one. As a result, all the funds raised (and perks earned) in the CdC 2020 Indigogo campaign will go towards CdC 2021 - please consider lifting our spirits by boosting next year’s festival with a donation or by sharing our link: https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/coup-de-come...

Also currently all of our shows and workshops next quarter are on hold, but iRev will continue in some form and we will keep you posted on the details.

If you have any questions, please feel free to contact us to or email: mailto:improvrevolution@gmail.com or via any of our social media handles. 

Again, we are sorry for this announcement and hope that you all are doing your best to stay healthy and hopeful.

Thank you,

Improv Revolution

J. Andres Serrano

---------

Hey! We're Improv Revolution, and we're here to immerse you an amazing comedy festival for FREE: The Coup de Comedy, a FREE four-day comedy festival consisting of panels, workshops, and shows, available to the community for FREE. Did you hear us say FREE!

However, it takes a lot of support for us to be able to provide FREE Comedy for All! Will you help us this year?

The Coup de Comedy 2020 will welcome back some old friends to teach and play, and introduce exciting new people and teams, featuring some of the most talented comedic artists in the world, and we can't wait to show you what we've got in store, including our Revolutionary Comedy Award honoring our special VIP celebrity guest!

What We Need & What You Get

Right now, we're asking for $3,750 for the Coup de Comedy in order to fund:

Production of a professional-grade festival including technical and running costs.

Advertising and promotion. We want as many people as possible to benefit from attending the Coup.

Bringing the talents of renowned teachers and comedians to the public for free.

Awesome Swag for Festival Attendees. 

The Coup de Comedy is the pride of Improv Revolution, and we're working hard to build our comedy community at UCI, in Orange County, and beyond. Offering a quality festival for free is of utmost importance to us because we believe the joy of comedy should be accessible by all!

Every dollar of your donation goes towards the comedy endeavors of Improv Revolution and is a vote of confidence in the future of comedy. Every dollar counts, so please contribute any way you can. We are young comedians promising to match your monetary donations with our hard work. Thank you.

The Impact

The Coup de Comedy has become a UCI tradition, where high-level comedy performances are made accessible for anyone who wants to attend!

Give students the opportunity to watch and work with top-notch comedians.

This is the seventh year of the Coup de Comedy, and with each year, we gain more experience and learn how to put on an even better festival! 

Get Involved!

This festival is for the comedy community at large, and we want you to feel included! Even if you can't make a monetary donation, there are still valuable ways to help us out:

Share this campaign with your friends! There are Indiegogo share tools that make telling others easy! 

LIKE our Facebook Page for the latest updates!

Or just come to the Coup de Comedy Festival 2020 on May 20-23, 2020! Free registration opens in April.

Who Are We?

Improv Revolution (or iRev) is a 9-year-old undergraduate improvisational ensemble at UC Irvine that performs long form and short form improv on campus and local festivals. We give free weekly workshops for students interested in improvisation. We are involved in community outreach with local schools and perform with other community teams and college groups.

"LIKE" our Facebook Page for the latest updates on all of our activities.

Hope to see you at the Coup de Comedy Festival 2020 and our upcoming shows!

story:
Short Summary

I am Kara M. Tyler. I've been a theatre maker in one form or another for some 20+ years. My artist life was rolling along in LA & NYC, until 3 years ago when I was struck with an acute case of complete artistic boredom. I needed to create with a new perspective, hear new voices, younger voices, as of yet unheard voices. So I packed up my life in the States and came to Graduate school in England. 

During my 2 years back in school I have become painfully aware of the non-balance of our storytelling, that our plight for inclusivity is still lacking in certain demographics, and in particular  we are often ill equipped and short- sighted in our work with actors with "disabilities". We cannot claim that art represents life if we do not represent ALL of life.  When I read 'Woman of Flowers' by Kaite O'Reilly, I fell in love with the poetry and nuance, with the cultural references, the female voice of the writing, and the thrill that our heroine, who is deaf, uses a combination of Sign language (BSL), lip reading and speaking English that will bring the  D/deaf and hearing communities together as one audience.  

My MFA (Master Fine Arts) program provides me the theatre, tech team, and basic props and costumes.  Outside of my University I  have managed to pull together an amazing team of 4 wonderful actors, a gifted Assistant Director, a Music Director who's creating original music with his musicians, and a movement choreographer.

What I don't have is a budget to provide props &  possible BSL interpretive support the school cannot offer and to alleviate travel and basic expenses for the actors & creatives.  They are a gifted lot of people putting HOURS into a project out of passion and a desire to honor art, inclusivity and the human experience.  As all ticket sales will go back to the University there will be nothing covering my out of pocket expenses (accrued on top of the fees of being a student!). 

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need £1200 to cover:

Actors stipend: travel, lunch, transporting instruments, etc. This is just to cover their expenses--but the more you donate the more goes to also covering some of their time (*They are volunteering their CAREER hours--not everyone would do that for their profession!).

Props: There will be some things not covered by the school budget ie; Bodhran (Irish drum) 

Marketing:  It would be nice to have physical postcards/flyers outside of the social networking and media marketing.

AND if we are able to achieve our goal or higher we would also like to make a donation to Deaf Unity who's mission is to unite the deaf community locally, regionally and globally. As we are a cast of English, Welsh, Scottish, Australian and American artists it seems befitting to pick a charity that empowers deaf communities around the world. 

What do you get?! 

You will be listed in our programs donors page for your generosity and receive a personalized thank you video from the rehearsal room! And the satisfaction in knowing that you were a contributor not just to the arts but in being one step closer to 'normalizing' a more inclusive future for the theatre.

I would like to make note that my University, like many, does not have captioning, nor a budget for a show interpreter.  To make this work for both the Deaf and Hearing audience I am typing the whole show into powerpoint and projecting as we go. The other challenge is that sign language, as a visual language (which is different for each country- British Sign Language here) takes hours of creative interpreting and aside from an interpreter to the hearing community, a BSL creative consultant would normally be called in. However Creative Consultants are not part of a Government funded budget and an expense that myself and most small companies are unable to afford.  This presents more working time and pressure for the Deaf actors and their directors. Because of the challenges involved many companies/Universities are prevented from undertaking  projects like 'Woman of Flowers'.  I would love to one day see captioning and interpreters as part of our mainstream working life.  But this will only happen if the need is exposed.

  • IF we do not reach our goal, do not fear, THE SHOW MUST GO ON!--We all just might be sleeping on couches and visiting your house at mealtime! 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word, share this campaign as well as the dates and time of the show! (https://www.east15.ac.uk/productions-london-lou...)   And while you are at it take a look at:   https://deafunity.org/about-us/

story:
What is Human Resources?

Human Resources is a brand new musical with book and lyrics by Mallory Schlossberg, music by Mallory Schlossberg and Alexandra Smith, and arrangements/scoring by Alexandra Smith. This December, we'll be premiering it for the first time ever on Zoom! 

The plot (without spoilers!)

Emily Silverberg is a writer who is down on her luck after losing her job at a pseudo-health startup. Her job was supposed to cover IVF and infertility treatments, and now she can't afford them. (She's got a lot of debt from her MFA program.) Her supportive husband, Max, encourages her to apply to work at a bigger and better company—the health food empire Greener Pastures—but before Emily can even apply, she gets a mysterious message from the company's recruiter, who asks her if she wants to be part of something bigger than herself. Once Emily starts working at Greener Pastures, she begins to suspect something’s not quite right. The company's mission is to "to feed the earth," and...let's just say they do that very literally. 

Human Resources takes a twist from work-place satire to full-on B-horror comedy. It's a campy, over-the-top musical with original songs that asks us what we'd be willing to give up for purpose and a place, while simultaneously tearing down the systems that prevent us from truly succeeding.

Why we're doing this fundraiser

Producing independent theater takes a lot. Yes, even though we are able to save money from not having rehearsal spaces/a theater, there are lots of other costs involved. We've got musicians, technicians, actors, and beyond making this show come to life. There's marketing and promotional costs. We've got to send critical materials to performers, production equipment, props, and more. And whatever we can give to the artists we will. Additionally, show tickets will be pay-what-you-can and will be divided up among the artists involved. So even if you don't donate now, we encourage you to pay for a ticket when we air the show in December - it will help support artists!

If we don't reach our goal, we'll still be able to use what we have to fund aspects of the show. 

We can't give up on making new theater, and we can't give up on artists.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute? Feel free to get the word out by sharing this! Or, as stated above, seeing the show later and (if you can) buying tickets.

Thank you!

story:
WHO WE ARE

We are a talanted group of actors in Los Angeles, gathered from all over the world. We have come together to tell fascinating and original stories through our art form.

We write, act, direct and produce our own material. Each one of us has their own unique voice which makes for a unique and compelling story.

Previous successful shows that we have done are: "The Last Night Inn" at the Victory Theatre and "Bench Stories" at the ACME Theatre, Hollywood. 

THE CAST of "Stories on the Rocks":

  • Anthony Montes                      
  • Sam LaFrance
  • Desi Ivanova
  • Kika Cicmanec
  • Charlotte Plummer
  • Adam Shirley
  • William Walker
  • Valentina Kolaric 
  • Roxanna Medina
  • Michael Dvorak
  • Sara Blindauer
  • Won Lee
  • Sophia Monti

Producer: Meghan Riley

Stage Manager: Tina Fy

Assistant Stage Manager: Alex Genther 

Artisitc Director: Anthony Montes

OUR PURPOSE

This campaign is to help produce our next show. We have all written a compilation of 6 amazing one act plays called-

"STORIES ON THE ROCKS"! Now we are simply looking to raise $6000 to put this show up. SO PLEASE help us and donate.

THE IMPACT

We beleive in the individuality and unique experience of every person and we express that in our plays. We aren't afraid of any subject matter as long as it makes up for a gripping story. Our plays are bold, gritty, raw, quirky, passionate and heartfelt. We make you cry through laughter and smile through tears.

story:
YMI Dancing is a branch of the Pia Bouman School for Ballet and Creative Movement in Toronto, a not-for-profit charity. Our mandate is to bring dance to the community at large and to provide a professional performance and creation experience for our dancers.  

YMI Dancing is struggling to continue its activities due to a lack of resources and the rising cost of expenses. The company approaches its 25th anniversary next year, and we are in the position that we are struggling to fulfill our mandate. YMI Dancing needs support to be able to create new work and get it out to the community at large, giving the young dancers the unique experience that YMI Dancing can offer. Your support can enable YMI to keep dancing.


                

If we achieve our funding goal, our plan is two fold:

  1. Invite two professional guest choreographers to create new work to be performed alongside YMI’s archival repertoire in our 25th anniversary gala performance.
  2. To strengthen our outreach in the community by building a roster of adaptable performances that can be brought to young and old, and will also complement the TDSB curriculum. Our community performances are brought to those who would otherwise not have the opportunity to see live performance.

YMI Dancing is currently solely supported by the Pia Bouman School, ticket sales, and fees that the dancers pay. This is not enough to sustain the company.


When you donate, you become a part of YMI.

The unique perks that we are giving you are a way for you to truly be a part of YMI, and see your ideas come to life through dance. Check them out in the sidebar!

Because YMI Dancing is part of a charitable organization, you will also receive a tax receipt for your contribution.

Any amount, big or small, will make a significant impact on YMI Dancing's future. Thank you for your support!


Registered Charity #893008375RR0001

*please note that due to CRA guidelines, tax receipts will be made for the total amount donated less the monetary value of any perk that you receive.

story:
A Little About Me

Hi everyone! My name is Annie Grove, and I am one step - or flight - away from fulfilling a dream. In high school, I participated in many fundraising efforts for both community and world-wide projects. After graduating, I delayed admission to college so I could volunteer full-time in a South Philadelphia middle school. I work 50 hours a week, take dance classes, and study with an acting teacher. At the same time, I'm applying to universities and conservatories for 2013-2014. I live on a small stipend that averages about $3 an hour.
 
 My dream is to become a professional actress and bring theatre into everyone's life, especially those who might never experience it. In everything I've done, I've been brave enough to start and strong enough to finish. For the last two years of high school, I earned a scholarship to a performing arts high school. I have worked part-time since I was 15. Now I need help for one more step in my education.
 
 
 

             What I Need and How You Can Help :)

Recently, I auditioned for the Guildhall School of Music and Drama. The school embodies a rigorous and academic craft unlike any other. I was given a final callback, which means that I must travel to London. This is the most incredible opportunity I've ever been given. The Guildhall panel sees over 2,300 hopeful applicants each season, and they invite only a handful back to London. However, I don't have airfare to London. Without the funds to travel, I cannot audition and earn a place in the school.

 Plane tickets are about $1,000-$1,700 dollars during the season. Once I get to London, I have a place to stay. I still need to budget a small amount for food and emergency money.

 

Even if I don't reach my entire goal, all of the donated funds will go towards my plane ticket. I'm trying many different avenues to raise this money, and I realize that the amount will come together in small amounts. For that reason, all amounts are equally appreciated. A family friend once said, "Never disregard a penny. Without it, 99 cents can't become a dollar."

 

                   What This Means To Me

When Guildhall invited me to come to London, I had to sit down because I almost fainted. Working with students this year has transformed and inspired me. Better than ever, I understand how theatre can unite a divided planet, and every child deserves the chance to experience great performances. I feel that it is finally my time to chase a dream.
First, I have to attend my callback for Guildhall! While I'm in London, I will attend various classes, workshops and interviews. This is an incredibly competitive program that requires not only maturity, but strength and everlasting passion as well. 
I am very humble in asking for help.  To me, $1,300 seems like a huge amount, but I'm confident in my ability to succeed. Any penny spared is greatly appreciated.
 

 

                 Other Ways You Can Help

Naturally, I understand that it is not possible for everyone to contribute funds! DON'T SWEAT IT! If you cannot contribute please don't worry! Instead all I ask is that you simply help me spread the word. If you follow Indiegogo's directions on sharing campaigns you will see that it's a very simple thing to do! Thank you all!

 

Words cannot express how much everyone's support means to me.

 

Love,

 

Annie Grove

 

 

 

Also a side note, 1,300 is around the minimum I need for a plane ticket! If it's possible I would like to keep raising funds until I reach 1,700!

:)

story:
PLEASE NOTE: This will NOT be available to persons living in Las Vegas, North Las Vegas or Henderson, NV - 

All money raised from this campaign will be donated to the International AIDS Organization for Education and Outreach programs!

Fallen Guardian Angels - Live on Stage - Brought to you with live streaming over the internet on December 1, 2012 - World AIDS Day - at 7:30pm Pacific Time (USA)

"Fallen Guardian Angels" has been named "The Official Script of World AIDS Day" and was recently inducted into the International AIDS Organization Archives as a dramatic historical recreation of the beginnings of the AIDS Pandemic. 

While Fallen Guardian Angels is fast becoming an HIV/AIDS organization fundraiser for High Schools around the globe, as well as several theatre groups, some areas and organizations have been unable to mount their own productions of "Fallen Guardian Angels" - Other people, because Internet and Social Media is one outlet forbidden (due to hate groups and overly sensitive PTA's) - cannot find a local production...You can follow along, as we will post photos from rehearsal as we progress toward performance night!

This is a chance to watch the production in the comfort of your own home - or, if you are an HIV/AIDS Organization, and want to raise money from this production, just select the second option (for $10) and you have the rights to stream it live onto your large screen TV from the website - Please note: We need to charge a fee for the right to show the stream and show at least one person attending - that is why there is a $10 charge - This is to protect the copyright of the script - 

How this will work - After you donate, you will be able to return to this campaign on December 1st, 2012 - In the "Update" section, there will be the link to the website for streaming video - The video may be available in archive for a couple of weeks after, but, to be certain you do see the production, please put on your calendars to watch us at 7:30pm Pacific Time - The stream will start approximately 10 minutes before the start of the production. 

You can donate more than the requested $5 - if you are at home and invite six people, just use the "different" amount link - Please include your email address so we can send you the link if you're unable to access the "Update" link - 

AGAIN: THIS LINK WILL BE ON BLACK OUT FOR THE CITIES OF LAS VEGAS, HENDERSON AND NORTH LAS VEGAS, NV -

story:
Our Story

My name is Cleveland Dominy. I live in the Hill Country near Austin, Texas. I have been in law enforcement since 1987. I have always had a passion for writing and storytelling. At the present time I have completed six books and numerous one-act plays. I feel it is time for me to pursue my true passion in life as being a writer and storyteller.

 

Bravura Theatre Company is going to produce three of my plays in â€œAn Evening of One-Acts by Cleveland Dominyâ€ in the spring of 2012. The plays in this production are Because I Love You, Old Dime Box, and One Suicide is Enough. 


Excerpts from the plays can be seen at http://www.native-heart.com under writings.

 

Bravura Theatre Company was founded in 2006 by Jake Coe â€“ a young, enthusiastic actor who is passionate about live theatre.

 

Possum Box Productions (http://www.possumbox.tv/ ) will film our plays. Possum Box is a brand new production company founded and created by a group of very talented young adults in Austin, TX.


Costumes and advisory will be by Virginia Davis of Midnight Breeze Designs:  http://www.midnightbreezedesigns.com. 

 

I am fortunate to have a network of very talented actors and artists who believe in me. We will be able to schedule a practice and performance venue when we begin receiving funds. We have scouted out several theatre venues in Austin where the majority of our team members live, work, and play. Our team will construct the sets, find props, manage the light and sound, create the costumes, cast, direct, and film,

 


The Impact

My goal is that our production of my plays will give other writers, performers, and artists hope that there is a way that they, too, can get their works out there. It will offer an opportunity for local performers to practice their craft and help the young start up theatre and production companies to gain recognition.

 

This is a link in a circle of very talented people who are seeking an avenue to display their creation and talents, including myself. Without it dreams vanish.

 

An Evening of One-Acts by Cleveland Dominy will be an entertaining night out for anyone attending and show all that there is hope in these tough times.

 

If this venture doesnâ€™t happen then the young Americans who are trying to get recognition for their talents will not get this opportunity and there will be one less casting call in Austin which might have led to some promising performer being discovered.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Our main expense is the fees for the practice and performance venue. We need $3000 for renting the venue, constructing the sets, costumes, printing the playbills and programs, and advertising.

 

We are all just working people without the means to fulfill these dreams. Without the support of our contributors we will be unable to accomplish our goal.

 

You help to bring new talent and original works that have never been seen out into the world. You will be there at the ground level of the launch of many talents. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us spread the word. Share me on facebook, google plus, and other social networks. Please invite your friends and family to help spread the word of our venture and let anyone that may be interested know about the plays. You can use the share tools available on this site.

story:
THE PLAY:

A forgery of jealousy about two women who defy expectations, set in a world rife with natural disaster, magic and the absence of personal responsibility, DIVE is a contemporary pre-quell to A Midsummer Night's Dream. Inspired by Adrienne Rich, Shakespeare, Rumi, incorporating original soundscapes, stylized movement and multi media Dive explores the untold story between a young Titania, the new Fairie Queen and a Votress (woman who has visions) who becomes a holy priestess of Titania's order, to a dangerous end. A tale of possession and gender, the war of the sexes and the value of vision.

DIVE was originally commissioned by Blue Box Productions for Sticky Fall/Winter 2010, at the Bowery Poetry Club in New York City. 


Now (we are thrilled to bits!) an 30 min expanded version of DIVE has been chosen by the Philadelphia Shakespeare Theatre as one of the plays featured in The Classical Cabaret Series.

 

WHAT WE NEED and WHAT YOU GET

 

We've already raised the first $450 of our budget and only need to raise the last $500 to tour DIVE to The Philadelphia Shakespeare Theatre’s Classical Cabaret Series!

 

Any gift amount from $1. on up, makes our hearts light up with gratitude.

Your money will help pay for:

--transportation and lodging for artists

--prop, costume, and set materials

 

 

You Get: Vip perks for gifts of $150. $100. and $50.

 

SHARE

 

We know not everyone can make a donation.

 You can always  help by spreading the word about this project to your friends, on Facebook, Twitter, Myspace, community bulletin boards…

 

VIP Perks

 

Titania $150

with a donation of $150 you have the option to select a Private Core Vinyasa Yoga Session with Jody* and a Private Pilates Mat Session with Ana*. ($240 value)

 

Votress $100

With a donation of $100. You have the option to select your choice of a Full Body Stretch session with Ana, a Private Core Vinyasa Yoga Session with Jody or a Private Pilates Mat Session with Ana. ($120 value)

 

Blue Boy $50

 

with a donation of $50 you have the option to select a 30 min guided meditation session with Jody or 30 minute stretching session with Ana

 

 

 

*Jody Christopherson is a certified Core Vinyasa Yoga instructor registered with Yoga Alliance

*Ana Valle is a certified Pilates Teacher, and Personal Trainer

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it’s important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it’s going. Be transparent and specific—people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don’t reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
The Story

        In this dark tragicomic play, the emperor Caligula has just suffered the loss of his beloved wife Drusilla and, shocked by the horror and meaninglessness of life, takes it out on Rome. He murders elected officials at random, impersonates Venus, goddess of love, and demands nothing less than the moon.

Background

 

The idea to put on Caligula arose when some of the team members were having an intellectual discussion about the ills of our time. Assistant Director Marianne brought up Caligula by Nobel Prize winner Albert Camus. Director Ittai Orr's search for a great, utterly shocking play to put on spring of his senior year had ended, and the team already in place could not be more excited and passionate about the production, not to mention enthralled with the play's wit and style. The only problem was that the existing English translation was stodgy, British, and old. That's why Marianne and Ittai set out to create a new, energetic adaptation, which now sees the stage for the first time.

The stellar cast is led by New York City native Samson Kohanski, who comes to the role of Caligula after studying at Michael Howard Studios and performing with the American Repertory Theatre, the Strawberry One Act Festival and the Commonwealth Shakespeare Company in Boston. 

Performance dates are Friday, March 30th at 8pm and Saturday March 31st at 3pm and 8pm at the Roy Arias Little Theater at Times Square. Tickets can be purchased here: http://caligula.ticketleap.com/caligula/

 


Why Now?

 

 A sense of loss and helplessness has been thick in the air. And one of the darker consequences of loss is rage, a feeling this play certainly captures. Still, there is hope, however brief and quiet, and it’s the excitement of that possibility that makes Caligula a worthwhile production. It’s the perfect time to put this on, when like Caligula, many seriously subscribe to the notion that “freedom must always come at someone else’s expense." There is, as Camus would suggest, another way. Caligula speaks to a universal and deeply personal feeling of loss that everyone goes through at least once in their lives. It sheds light on the profound questions still left open by the bloody twentieth century. A truly ensemble effort, it draws from the strengths and passions of the entire team. 

 


What We Need & What You Get

 

        Putting on a play is expensive. The Roy Arias Little Theatre, where Caligula will be performed, costs a total of $3,000 to rent for the week and compounded with other expenses like props, publicity materials, set pieces and costumes, brings us to a budget of about $5,000. Some of it will be earned back through ticket revenue and a small grant we won from the St. Anthony Hall Educational Fund. But we won't even come close to breaking even without your support. 
       Our mission is to create an experience that lives up to Oscar Wilde's idea of theater as "the most immediate way in which a human being can share with another the sense of what it is to be a human being." Our goal is to attempt to contribute to and revive a tradition of theater that asks the hardest questions and tells the most important truths about being human. Caligula helps us understand so much about our own times, from the hopelessness of terrorism to the deeply personal experience of grappling with morality, meaning and loss. Like any truly great work, Caligula is vital, and we can't wait to bring it to New York.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

 

Like us on our Facebook Page http://www.facebook.com/caligula2012 and share the Indiegogo with friends!
